Megan Ming Francis is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Political Science at the University of Washington where she specializes in the study of American politics, race, and the development of constitutional law. She is particularly interested in the construction of rights and citizenship, black political activism, and the post-civil war South. Born and raised in Seattle, WA, she was educated at Garfield High School, Rice University in Houston, and Princeton University where she received her M.A. and her Ph.D. in Politics.

In her award winning book, Civil Rights and the Making of the Modern American State, shows that the battle against lynching and mob violence in the first quarter of the 20th century were pivotal to the development of civil rights and the growth of federal court power. She is inspired by people who fight for justice–even when the end appears nowhere in sight.

talk: A Holocaust survivor's blueprint for happiness
speaker: Eddie Jaku
speaker_bio:
Eddie Jaku OAM, born Abraham Jakubowicz in Germany in 1920.

His family considered themselves German, first, Jewish second. On 9 November 1938, the night immortalised as Kristallnacht, Eddie returned home from boarding school to an empty house. At dawn Nazi soldiers burst in, Eddie was beaten and taken to Buchenwald.

Eddie was released and with his father escaped to Belgium and then France, but was again captured and sent to a camp, and thereafter to Auschwitz. On route, Eddie managed to escape back to Belgium where he lived in hiding with his parents and sister.

In October 1943, Eddie’s family were arrested and again sent to Auschwitz where his parents were both murdered. In 1945, Eddie was sent on a ‘death march’ but once again escaped and hid in a forest eating slugs and snails until June 1945 he was finally rescued by.

Eddie has volunteered at the Sydney Jewish Museum since it’s inception in 1992. Self-proclaimed as ‘the happiest man on earth’, he saw death every day throughout WWII, and because he managed to survive, made a vow to himself to smile every day.

Edie has been married to Flore for 73 years, they have two sons, grandchildren and great grandchildren.

talk: How to cope with anxiety
speaker: Olivia Remes
speaker_bio: Anxiety is one of most prevalent mental health disorders, with 1 out of 14 people around the world being likely affected. Leading up to conditions such as depression, increased risk for suicide, disability and requirement of high health services, very few people who often need treatment actually receive it. In her talk “How to cope with anxiety”, Olivia Remes of the University of Cambridge will share her vision on anxiety and will unravel ways to treat and manage this health disorder. Arguing that treatments such as psychotherapy and medication exist and often result in poor outcome and high rates of relapses, she will emphasise the importance of harnessing strength in ourselves as we modify our problem-coping mechanisms. At TEDxUHasselt 2017, Olivia will stress that by allowing ourselves to believe that what happens in life is comprehensive, meaningful, and manageable, one can significantly improve their risk of developing anxiety disorders.

speaker_occ: Paleontologist - Head of the School of Biological Sciences at the University of Bristol.
speaker_bio:
Michael Benton is a paleontologist who has made fundamental contributions to understanding the history of life, particularly concerning how biodiversity changes through time. Ηis approach has revolutionised our understanding of major questions. A key theme is the Permo–Triassic mass extinction, the largest mass extinction of all time, which took place over 250 million years ago, where he investigates how life was able to recover from such a devastating event.
He has written more than 50 books and he founded the MSc in Palaeobiology at Bristol in 1996, from which more than 320 students have graduated. He has supervised more than 65 PhD students. He is currently Head of the School of Biological Sciences at the University of Bristol. He was elected Fellow of the Royal Society in 2014.

Lindiwe Mazibuko was until recently the Leader of the Opposition in the South African National Assembly, making her the Democratic Alliance’s (DA) youngest-ever
parliamentary leader and the first black woman in South African history to be elected to the post of Leader of the Opposition. Mazibuko committed herself to making
Parliament the true centre of robust political debate and engagement in South Africa. In May 2014, at the end of her term and following a successful electoral campaign in which the DA grew its share of the national vote from 16% to 22%, Mazibuko announced that she would take a sabbatical from active politics.
In May 2015, she graduated from Harvard University’s John F. Kennedy School of Government with a Master of Public
Administration (MPA), and since September 2015 she has been in residence at the Institute of Politics (IOP) at Harvard
University as a Fall Resident Fellow.

Brian has worked on redistricting software for over a decade, resulting in an efficient system that can solve for compact, impartial, non-gerrymandered districts on a home computer. This work has been cited in the Washington Post and scholarly journals. The software is Free and Open Source allowing anyone to verify its function or tinker with it to make it better.

Brian earned a B.S. in Computer Science from Carnegie Mellon University.

Returning home to Reno he quickly got back into the saddle and started coaching at his high school Alma mater. Recently he fulfilled his dream of being the Varsity Offensive Line Coach and at the age of 21 became the youngest Line Coach in the school’s history. A senior at the University of Nevada, Reno, Shane is majoring in Finance and Economics. In addition to school and coaching, he currently works as the Marketing Manager at Oliver Wickes and Associates® and he is the author of the blog Faith, Family, Football.

In early 2014, Adam successfully crowd-funded a documentary on student loan debt, raising nearly $70,000 in 45 days. The film, Broke Busted & Disgusted is due out in early 2015 and is already garnering critical acclaim. The mission of the film is to start a national debate about changing the way we fund college and not crippling 20 somethings with mountains of debt.
Adam’s core message is we are all after the same thing – to relentlessly pursue our passions, live simply and happily, and make a difference to those around us.

I'm a social scientist currently working on my first book, "The End of Animal Farming." I sometimes write articles in outlets such as in Huffington Post and Vox, and I've given talks in 15 different countries on the topics of effective altruism, animal protection, and food ethics. I'm the Research Director at Sentience Institute, a nonprofit, effective altruism think tank launched in June 2017 focused on expanding humanity's moral circle. talk: Schrödinger's cat

speaker_bio: I’m an Associate Professor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy at Union College, and I write books about science for non-scientists. I also blog about physics and other things at Forbes.com and ScienceBlogs.com. I have a BA in physics from Williams College and a Ph.D. in Chemical Physics from the University of Maryland, College Park (studying laser cooling at the National Institute of Standards and Technology in the lab of Bill Phillips, who shared the 1997 Nobel in Physics). I was a post-doc at Yale, and have been at Union since 2001. My books _How to Teach Physics to Your Dog_ and _How to Teach Relativity to Your Dog_ explain modern physics through imaginary conversations with my German Shepherd, Emmy, and my most recent book, _Eureka: Discovering Your Inner Scientist_ (Basic, 2014), explains how we use the process of science in everyday activities. I live in Niskayuna, NY with my wife, Kate Nepveu, our two kids, and Emmy, the Queen of Niskayuna.

talk: A needle in countless haystacks
speaker: Ariel Anbar
speaker_bio: Ariel Anbar is a scientist and educator interested in Earth’s past and future evolution as an inhabited world, and the prospects for life beyond. His group’s major focus is the chemical evolution of the atmosphere and oceans, as revealed by the development of novel geochemical methods. Trained as a geologist and a chemist, Anbar is a President’s Professor at Arizona State University, where he is on the faculty of the School of Earth & Space Exploration and the School of Molecular Sciences, and a Distinguished Sustainability Scholar in the Global Institute of Sustainability. The author or co-author of over 100 refereed papers, Anbar directed ASU’s NASA-funded Astrobiology Program from 2009 – 2015, and oversees ASU’s new Center for Education Through eXploration. He is a graduate of Harvard (A.B. 1989) and Caltech (Ph.D. 1996). Before coming to ASU he was on the faculty of the University of Rochester from 1996 to 2004. Anbar is a Fellow of the Geological Society of America, which awarded him the Donath Medal in 2002. He was recognized as an HHMI Professor in 2014, and elected a Fellow of the Geochemical Society and the European Association of Geochemistry in 2015.

speaker_bio: Our world is not flat, says ecnomist Pankaj Ghemawat -- it's at best semi-globalized, with limited interactions between countries and economies.

talk: Online video -- annotated, remixed and popped
speaker: Ryan Merkley
speaker_bio: Ryan Merkley is the Chief Operating Officer at the Mozilla Foundation, and is dedicated to making the web a more user-friendly place.

talk: The city of walls
speaker: Lars Brownworth

talk: My battle to expose government corruption
speaker: Heather Brooke
speaker_bio: Heather Brooke campaigns for freedom of information, requesting one secret document at a time.

talk: Science is for everyone, kids included
speaker: Beau Lotto
speaker_bio: Beau Lotto seeks to pull aside the curtain of why we see what we do in order to create the possibility and agency in deciding what to perceive next.

talk: Let's pool our medical data
speaker: John Wilbanks
speaker_bio: Imagine the discoveries that could result from a giant pool of freely available health and genomic data. John Wilbanks is working to build it.

talk: Smart failure for a fast-changing world
speaker: Eddie Obeng
speaker_bio: Our environment changes faster than we can learn about it, Eddie Obeng says. How do we keep up?

talk: The secret lives of paintings
speaker: Maurizio Seracini
speaker_bio: Maurizio Seracini uses advanced tools common in engineering and medical labs to unravel centuries-old mysteries of art.

talk: Talk nerdy to me
speaker: Melissa Marshall
speaker_bio: Melissa Marshall aims to teach great communication skills to scientists and engineers, so that they can effectively share their work.

talk: What's so funny about mental illness?
speaker: Ruby Wax
speaker_bio: Ruby Wax is a loud, funny woman -- who spent much of her comedy career battling depression in silence. Now her work blends mental health advocacy and laughs.

talk: How art, technology and design inform creative leaders
speaker: John Maeda
speaker_bio: John Maeda, the former president of the Rhode Island School of Design, is dedicated to linking design and technology. Through the software tools, web pages and books he creates, he spreads his philosophy of elegant simplicity.

talk: 3 ways to (usefully) lose control of your brand
speaker: Tim Leberecht
speaker_bio: A humanist in Silicon Valley, Tim Leberecht argues that in a time of artificial intelligence, big data and the quantification of everything, we are losing sight of the importance of the emotional and social aspects of our work.

talk: Weaving narratives in museum galleries
speaker: Thomas P. Campbell
speaker_bio: During his term as director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and now at San Francisco's Fine Arts Museums, Thomas P. Campbell aims to make museum offerings both narrative-driven and accessible.

talk: The self-organizing computer course
speaker: Shimon Schocken
speaker_bio: Shimon Schocken is a computer science professor and dedicated educator.

talk: Terrorism is a failed brand
speaker: Jason McCue
speaker_bio: Jason McCue litigates against terrorists, dictators and others who seem above the law, using the legal and judicial system in innovative ways.

talk: Between music and medicine
speaker: Robert Gupta
speaker_bio: Violinist Robert Gupta joined the LA Philharmonic at the age of 19 -- and maintains a passionate parallel interest in neurobiology and mental health issues. He's a TED Senior Fellow.

talk: Your body language may shape who you are
speaker: Amy Cuddy
speaker_bio: Amy Cuddy’s research on body language reveals that we can change other people’s perceptions — and perhaps even our own body chemistry — simply by changing body positions.

talk: Let's prepare for our new climate
speaker: Vicki Arroyo
speaker_bio: Vicki Arroyo uses environmental law and her background in biology and ecology to help prepare for global climate change.

talk: Making sense of maps
speaker: Aris Venetikidis
speaker_bio: Aris Venetikidis imagines how maps work with our minds.

talk: A thousand times no
speaker: Bahia Shehab
speaker_bio: TED Fellow Bahia Shehab sends an important message through her street art in Cairo: “You can crush the flowers, but you can’t delay spring."

talk: What doctors don't know about the drugs they prescribe
speaker: Ben Goldacre
speaker_bio: Ben Goldacre unpicks dodgy scientific claims made by scaremongering journalists, dubious government reports, pharmaceutical corporations, PR companies and quacks.

talk: An animated tour of the invisible
speaker: John Lloyd
speaker_bio: John Lloyd helps make some of the cleverest television in the UK.

talk: How the Internet will (one day) transform government
speaker: Clay Shirky
speaker_bio: Clay Shirky argues that the history of the modern world could be rendered as the history of ways of arguing, where changes in media change what sort of arguments are possible -- with deep social and political implications.

talk: The art of the metaphor
speaker: Jane Hirshfield

talk: What we're learning from 5,000 brains
speaker: Read Montague
speaker_bio: What does "normal behavior" look like? To find out, Read Montague is imaging thousands of brains at work.

talk: The currency of the new economy is trust
speaker: Rachel Botsman
speaker_bio: Rachel Botsman is a recognized expert on how collaboration and trust enabled by digital technologies will change the way we live, work, bank and consume.

talk: A story about knots and surgeons
speaker: Ed Gavagan
speaker_bio: Ed Gavagan was walking down the street in downtown Manhattan when he was the victim of a gang assignment to kill a random stranger. He lives to tell the amazing story.

talk: Demand a fair trade cell phone
speaker: Bandi Mbubi
speaker_bio: Bandi Mbubi would like to make sure that you are using a fair trade cell phone.

talk: Discover the physical side of the internet
speaker: Andrew Blum
speaker_bio: For his new book, "Tubes," Andrew Blum visited the places where the internet exists in physical form: the cables and switches and servers that virtually connect us.

talk: Why architects need to use their ears
speaker: Julian Treasure
speaker_bio: Julian Treasure studies sound and advises businesses on how best to use it.

talk: The mysterious workings of the adolescent brain
speaker: Sarah-Jayne Blakemore
speaker_bio: Sarah-Jayne Blakemore is Professor of Psychology at the University of Cambridge, UK, and leader of the Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience Group.

talk: The global food waste scandal
speaker: Tristram Stuart
speaker_bio: Tristram Stuart sounds the warning bell on global food waste, calling for us to change the systems whereby large quantities of produce and other foods end up in trash heaps.

talk: Demand a more open-source government
speaker: Beth Noveck
speaker_bio: A lawyer by training and a techie by inclination, Beth Noveck works to build data transparency into government.

talk: A choreographer's creative process in real time
speaker: Wayne McGregor
speaker_bio: Wayne McGregor and his dancers explore the uncharted territory where mind and movement intersect.

talk: The promise of research with stem cells
speaker: Susan Solomon
speaker_bio: Susan Solomon enables support for human stem cell research, aiming to cure major diseases and empower more personalized medicine.

talk: The voices of China's workers
speaker: Leslie T. Chang
speaker_bio: In her reporting and writing, Leslie T. Chang explores the lives of workers in China, focusing on the experience of women.

talk: How big is a mole? (Not the animal, the other one.)
speaker: Daniel Dulek

talk: Mental health for all by involving all
speaker: Vikram Patel
speaker_bio: Vikram Patel helps bring better mental health care to low-resource communities -- by teaching ordinary people to deliver basic psychiatric services.

talk: Why eyewitnesses get it wrong
speaker: Scott Fraser
speaker_bio: Scott Fraser is a forensic psychologist who thinks deeply about the fallibility of human memory and encourages a more scientific approach to trial evidence.

talk: Brilliant designs to fit more people in every city
speaker: Kent Larson
speaker_bio: Kent Larson designs new technologies that solve the biggest questions facing our cities.

talk: Energy from floating algae pods
speaker: Jonathan Trent
speaker_bio: Not only does Jonathan Trent grow algae for biofuel, he wants to do so by cleansing wastewater and trapping carbon dioxide in the process. And it’s all solar-powered.

talk: Sculpted space, within and without
speaker: Antony Gormley
speaker_bio: Antony Gormley's work plays with the human form in space.

talk: The rise of human-computer cooperation
speaker: Shyam Sankar
speaker_bio: An advocate of human-computer symbiosis, Shyam Sankar looks for clues in big and disparate data sets.

talk: The power of the informal economy
speaker: Robert Neuwirth
speaker_bio: Robert Neuwirth’s writings on the street-level reality of the developing world have opened a new dialogue on development and economics.

talk: The art of creating awe
speaker: Rob Legato
speaker_bio: Rob Legato creates surprising and creative visual illusions for movies.

talk: Design for people, not awards
speaker: Timothy Prestero
speaker_bio: Timothy Prestero loves a flashy "concept car." But in his own work, he aims to design products for social impact, keeping users in mind.

talk: Strange answers to the psychopath test
speaker: Jon Ronson
speaker_bio: Jon Ronson is a writer and documentary filmmaker who dips into every flavor of madness, extremism and obsession.

talk: How to step up in the face of disaster
speaker: Caitria O'Neill
speaker_bio: When a freak tornado hit her Massachusetts hometown, Caitria O’Neill wasn't an expert in disaster relief recovery. But she learned quickly and is now passing her knowledge on through the website Recovers.org.

talk: Can democracy exist without trust?
speaker: Ivan Krastev
speaker_bio: From his home base in Bulgaria, Ivan Krastev thinks about democracy -- and how to reframe it.

talk: What's a snollygoster? A short lesson in political speak
speaker: Mark Forsyth
speaker_bio: Mark Forsyth strolls through the English language, telling stories, making connections and banishing hobgoblins.

talk: Photos that bear witness to modern slavery
speaker: Lisa Kristine
speaker_bio: Lisa Kristine uses photography to expose deeply human stories.

talk: Embrace the remix
speaker: Kirby Ferguson
speaker_bio: Kirby Ferguson explores creativity in a world where "everything is a remix."

talk: How we can eat our landscapes
speaker: Pam Warhurst
speaker_bio: Pam Warhurst cofounded Incredible Edible, an initiative in Todmorden, England dedicated to growing food locally by planting on unused land throughout the community.

talk: A test for Parkinson's with a phone call
speaker: Max Little
speaker_bio: Max Little is a mathematician whose research includes a breakthrough technique to monitor – and potentially screen for – Parkinson's disease through simple voice recordings.

talk: Dare to disagree
speaker: Margaret Heffernan
speaker_bio: The former CEO of five businesses, Margaret Heffernan explores the all-too-human thought patterns that lead organizations and managers astray.

talk: Fighting with nonviolence
speaker: Scilla Elworthy
speaker_bio: Scilla Elworthy founded Oxford Research Group in 1982, to promote effective dialogue between nuclear weapons policy-makers and their opponents.

talk: Is life really that complex?
speaker: Hannah Fry
speaker_bio: Hannah Fry researches the trends in our civilization and ways we can forecast its future.

talk: The mad scientist of music
speaker: Mark Applebaum
speaker_bio: Mark Applebaum has built an instrument out of doorstops and combs, as well as composed a piece of music to be performed by a florist.

talk: (Re)touching lives through photos
speaker: Becci Manson
speaker_bio: After the March 2011 earthquake and tsunami in Japan, Becci Manson and her volunteer colleagues cleaned and restored hundreds of damaged photos.

talk: What we're learning from online education
speaker: Daphne Koller
speaker_bio: With Coursera, Daphne Koller and co-founder Andrew Ng are bringing courses from top colleges online, free, for anyone who wants to take them.

talk: Behind the Great Firewall of China
speaker: Michael Anti
speaker_bio: Michael Anti (Zhao Jing), a key figure in China's new journalism, explores the growing power of the Chinese internet.

talk: When a reporter becomes the story
speaker: Giles Duley
speaker_bio: Giles Duley began his career as a fashion photographer. When it was time for a change he found himself on a journey of war and hardship.

talk: Every city needs healthy honey bees
speaker: Noah Wilson-Rich
speaker_bio: Noah Wilson-Rich doesn't just want to know why bees are dying off, but what's saving them.

talk: Building unimaginable shapes
speaker: Michael Hansmeyer
speaker_bio: Michael Hansmeyer is an architect and programmer who explores the use of algorithms and computation to generate architectural form.

talk: Imaging at a trillion frames per second
speaker: Ramesh Raskar
speaker_bio: Photography is about creating images by recording light. At the MIT media lab, professor Ramesh Raskar and his team members have invented a camera that can photograph light itself as it moves at, well, the speed of light.

talk: Finding the story inside the painting
speaker: Tracy Chevalier
speaker_bio: Novelist Tracy Chevalier is the author of "Girl With a Pearl Earring."

talk: Your phone company is watching
speaker: Malte Spitz
speaker_bio: Malte Spitz asked his cell phone carrier what it knew about him -- and mapped what he found out.

talk: A Navy Admiral's thoughts on global security
speaker: James Stavridis
speaker_bio: What will 21st-century security look like? Navy Admiral James Stavridis suggests that dialogue and openness will be the game-changers.

talk: Technology crafts for the digitally underserved
speaker: Vinay Venkatraman
speaker_bio: Vinay Venkatraman aims to design technological devices for the "bottom of the pyramid" rather than simply for the affluent.

talk: The greatest machine that never was
speaker: John Graham-Cumming
speaker_bio: Computer programmer John Graham-Cumming keeps geek history alive by raising awareness for its heroes and their inventions.

talk: I listen to color
speaker: Neil Harbisson
speaker_bio: Neil Harbisson's "eyeborg" allows him to hear colors, even those beyond the range of sight.

talk: Image recognition that triggers augmented reality
speaker: Matt Mills
speaker_bio: Matt Mills comes from Aurasma, a startup that makes augmented-reality technology for mobile phones.

talk: Sometimes it's good to give up the driver's seat
speaker: Baba Shiv
speaker_bio: Baba Shiv studies how “liking” and “wanting” shape the choices we make, and what that means in the world of marketing.

talk: How big is infinity?
speaker: Dennis Wildfogel

talk: Let's crowdsource the world's goals
speaker: Jamie Drummond
speaker_bio: Jamie Drummond co-founded the advocacy organization ONE, whose central themes are ending extreme poverty and fighting the AIDS pandemic.

talk: Experiments that point to a new understanding of cancer
speaker: Mina Bissell
speaker_bio: Mina Bissell studies how cancer interacts with our bodies, searching for clues to how cancer's microenvironment influences its growth.

talk: Capturing memories in video art
speaker: Gabriel Barcia-Colombo
speaker_bio: Gabe Barcia-Colombo creates madcap art inspired both by Renaissance era curiosity cabinets and the modern-day digital chronicling of everyday life. Think: miniature people projected in objects and a DNA Vending Machine.

talk: How to fool a GPS
speaker: Todd Humphreys
speaker_bio: Todd Humphreys studies GPS, its future, and how we can address some of its biggest security problems.

talk: The survival of the sea turtle
speaker: Scott Gass

talk: New ways to see music (with color! and fire!)
speaker: Jared Ficklin
speaker_bio: In his day job, Jared Ficklin makes user interfaces at frog design. As a hobby, he explores what music looks like ... in light, in shapes, in fire.

talk: A vision of crimes in the future
speaker: Marc Goodman
speaker_bio: Marc Goodman works to prevent future crimes and acts of terrorism, even those security threats not yet invented.

talk: The future race car -- 150mph, and no driver
speaker: Chris Gerdes
speaker_bio: An autonomous car may seem like a thing of the distant future, but mechanical engineer Chris Gerdes is racing to make it a reality today.

talk: Meet your microbes
speaker: Jonathan Eisen
speaker_bio: Jonathan Eisen studies the ecology and evolution of microbial communities -- and their co-evolution with their hosts.

talk: The game that can give you 10 extra years of life
speaker: Jane McGonigal
speaker_bio: Reality is broken, says Jane McGonigal, and we need to make it work more like a game. Her work shows us how.

talk: A young guitarist meets his hero
speaker: Preston Reed
speaker_bio: Preston Reed’s hands have an otherworldly coordination. The fingers, nails, thumbs, and palms of both left and right dance, pluck, strum, and slap his guitar, which bursts with a full sound.

talk: A novel idea for cleaning up oil spills
speaker: Cesar Harada
speaker_bio: TED Senior Fellow Cesar Harada aims to harness the forces of nature as he invents innovative remedies for man-made problems like oil spills and radioactive leaks.

talk: What's your 200-year plan?
speaker: Raghava KK
speaker_bio: Raghava KK's paintings and drawings use cartoonish shapes and colors to examine the body, society, our world.

talk: How I'm preparing to get Alzheimer's
speaker: Alanna Shaikh
speaker_bio: Alanna Shaikh is a global health consultant who specializes in strengthening health systems.

talk: Calculating the odds of intelligent alien life
speaker: Jill Tarter
speaker_bio: SETI's Jill Tarter has devoted her career to hunting for signs of sentient beings elsewhere. Winner of the 2009 TED Prize, almost all aspects of her field have been affected by her work.

talk: The levitating superconductor
speaker: Boaz Almog
speaker_bio: Boaz Almog uses quantum physics to levitate and trap objects in midair. Call it "quantum levitation."

talk: A tale of mental illness -- from the inside
speaker: Elyn Saks
speaker_bio: Elyn Saks asks bold questions about how society treats people with mental illness.

talk: Four principles for the open world
speaker: Don Tapscott
speaker_bio: Don Tapscott, Executive Chairman of the Blockchain Research Institute, is one of the world’s leading authorities on the impact of technology in business and society. He has authored 16 books, including "Wikinomics: How Mass Collaboration Changes Everything," which has been translated into over 25 languages

talk: How Arduino is open-sourcing imagination
speaker: Massimo Banzi
speaker_bio: Massimo Banzi co-founded Arduino, which makes affordable open-source microcontrollers for interactive projects, from art installations to an automatic plant waterer.

talk: Reinventing the encyclopedia game
speaker: Rives
speaker_bio: Performance artist and storyteller Rives has been called "the first 2.0 poet," using images, video and technology to bring his words to life.

talk: Advice to a young scientist
speaker: E.O. Wilson
speaker_bio: Biologist E.O. Wilson explores the world of ants and other tiny creatures, and writes movingly about the way all creatures great and small are interdependent.

talk: India's invisible innovation
speaker: Nirmalya Kumar
speaker_bio: Nirmalya Kumar is a professor of Marketing at the London Business School and a passionate voice for new entrepreneurs in India.

talk: Tour the solar system from home
speaker: Jon Nguyen
speaker_bio: Jon Nguyen is an award winning aeronautics and graphics engineer at NASA.

talk: How do pain relievers work?
speaker: George Zaidan

talk: How to air-condition outdoor spaces
speaker: Wolfgang Kessling
speaker_bio: Wolfgang Kessling and his team at Transsolar designed the solar cooling and comfort concepts that helped Qatar win the bid for the 2022 football World Cup.

talk: The 100,000-student classroom
speaker: Peter Norvig
speaker_bio: Peter Norvig is a leading American computer scientist, expert on artificial intelligence and the Director of Research at Google Inc.

talk: The electric rise and fall of Nikola Tesla
speaker: Marco Tempest
speaker_bio: Using technology and an array of special effects, Marco Tempest develops immersive environments that allow viewers to viscerally experience the magic of technology.

talk: Are we over-medicalized?
speaker: Ivan Oransky
speaker_bio: Ivan Oransky is the executive editor of Reuters Health, and has done pioneering work in covering scientific retractions.

talk: Lessons from death row inmates
speaker: David R. Dow
speaker_bio: David R. Dow has defended over 100 death row inmates in 20 years.

talk: Women should represent women in media
speaker: Megan Kamerick
speaker_bio: Journalist Megan Kamerick fights for well-balanced storytelling in media.

talk: The myth of the gay agenda
speaker: LZ Granderson
speaker_bio: CNN and ESPN columnist LZ Granderson is a celebrated voice on sports, race and gay rights.

talk: Archaeology from space
speaker: Sarah Parcak
speaker_bio: Like a modern-day Indiana Jones, Sarah Parcak uses satellite images to locate lost ancient sites. The winner of the 2016 TED Prize, her wish is to protect the world’s shared cultural heritage.

talk: The shared wonder of film
speaker: Baroness Beeban Kidron
speaker_bio: Beeban Kidron directed Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason and Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit. She also cofounded FILMCLUB, a charity for students devoted to the art of storytelling through film.

talk: What if our health care system kept us healthy?
speaker: Rebecca Onie
speaker_bio: Rebecca Onie is a nationally recognized leader in the intersection of social determinants, population health and health care delivery

talk: We are all designers
speaker: John Hockenberry
speaker_bio: Journalist and commentator John Hockenberry has reported from all over the world in virtually every medium. He's the author of "Moving Violations: War Zones, Wheelchairs and Declarations of Independence."

talk: A new way to diagnose autism
speaker: Ami Klin
speaker_bio: Ami Klin is an award winning autism spectrum disorder researcher finding new avenues for early diagnosis.

talk: How to speed up chemical reactions (and get a date)
speaker: Aaron Sams

talk: Design, explained.
speaker: John Hodgman
speaker_bio: John Hodgman is a writer, humorist, geek celebrity, former professional literary agent and expert on all world knowledge. He was the bumbling PC in Apple's long-running "I'm a Mac; I'm a PC" ad campaign.

talk: Mining minerals from seawater
speaker: Damian Palin
speaker_bio: Damian Palin is developing a way to use bacteria to biologically "mine" minerals from water -- specifically, out of the brine left over from the desalinization process.

talk: Why is 'x' the unknown?
speaker: Terry Moore
speaker_bio: Terry Moore is the director of the Radius Foundation, a forum for exploring and gaining insight from different worldviews.

talk: What we didn't know about penis anatomy
speaker: Diane Kelly
speaker_bio: Diane Kelly studies vertebrate anatomy, in particular the connection between the design and the function of reproductive organs.

talk: Will our kids be a different species?
speaker: Juan Enriquez
speaker_bio: Juan Enriquez thinks and writes about the profound changes that genomics and brain research will bring about in business, technology, politics and society.

talk: A new way to stop identity theft
speaker: David Birch
speaker_bio: David Birch is a digital money and ID consultant paving the way for a 21st-century identity.

talk: ET is (probably) out there -- get ready
speaker: Seth Shostak
speaker_bio: Seth Shostak is an astronomer, alien hunter and bulwark of good, exciting science.

talk: Dancing with light
speaker: Quixotic Fusion
speaker_bio: Anthony Magliano and Mica Thomas are the founder and artistic directors of Quixotic, a mixed-media theater/performance/aerialist company.

talk: What your designs say about you
speaker: Sebastian Deterding
speaker_bio: Sebastian Deterding is an interface designer who thinks deeply about persuasive and gameful design.

talk: The attitudes that sparked Arab Spring
speaker: Dalia Mogahed
speaker_bio: Researcher and pollster Dalia Mogahed is an author, advisor and consultant who studies Muslim communities.

talk: Revealing the lost codex of Archimedes
speaker: William Noel
speaker_bio: William Noel is a curator who believes museums should make their collections free and available on the Internet.

talk: 4 lessons from robots about being human
speaker: Ken Goldberg
speaker_bio: Ken Goldberg works reflect the intersection of robotics, social media, and art.

talk: A reality check on renewables
speaker: David MacKay
speaker_bio: As an information theorist and computer scientist, David MacKay uses hard math to assess our renewable energy options.

talk: Beats that defy boxes
speaker: Reggie Watts
speaker_bio: Reggie Watts creates unpredictably brilliant performances on the spot using his voice, looping pedals and his giant brain.

talk: HIV -- how to fight an epidemic of bad laws
speaker: Shereen El Feki
speaker_bio: Shereen El Feki works and writes on sexuality and social change in the Arab world.

talk: The journey across the high wire
speaker: Philippe Petit
speaker_bio: High-wire artist Philippe Petit surprised the world when he walked illegally between the Twin Towers in 1974.

talk: Religions and babies
speaker: Hans Rosling
speaker_bio: In Hans Rosling’s hands, data sings. Global trends in health and economics come to vivid life. And the big picture of global development -- with some surprisingly good news -- snaps into sharp focus.

talk: One is one... or is it?
speaker: Christopher Danielson

talk: What's left to explore?
speaker: Nathan Wolfe
speaker_bio: Armed with blood samples, high-tech tools and a small army of fieldworkers, Nathan Wolfe hopes to re-invent pandemic control -- and reveal hidden secrets of the planet's dominant lifeform: the virus.

talk: The sea we've hardly seen
speaker: Melissa Garren
speaker_bio: Melissa Garren is a molecular and marine biologist with a passion for unlocking the mysteries of our ocean's ecosystems and finding new avenues for conservation.

talk: Cheap, effective shelter for disaster relief
speaker: Michael McDaniel
speaker_bio: Michael McDaniel is a graphic designer using his skills to help people in meaningful ways.

talk: One year of turning the world inside out
speaker: JR
speaker_bio: With a camera, a dedicated wheatpasting crew and the help of whole villages and favelas, 2011 TED Prize winner JR shows the world its true face.

talk: How to look inside the brain
speaker: Carl Schoonover
speaker_bio: Carl Schoonover is a neuroscientist and one of the founders of NeuWrite, a collaboration between writers and neuroscientist.

talk: How to build your creative confidence
speaker: David Kelley
speaker_bio: David Kelley’s company IDEO helped create many icons of the digital generation -- but what matters even more to him is unlocking the creative potential of people and organizations to innovate routinely.

talk: The mathematics of history
speaker: Jean-Baptiste Michel
speaker_bio: Jean-Baptiste Michel looks at how we can use large volumes of data to better understand our world.

talk: The optimism bias
speaker: Tali Sharot
speaker_bio: Tali Sharot studies why our brains are biased toward optimism.

talk: 3 new ways to kill mosquitoes
speaker: Bart Knols
speaker_bio: Bart Knols is a doctor committed to killing mosquitoes and ending malaria.

talk: Beethoven the businessman
speaker: José Bowen
speaker_bio: José Bowen is an accomplished musician and teacher who explores how technology has shaped the history of music.

talk: 404, the story of a page not found
speaker: Renny Gleeson
speaker_bio: Renny Gleeson helps navigate brands through fresh concepts, such as viral marketing and social media, to find the pulse of the modern consumer.

talk: Feats of memory anyone can do
speaker: Joshua Foer
speaker_bio: Joshua Foer is a science writer who 'accidentally' won the U.S. Memory Championship.

talk: Unseen footage, untamed nature
speaker: Karen Bass
speaker_bio: Karen Bass has traveled the world to explore and capture footage from every environment across the Earth.

talk: Information is food
speaker: JP Rangaswami
speaker_bio: JP Rangaswami thinks deeply (and hilariously) about disruptive data.

talk: From stigma to supermodel
speaker: Rick Guidotti
speaker_bio: Photographer Rick Guidotti sees a rich beauty in our genetic diversity and works to expose that vision to everyone.

talk: A teen just trying to figure it out
speaker: Tavi Gevinson
speaker_bio: Tavi Gevinson is a fashion blogger and a feminist who encourages everyone to embrace their complexity and look cool doing it.

talk: Perspective is everything
speaker: Rory Sutherland
speaker_bio: Rory Sutherland stands at the center of an advertising revolution in brand identities, designing cutting-edge, interactive campaigns that blur the line between ad and entertainment.

talk: Tracking our online trackers
speaker: Gary Kovacs
speaker_bio: Gary Kovacs is a technologist and the former CEO of the Mozilla Corporation, where he directed the development of Firefox.

talk: Sculpting waves in wood and time
speaker: Reuben Margolin
speaker_bio: Reuben Margolin's moving sculptures combine the logic of math with the sensuousness of nature.

talk: A 40-year plan for energy
speaker: Amory Lovins
speaker_bio: In his new book, "Reinventing Fire," Amory Lovins shares ingenious ideas for the next era of energy.

talk: Insults by Shakespeare
speaker: April Gudenrath
speaker_bio: Ms. April Gudenrath is from the US, currently residing in Korea in order to teach English literature to high school students at TCIS. Her teaching experience stretches back 15 years in US public and private schools. She is titled a TED-ED educator have published sveral rticles and books about technological pedgogy in the classroom. In addition, she is an international consultant on the blended classroom K-20. Outside of her work, she is a mother of two college students. In her previous school, as she underwent the tragedy of 11 student suicides, she was compelled to help her students by asking "Why?" and wants to address the importance of vulnerability in our lives.

talk: A new museum wing ... in a giant bubble
speaker: Elizabeth Diller
speaker_bio: Elizabeth Diller and her maverick firm DS+R bring a groundbreaking approach to projects in architecture, urban design and art by playing with new materials and tampering with space and spectacle in ways that make you look twice.

talk: Gaming for understanding
speaker: Brenda Romero
speaker_bio: Brenda Romero designs games that turn some of history's most tragic lessons into interactive, emotional experiences.

talk: How to use a paper towel
speaker: Joe Smith
speaker_bio: Joe Smith is an active figure in the Oregon community and a powerful advocate for proper paper towel use.

talk: Texting that saves lives
speaker: Nancy Lublin
speaker_bio: Nancy Lublin, cofounder and former CEO of Crisis Text Line, uses technology and data to save lives.

talk: The 4 commandments of cities
speaker: Eduardo Paes
speaker_bio: Mayor Eduardo Paes is on a mission to ensure that Rio's renaissance creates a positive legacy for all its citizens.

talk: Just how small is an atom?
speaker: Jon Bergmann
speaker_bio: Jon Bergmann co-wrote the book on the "flipped classroom" -- using video to help students master new ideas outside the traditional class setting.

talk: Sex determination
speaker: Aaron Reedy
speaker_bio: Aaron Reedy teaches at Thomas Kelly High School in Chicago, where he uses innovative projects to connect his classroom to the wider world of science.

talk: How folding paper can get you to the moon
speaker: Adrián Paenza

talk: How to buy happiness
speaker: Michael Norton
speaker_bio: Through clever studies, Michael Norton studies how we feel about what we buy and spend.

talk: Is our universe the only universe?
speaker: Brian Greene
speaker_bio: Brian Greene is perhaps the best-known proponent of superstring theory, the idea that minuscule strands of energy vibrating in a higher dimensional space-time create every particle and force in the universe.

talk: Tracking ancient diseases using ... plaque
speaker: Christina Warinner
speaker_bio: Christina Warinner is a researcher at the University of Zurich, where she studies how humans have co-evolved with environments, diets and disease.

talk: Older people are happier

speaker_bio: Laura Carstensen is the director of the Stanford Center on Longevity, and has extensively studied the effects on wellbeing of extended lifetimes.

talk: The stories behind the bloodlines
speaker: Taryn Simon
speaker_bio: With a large-format camera and a knack for talking her way into forbidden zones, Taryn Simon photographs portions of the American infrastructure inaccessible to its inhabitants.

talk: How I beat a patent troll
speaker: Drew Curtis
speaker_bio: Drew Curtis is the founder and administrator of Fark.com.

talk: How do we heal medicine?
speaker: Atul Gawande
speaker_bio: Surgeon and public health professor by day, writer by night, Atul Gawande explores how doctors can dramatically improve their practice using approaches as simple as a checklist – or coaching.

talk: Building US-China relations ... by banjo
speaker: Abigail Washburn
speaker_bio: Abigail Washburn pairs venerable folk elements with far-flung sounds, creating results that feel both strangely familiar and unlike anything anybody's ever heard before.

talk: How I repaired my own heart
speaker: Tal Golesworthy
speaker_bio: Tal Golesworthy is an engineer and entrepreneur, working in research and development of combustion and air pollution control -- until he decided to innovate in his own health.

talk: Let's put birth control back on the agenda
speaker: Melinda Gates
speaker_bio: Melinda French Gates is cochair of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, where she puts into practice the idea that every life has equal value.

talk: Moral behavior in animals
speaker: Frans de Waal
speaker_bio: Frans de Waal studies primate social behavior -- how they fight and reconcile, share and cooperate.

talk: Half a million secrets
speaker: Frank Warren
speaker_bio: Frank Warren is the creator of the PostSecret Project, a blog full of secrets anonymously shared via postcard.

talk: The other inconvenient truth
speaker: Jonathan Foley
speaker_bio: Jonathan Foley studies complex environmental systems and their affects on society. His computer models have shown the deep impact agriculture is having on our planet.

talk: "Put the financial aid in the bag"
speaker: Carvens Lissaint
speaker_bio: Carvens Lissaint is a Haitian American poet, actor, singer and playwright, currently starring in the Tony-winning musical HAMILTON as George Washington on Broadway.

talk: How can technology transform the human body?
speaker: Lucy McRae
speaker_bio: Trained as a classical ballerina and architect, Lucy McRae is fascinated by the human body, and how it can be shaped by technology.

talk: On the virtual dissection table
speaker: Jack Choi
speaker_bio: Jack is the CEO of Anatomage, a company specializing on 3D medical technology.

talk: Designing books is no laughing matter. OK, it is.
speaker: Chip Kidd
speaker_bio: Chip Kidd's book jacket designs spawned a revolution in the art of American book packaging.

talk: Connected, but alone?
speaker: Sherry Turkle
speaker_bio: Sherry Turkle studies how technology is shaping our modern relationships: with others, with ourselves, with it.

talk: The secret life of plankton
speaker: Tierney Thys
speaker_bio: Tierney Thys is a marine biologist and science educator. She studies the behavior of the Mola mola, or giant ocean sunfish -- and works with other scientists to make films that share the wonders they see.

talk: I am a pirate
speaker: Rick Falkvinge
speaker_bio: Rick Falkvinge, didn’t plan on becoming a politician, but his dedication to civil liberties and internet sovereignty led to him founding the Swedish Pirate Party in 2006.

talk: Inventing is the easy part. Marketing takes work
speaker: Daniel Schnitzer
speaker_occ: Founder and Executive Director, Earthspark International
speaker_bio: Daniel Schnitzer is the founder of EarthSpark International, a company dedicated to helping create clean energy supply chains in Haiti.

talk: A magical tale (with augmented reality)
speaker: Marco Tempest
speaker_bio: Using technology and an array of special effects, Marco Tempest develops immersive environments that allow viewers to viscerally experience the magic of technology.

talk: Building blocks that blink, beep and teach
speaker: Ayah Bdeir
speaker_bio: Ayah Bdeir is an engineer and artist, and is the founder of littleBits and karaj, an experimental art, architecture and technology lab in Beirut.

talk: Unlock the intelligence, passion, greatness of girls
speaker: Leymah Gbowee
speaker_bio: Leymah Gbowee is a peace activist in Liberia. She led a women's movement that was pivotal in ending the Second Liberian Civil War in 2003, and now speaks on behalf of women and girls around the world.

talk: From mach-20 glider to hummingbird drone
speaker: Regina Dugan
speaker_bio: As director of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), Regina Dugan oversaw the US armed forces' innovation engine. Now she deploys the same research tactics at Google.

talk: The missing link to renewable energy
speaker: Donald Sadoway
speaker_bio: Donald Sadoway is working on a battery miracle -- an inexpensive, incredibly efficient, three-layered battery using “liquid metal."

talk: How many universes are there?
speaker: Chris Anderson
speaker_bio: After a long career in journalism and publishing, Chris Anderson became the curator of the TED Conference in 2002 and has developed it as a platform for identifying and disseminating ideas worth spreading.

talk: Why can't we see evidence of alien life?
speaker: Chris Anderson
speaker_bio: After a long career in journalism and publishing, Chris Anderson became the curator of the TED Conference in 2002 and has developed it as a platform for identifying and disseminating ideas worth spreading.

talk: Let's talk about dying
speaker: Peter Saul
speaker_bio: Over the past 35 years Peter Saul has been intimately involved in the dying process for over 4,000 patients. He is passionate about improving the ways we die.

talk: Make data more human
speaker: Jer Thorp
speaker_bio: Jer Thorp’s work focuses on adding meaning and narrative to huge amounts of data as a way to help people take control of the information that surrounds them.

talk: Everyday moments, caught in time
speaker: Billy Collins
speaker_bio: A two-term U.S. Poet Laureate, Billy Collins captures readers with his understated wit, profound insight -- and a sense of being "hospitable."

talk: Yup, I built a nuclear fusion reactor

speaker_bio: At 14, Taylor Wilson became the youngest person to achieve fusion -- with a reactor born in his garage. Now he wants to save our seaports from nuclear terror.

talk: Let's transform energy -- with natural gas
speaker: T. Boone Pickens
speaker_bio: A legendary oil and gas entrepreneur, T. Boone Pickens is now on a mission to enhance U.S. energy policies to lessen the nation’s dependence on OPEC oil.

talk: Victims of the city
speaker: Mark Raymond
speaker_bio: Mark Raymond’s work as an architect in Trinidad and Tobago is founded on the belief that thoughtfully designed cities can foster sustainability and inclusiveness throughout a society.

talk: Beautiful artificial limbs
speaker: Scott Summit
speaker_bio: Scott Summit uses his 20 years of experience as an industrial designer to make artificial limbs that help people take personal control of these intimate objects.

talk: Listening to shame
speaker: Brené Brown
speaker_bio: Dr. Brené Brown studies courage, vulnerability, shame and empathy.

talk: The $8 billion iPod
speaker: Rob Reid
speaker_bio: Author and entrepreneur Rob Reid writes speculative fiction for Random House.

talk: Religion, evolution, and the ecstasy of self-transcendence
speaker: Jonathan Haidt
speaker_bio: Jonathan Haidt studies how -- and why -- we evolved to be moral and political creatures.

talk: How simple ideas lead to scientific discoveries
speaker: Adam Savage
speaker_bio: Adam Savage is an internationally renowned television producer, host and public speaker.

talk: Deep ocean mysteries and wonders
speaker: David Gallo
speaker_bio: A pioneer in ocean exploration, David Gallo is an enthusiastic ambassador between the sea and those of us on dry land.

talk: Questions no one knows the answers to
speaker: Chris Anderson
speaker_bio: After a long career in journalism and publishing, Chris Anderson became the curator of the TED Conference in 2002 and has developed it as a platform for identifying and disseminating ideas worth spreading.

talk: The cockroach beatbox
speaker: Greg Gage
speaker_bio: TED Fellow Greg Gage helps kids investigate the neuroscience in their own backyards.

talk: Why you will fail to have a great career
speaker: Larry Smith
speaker_occ: Professor of Economics, University of Waterloo
speaker_bio: A professor of economics at the University of Waterloo in Canada, Larry Smith coaches his students to find the careers that they will truly love.

talk: Design to challenge reality
speaker: Kelli Anderson
speaker_bio: From wedding invitations to Utopian newspapers, Kelli Anderson re-designs commonplace objects to go beyond their ordinary functions and create surprising experiences.

talk: A TED speaker's worst nightmare
speaker: Colin Robertson
speaker_bio: Colin Robertson is apparently "attempting to make the world's first crowdsourced solar energy solution" Or is he?

talk: Coding a better government
speaker: Jennifer Pahlka
speaker_bio: Jennifer Pahlka is the founder of Code for America, which matches software geniuses with US cities to reboot local services.

talk: Why I must speak out about climate change
speaker: James Hansen
speaker_bio: James Hansen has made key insights into our global climate -- and inspired a generation of activists and scientists.

talk: The clues to a great story
speaker: Andrew Stanton
speaker_bio: Andrew Stanton has made you laugh and cry. The writer behind the three "Toy Story" movies and the writer/director of "WALL-E," he releases his new film, "John Carter," in March.

talk: The power of introverts
speaker: Susan Cain
speaker_bio: Our world prizes extroverts, but Susan Cain makes a case for the contemplative. She's leading a social revolution that's showing people that looking inward is a virtue, not a problem.

talk: Robots that fly ... and cooperate
speaker: Vijay Kumar
speaker_bio: As the dean of the University of Pennsylvania's School of Engineering and Applied Science, Vijay Kumar studies the control and coordination of multi-robot formations.

talk: The Earth is full
speaker: Paul Gilding
speaker_bio: Paul Gilding is an independent writer, activist and adviser on a sustainable economy. Click through to watch the onstage debate that followed this talk.

talk: Abundance is our future
speaker: Peter Diamandis
speaker_bio: Peter Diamandis runs the X Prize Foundation, which offers large cash incentive prizes to inventors who can solve grand challenges like space flight, low-cost mobile medical diagnostics and oil spill cleanup. He is the chair of Singularity University, which teaches executives and grad students about exponentially growing technologies.

talk: The ocean's shifting baseline
speaker: Daniel Pauly
speaker_bio: Daniel Pauly is the principal investigator at the Sea Around Us Project, which studies the impact of the world's fisheries on marine ecosystems. The software he's helped develop is used around the world to model and track the ocean.

talk: A census of the ocean
speaker: Paul Snelgrove
speaker_bio: Paul Snelgrove led the group that pulled together the findings of the Census of Marine Life -- synthesizing 10 years and 540 expeditions into a book of wonders.

talk: Why videos go viral
speaker: Kevin Allocca
speaker_bio: Kevin Allocca is YouTube's expert on the intersection of web video and global culture

talk: The sibling bond
speaker: Jeffrey Kluger
speaker_bio: A senior editor of science and technology reporting at TIME magazine, Jeffrey Kluger has written books on a wide range of science subjects, including the Polio vaccine, Apollo 13 and the effect of sibling relationships.

talk: All your devices can be hacked
speaker: Avi Rubin
speaker_bio: Avi Rubin is a professor of computer science and director of the Health and Medical Security Lab at Johns Hopkins University. His research is focused on the security of electronic records -- including medical and voting records.

talk: My immigration story
speaker: Tan Le
speaker_bio: Tan Le is the founder & CEO of Emotiv, a bioinformatics company that's working on identifying biomarkers for mental and other neurological conditions using electroencephalography (EEG).

talk: Saving for tomorrow, tomorrow
speaker: Shlomo Benartzi
speaker_bio: Shlomo Benartzi uses behavioral economics to study how and why we plan well for the future (or fail to), and uses that to develop new programs to encourage saving for retirement.

talk: Using tech to enable dreaming
speaker: Shilo Shiv Suleman
speaker_bio: Shilo Shiv Suleman is an illustrator, storyteller and iPad book creator.

talk: Comedy is translation
speaker: Chris Bliss
speaker_bio: Chris Bliss explores the inherent challenge of communication, and how comedy opens paths to new perspectives.

talk: 2600 years of history in one object
speaker: Neil MacGregor
speaker_bio: The writer and presenter of the BBC Radio 4 series "A History of the World in 100 Objects" and the accompanying book.

talk: Look up for a change
speaker: Lucianne Walkowicz
speaker_bio: Lucianne Walkowicz works on NASA's Kepler mission, studying starspots and "the tempestuous tantrums of stellar flares."

talk: The true cost of oil
speaker: Garth Lenz
speaker_bio: Garth Lenz’ touring exhibition, “The True Cost of Oil”, has played a major part in the fight against Alberta Tar Sands Mining.

talk: How mobile phones power disaster relief
speaker: Paul Conneally
speaker_bio: Paul Conneally is the public communications manager for the International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, and a leader in using digital technologies for humanitarian aid.

talk: How do you save a shark you know nothing about?
speaker: Simon Berrow
speaker_bio: Simon Berrow is a marine biologist dedicated to studying and preserving the basking shark.

talk: Crowdsource your health
speaker: Lucien Engelen
speaker_bio: Lucien Engelen is a strategist and innovator in health(care) who is working to put patients into the healthcare team.

talk: What you don't know about marriage
speaker: Jenna McCarthy
speaker_bio: Jenna McCarthy writes about relationships, marriage and parenting.

talk: The toxic baby
speaker: Tyrone Hayes
speaker_bio: Tyrone Hayes studies frogs and amphibians -- and the effects on their bodies of common farming chemicals.

talk: Deaf in the military
speaker: Keith Nolan
speaker_bio: Keith Nolan doesn't believe his deafness should be a barrier to serving his country -- and is making the case for increasing the role of citizens with disabilities in the military.

talk: Everyday leadership
speaker: Drew Dudley
speaker_bio: Drew Dudley believes leadership is not a characteristic reserved for the extraordinary. He works to help people discover the leader within themselves.

talk: Impossible photography
speaker: Erik Johansson
speaker_bio: Photographer Erik Johansson creates impossible but photorealistic images that capture an idea, not a moment.

talk: Where are the baby dinosaurs?
speaker: Jack Horner
speaker_bio: Jack Horner and his dig teams have discovered the first evidence of parental care in dinosaurs, extensive nesting grounds, evidence of dinosaur herds, and the world’s first dinosaur embryos. He's now exploring how to build a dinosaur.

talk: Globalizing the local, localizing the global
speaker: Sheikha Al Mayassa
speaker_bio: Sheikha Al Mayassa is the young and progressive force behind Qatar's mission to become the Middle East's foremost destination for the arts and culture.

talk: How your brain tells you where you are
speaker: Neil Burgess
speaker_bio: At University College in London, Neil Burgess researches how patterns of electrical activity in brain cells guide us through space.

talk: The secret structure of great talks
speaker: Nancy Duarte
speaker_bio: Nancy Duarte believes that ideas are the most powerful tools people have.  Her passion is to help every person learn to communicate their world-changing idea effectively.

talk: Let's bridge the digital divide!
speaker: Aleph Molinari
speaker_bio: Through education and technology-focused community centers, Aleph Molinari empowers the 5 billion people who cannot access or use the Internet and other technologies.

talk: Hooked by an octopus
speaker: Mike deGruy
speaker_bio: Mike deGruy filmed in and on the ocean for more than three decades -- becoming almost as famous for his storytelling as for his glorious, intimate visions of the sea and the creatures who live in it.

talk: Back to the future (of 1994)
speaker: Danny Hillis
speaker_bio: Inventor, scientist, author, engineer -- over his broad career, Danny Hillis has turned his ever-searching brain on an array of subjects, with surprising results.

talk: The universal anesthesia machine
speaker: Erica Frenkel
speaker_bio: At Gradian Health Systems, Erica Frenkel works to bring safe anesthesia to hospitals all over the world.

talk: The happy secret to better work
speaker: Shawn Achor
speaker_bio: Shawn Achor is the CEO of Good Think Inc., where he researches and teaches about positive psychology.

talk: Treating cancer with electric fields
speaker: Bill Doyle
speaker_bio: With his company Novocure, Bill Doyle works to bring breakthrough medical technologies to doctors and patients.

talk: Why I chose a gun
speaker: Peter van Uhm
speaker_bio: General Peter van Uhm is the Chief of the Netherlands Defence staff.

talk: What happens inside those massive warehouses?
speaker: Mick Mountz
speaker_bio: Mick Mountz is the founder and CEO of Kiva Systems, making high-tech products for fast, cheap and efficient inventory fulfillment. In March 2012, Kiva was acquired by Amazon.

talk: Women entrepreneurs, example not exception
speaker: Gayle Tzemach Lemmon
speaker_bio: Gayle Tzemach Lemmon writes about women around the world living their lives at war and in conflict zones.

talk: Doctors make mistakes. Can we talk about that?
speaker: Brian Goldman
speaker_bio: Brian Goldman is an emergency-room physician in Toronto, and the host of CBC Radio’s "White Coat, Black Art."

talk: Extreme swimming with the world's most dangerous jellyfish
speaker: Diana Nyad
speaker_bio: A record-setting long-distance swimmer, Diana Nyad writes and thinks deeply about motivation.

talk: A primer on 3D printing
speaker: Lisa Harouni
speaker_bio: Lisa Harouni is the co-founder of Digital Forming, working in "additive manufacturing" -- or 3D printing.

talk: Is there a real you?
speaker: Julian Baggini
speaker_bio: Julian Baggini is a journalist and philosopher who studies the complexities of personal identity. He is the editor-in-chief of the Philosophers' Magazine.

talk: Plant fuels that could power a jet
speaker: Bilal Bomani
speaker_bio: Bilal Bomani runs NASA’s Greenlab research facility, where he is developing the next generation of biofuels.

talk: The beautiful math behind the world's ugliest music
speaker: Scott Rickard
speaker_bio: Scott Rickard is passionate about mathematics, music -- and educating the next generation of scientists and mathematicians.

talk: How to make choosing easier
speaker: Sheena Iyengar
speaker_bio: Sheena Iyengar studies how people choose (and what makes us think we're good at it).

talk: Why SOPA is a bad idea
speaker: Clay Shirky
speaker_bio: Clay Shirky argues that the history of the modern world could be rendered as the history of ways of arguing, where changes in media change what sort of arguments are possible -- with deep social and political implications.

talk: Three types of online attack
speaker: Mikko Hypponen
speaker_bio: As computer access expands, Mikko Hypponen asks: What's the next killer virus, and will the world be able to cope with it? And also: How can we protect digital privacy in the age of government surveillance?

talk: Atheism 2.0
speaker: Alain de Botton
speaker_bio: Through his witty and literate books -- and his new School of Life  -- Alain de Botton helps others find fulfillment in the everyday.

talk: Meet the Water Canary
speaker: Sonaar Luthra
speaker_bio: TED Senior Fellow Sonaar Luthra is measuring climate-related water risk and implementing solutions for organizations and communities facing 21st-century water security challenges.

talk: The debut of the British Paraorchestra
speaker: British Paraorchestra
speaker_bio: The British Paraorchestra is the first orchestra for world-class musicians of disability

talk: Thorium, an alternative nuclear fuel
speaker: Kirk Sorensen
speaker_bio: Kirk Sorensen stumbled across thorium while doing research on how to power a lunar community.  Thorium is a cleaner, safer, and more abundant nuclear fuel -- one that Kirk believes will revolutionize how we produce our energy.

talk: "Women of Hope"
speaker: Morley
speaker_bio: Recording artist, singer, and composer Morley weaves jazz, soul and folk traditions into a vocal and acoustic splendor and has graced stages from Nomad Women’s Festival to Carnegie Hall.

talk: Animations of unseeable biology
speaker: Drew Berry
speaker_bio: Drew Berry creates stunning and scientifically accurate animations to illustrate how the molecules in our cell move and interact.

talk: In defense of dialogue
speaker: Jonas Gahr Støre
speaker_bio: Jonas Gahr Støre is the Norwegian Foreign Minister, charged with working for Norway's interests internationally.

talk: Award-winning teenage science in action
speaker: Lauren Hodge
speaker_bio: Lauren Hodge won the 2011 Google Science Fair in the age 13-14 category.

talk: Be suspicious of simple stories
speaker: Tyler Cowen
speaker_bio: In his work, economist Tyler Cowen looks at clues from pop culture, art, food, to gather data and make observations on the world's globalizing culture and commerce.

talk: Can astronomers help doctors?
speaker: Michelle Borkin
speaker_bio: Michelle Borkin is a PhD candidate in applied physics. She works with the Astronomical Medicine Project and interdisciplinary 3D visualization techniques.

talk: 1,000 TED Talks in six words
speaker: Sebastian Wernicke
speaker_bio: After making a splash in the field of bioinformatics, Sebastian Wernicke moved on to the corporate sphere, where he motivates and manages multidimensional projects.

talk: The global power shift
speaker: Paddy Ashdown
speaker_bio: Paddy Ashdown is a former member of the British Parliament and a diplomat with a lifelong commitment to international cooperation.

talk: Life's third act
speaker: Jane Fonda
speaker_bio: Jane Fonda has had four extraordinary careers (so far): Oscar-winning actor, author, fitness guru and impassioned activist.

talk: How healthy living nearly killed me
speaker: A.J. Jacobs
speaker_bio: Immersing himself in alternate lifestyles and hilarious experiments (usually with himself as the guinea pig), writer A.J. Jacobs tests the limits of behavior, customs, culture -- and reports back on the wisdom and practical knowledge he's gained.

talk: There are no scraps of men
speaker: Alberto Cairo
speaker_bio: Alberto Cairo leads the International Red Cross' orthopedic rehabilitation work in Afghanistan.

talk: How to stop torture
speaker: Karen Tse
speaker_bio: In too many countries, it's still normal to torture prisoners for confessions and information. Karen Tse works to end that.

talk: The battle between your present and future self
speaker: Daniel Goldstein
speaker_bio: Daniel Goldstein studies how we make decisions about our financial selves -- both now and in the future,

talk: A prosthetic eye to treat blindness
speaker: Sheila Nirenberg
speaker_bio: Sheila Nirenberg studies how the brain encodes information -- possibly allowing us to decode it, and maybe develop prosthetic sensory devices.

talk: The quest to understand consciousness
speaker: Antonio Damasio
speaker_bio: Antonio Damasio's research in neuroscience has shown that emotions play a central role in social cognition and decision-making. His work has had a major influence on current understanding of the neural systems, which underlie memory, language, consciousness.

talk: Medicine for the 99 percent
speaker: Thomas Pogge
speaker_bio: Philosopher Thomas Pogge wants to ensure medications get to those who need it most.  He has published on a wide range of subjects such as global justice and human rights.

talk: My subversive (garden) plot
speaker: Roger Doiron
speaker_bio: Roger Doiron wants everyone to plant a garden. He’s the founder of Kitchen Gardeners International, a network of home gardeners.

talk: An unexpected place of healing
speaker: Ramona Pierson
speaker_bio: Ramona Pierson develops tools to revolutionize learning management and assessment systems -- her fourth career after aviation, neuropsychology and software development.

talk: Cooking as alchemy
speaker: Homaro Cantu
speaker_bio: The executive chef at Chicago's Moto restaurant, Homaro Cantu created postmodern cuisine and futuristic food delivery systems.

talk: Put a value on nature!
speaker: Pavan Sukhdev
speaker_bio: A banker by training, Pavan Sukhdev runs the numbers on greening up -- showing that green economies are an effective engine for creating jobs and creating wealth.

talk: Color-coded surgery
speaker: Quyen Nguyen
speaker_bio: Quyen Nguyen uses molecular probes that make tumors -- and just the tumors -- glow, as an extraordinary aid to surgeons.

talk: The hidden light of Afghanistan
speaker: Monika Bulaj
speaker_bio: Monika Bulaj’s stunning, painting-like photographs blur religious and cultural divisions, exploding stereotypes. She is a TED Fellow.

talk: What happens when an NGO admits failure
speaker: David Damberger
speaker_bio: David Damberger’s work with Engineers Without Borders has taken him from communities in India to Southern Africa to help build infrastructure -- and learn.

talk: The world's smallest 3D printer
speaker: Klaus Stadlmann
speaker_bio: Klaus Stadlmann was pursuing his PhD at Vienna's Technical University when a broken laser system gave him some unexpected free time to think. Instead of working on his thesis, he decided to build the world's smallest 3D printer.

talk: There are no mistakes on the bandstand
speaker: Stefon Harris
speaker_bio: Stefon Harris plays the vibraphone -- and leads a jazz ensemble with a collaborative sound built on collective inspiration.

talk: Ultrasound surgery -- healing without cuts
speaker: Yoav Medan
speaker_bio: With his team, Yoav Medan is developing a tool for incision-less surgery via focused ultrasound.

talk: The magnificence of spider silk
speaker: Cheryl Hayashi
speaker_bio: Cheryl Hayashi studies the delicate but terrifically strong silk threads that make up a spider's web, finding startling applications for human use.

talk: Massive-scale online collaboration
speaker: Luis von Ahn
speaker_bio: Luis von Ahn builds systems that combine humans and computers to solve large-scale problems that neither can solve alone.

talk: How to topple a dictator
speaker: Srdja Popovic
speaker_bio: Srdja Popovic was a founder and leader of the student movement that brought down the Milosovic regime. Now, he helps other nonviolent movements learn and grow.

talk: How many lives can you live?
speaker: Sarah Kay
speaker_bio: Sarah Kay is a poet, performer, educator and the founder of Project VOICE, an organization that uses spoken word poetry to entertain, educate and empower students and teachers worldwide.

talk: Don't misrepresent Africa
speaker: Leslie Dodson
speaker_bio: Leslie Dodson’s work has taken her from Latin America to Indonesia covering international finance, economics, and politics.

talk: Don't regret regret
speaker: Kathryn Schulz
speaker_bio: Kathryn Schulz is a staff writer for the New Yorker and is the author of "Being Wrong: Adventures in the Margin of Error."

talk: Building the musical muscle
speaker: Charles Limb
speaker_bio: Charles Limb is a doctor and a musician who researches the way musical creativity works in the brain.

talk: Dance vs. powerpoint, a modest proposal
speaker: John Bohannon
speaker_bio: John Bohannon is a scientist and writer who runs the annual Dance Your Ph.D. contest.

talk: What we learn before we're born
speaker: Annie Murphy Paul
speaker_bio: Annie Murphy Paul investigates how life in the womb shapes who we become.

talk: Philosophy in prison
speaker: Damon Horowitz
speaker_bio: Damon Horowitz explores what is possible at the boundaries of technology and the humanities.

talk: Living beyond limits
speaker: Amy Purdy
speaker_bio: Amy Purdy became a professional snowboarder despite losing both her legs to meningitis. She encourages us to take control of our lives, and our limits.

talk: A garden in my apartment
speaker: Britta Riley
speaker_bio: Britta Riley designs and builds urban farms  and other participatory artworks that explore the city.

talk: The technology of storytelling
speaker: Joe Sabia
speaker_bio: Joe Sabia investigates new ways to tell stories -- meshing viral video and new display technologies with old-fashioned narrative.

talk: Meet Rezero, the dancing ballbot
speaker: Péter Fankhauser
speaker_bio: Péter Fankhauser is the leader of a team of students working on Rezero, a robot that balances on a single sphere.

talk: How to defend Earth from asteroids
speaker: Phil Plait
speaker_bio: Phil Plait has spent his life evangelizing science, getting the word out about the real world and how we know what we know about it.

talk: Being young and making an impact
speaker: Natalie Warne
speaker_bio: Natalie Warne did not let being too young stop her from running a successful campaign for the Invisible Children project  In this talk, she calls on young people everywhere not to let age stop them from changing the world.

talk: How games make kids smarter
speaker: Gabe Zichermann
speaker_bio: Do kids these days have short attention spans, or does the world just move too slow? Gabe Zichermann suggests that today's video games are making children smarter -- and we should all embrace gamification.

talk: Science versus wonder?
speaker: Robin Ince
speaker_bio: The rational-minded Robin Ince conducts live experiments in comedy.

talk: Experiments that hint of longer lives
speaker: Cynthia Kenyon
speaker_bio: When it comes to aging well, having “good genes” (or rather, mutant ones) is key, says Cynthia Kenyon. She unlocked the genetic secret of longevity in roundworms — and now she’s working to do the same for humans.

talk: A 12-year-old app developer
speaker: Thomas Suarez
speaker_bio: Thomas Suarez, a 12 year old, taught himself to build iphone apps.

talk: Fly with the Jetman
speaker: Yves Rossy
speaker_bio: With a jet-powered wing attached to his body, Yves Rossy expands the possibilities of human flight.

talk: Conception to birth -- visualized
speaker: Alexander Tsiaras
speaker_bio: Using art and technology, Alexander Tsiaras visualizes the unseen human body.

talk: Open science now!
speaker: Michael Nielsen
speaker_bio: A physicist turned writer, Michael Nielsen believes online communication and collaboration tools are revolutionizing the way we make scientific discoveries.

talk: 6 ways to save the internet
speaker: Roger McNamee
speaker_bio: Ten years from now we will interact with the internet in completely different ways. Roger McNamee identifies six changes that are already transforming the ways we consume and create content.

talk: The shared experience of absurdity
speaker: Charlie Todd
speaker_bio: Charlie Todd is the creator of Improv Everywhere, a group that creates absurd and joyful public scenes.

talk: A map of the brain
speaker: Allan Jones
speaker_bio: As CEO of the Allen Institute for Brain Science, Allan Jones leads an ambitious project to build an open, online, interactive atlas of the human brain.

talk: Ancient wonders captured in 3D
speaker: Ben Kacyra
speaker_bio: Ben Kacyra uses state-of-the-art technology to preserve cultural heritage sites and let us in on their secrets in a way never before possible.

talk: High-tech art (with a sense of humor)
speaker: Aparna Rao
speaker_bio: A part of the Bangalore-based artist duo Pors & Rao, TED Senior Fellow Aparna Rao works with electro-mechanical systems and interactive installations.

talk: The line between life and not-life
speaker: Martin Hanczyc
speaker_bio: Martin Hanczyc explores the path between living and nonliving systems, using chemical droplets to study behavior of the earliest cells.

talk: The right to understand
speaker: Sandra Fisher-Martins
speaker_bio: Sandra Fisher-Martins fights “information apartheid” -- the barrier created by overly complex language.

talk: How mobile phones helped solve two murders
speaker: Paul Lewis
speaker_bio: Reporter Paul Lewis harnesses the power of mobile phones and social media -- innovations that are making every person a potential journalist.

talk: Augmented reality, techno-magic
speaker: Marco Tempest
speaker_bio: Using technology and an array of special effects, Marco Tempest develops immersive environments that allow viewers to viscerally experience the magic of technology.

talk: The real reason for brains
speaker: Daniel Wolpert
speaker_bio: A neuroscientist and engineer, Daniel Wolpert studies how the brain controls the body.

talk: A plane you can drive
speaker: Anna Mracek Dietrich
speaker_bio: Anna Mracek Dietrich is one of the creators of the Transition, the "plane you can drive."

talk: Trust, morality -- and oxytocin?
speaker: Paul Zak
speaker_bio: A pioneer in the field of neuroeconomics, Paul Zak is uncovering how the hormone oxytocin promotes trust, and proving that love is good for business.

talk: FBI, here I am!
speaker: Hasan Elahi
speaker_bio: In 2002, American artist Hasan Elahi’s name was added (by mistake) to the US government’s watch list.

talk: Stories cut from paper
speaker: Béatrice Coron
speaker_bio: Béatrice Coron has developed a language of storytelling by papercutting multi-layered stories.

talk: Open-source cancer research
speaker: Jay Bradner
speaker_bio: In his lab, Jay Bradner, a researcher at Harvard and Dana Farber in Boston, works on a breakthrough approach for subverting cancer .. and he’s giving the secret away.

talk: The strange tale of the Norden bombsight
speaker: Malcolm Gladwell
speaker_bio: Detective of fads and emerging subcultures, chronicler of jobs-you-never-knew-existed, Malcolm Gladwell's work is toppling the popular understanding of bias, crime, food, marketing, race, consumers and intelligence.

talk: How economic inequality harms societies
speaker: Richard Wilkinson
speaker_bio: In "The Spirit Level," Richard Wilkinson charts data that proves societies that are more equal are healthier, happier societies.

talk: Art made of storms
speaker: Nathalie Miebach
speaker_bio: Nathalie Miebach is a Boston-based artist who translates weather data into complex sculptures and musical scores.

talk: A prosthetic arm that "feels"
speaker: Todd Kuiken
speaker_bio: A doctor and  engineer, Todd Kuiken builds new prosthetics that connect with the human nervous system. Yes: bionics.

talk: How cyberattacks threaten real-world peace
speaker: Guy-Philippe Goldstein
speaker_bio: Guy-Philippe Goldstein is the author of Babel Minute Zero, a novel that examines the reality of cyberwar in our current geopolitical topography.

talk: Freeing energy from the grid
speaker: Justin Hall-Tipping
speaker_bio: Justin Hall-Tipping works on nano-energy startups -- mastering the electron to create power.

talk: Learning from a barefoot movement
speaker: Bunker Roy
speaker_bio: Sanjit “Bunker” Roy is the founder of Barefoot College, which helps rural communities becomes self-sufficient.

talk: My mushroom burial suit
speaker: Jae Rhim Lee
speaker_bio: TED Senior Fellow Jae Rhim Lee develops new rituals and objects around death to point us toward a more sustainable future, including a mushroom burial suit that converts our unused bodies efficiently into clean compost.

talk: How to spot a liar
speaker: Pamela Meyer
speaker_bio: Pamela Meyer thinks we’re facing a pandemic of deception, but she’s arming people with tools that can help take back the truth.

talk: The day I turned down Tim Berners-Lee
speaker: Ian Ritchie

talk: How beauty feels
speaker: Richard Seymour
speaker_bio: As a partner in seymourpowell, Richard Seymour designs idea-driven products -- from household goods to trains and motorcycles.

talk: What do babies think?
speaker: Alison Gopnik
speaker_bio: Alison Gopnik takes us into the fascinating minds of babies and children, and shows us how much we understand before we even realize we do.

talk: Trusting the ensemble
speaker: Charles Hazlewood
speaker_bio: Charles Hazlewood dusts off and invigorates classical music, adding a youthful energy and modern twists to centuries-old masterworks. At TEDGlobal, he conducts the Scottish Ensemble.

talk: We can recycle plastic
speaker: Mike Biddle
speaker_bio: Discarded plastic, too often, ends up buried or burned, not recycled (it's just too complicated). But Mike Biddle has found a way to close the loop.

talk: Less stuff, more happiness
speaker: Graham Hill
speaker_bio: Graham Hill is the founder of TreeHugger.com and LifeEdited; he travels the world to tell stories of sustainability and minimalism. He tweets at @GHill.

talk: Finding life we can't imagine
speaker: Christoph Adami
speaker_bio: Christoph Adami works on the nature of life and evolution, trying to define life in a way that is as free as possible from our preconceptions.

talk: The generation that's remaking China
speaker: Yang Lan
speaker_bio: Yang Lan is often called “the Oprah of China.” The chair of a multiplatform business empire, Yang is pioneering more-open means of communication in the communist nation.

talk: A flirtatious aria
speaker: Danielle de Niese
