speaker_bio: Her voice described as a “sweet gleaming soprano,” Danielle de Niese breathes new life into opera, astonishing critics and making audiences sit up and listen.

talk: Battling bad science
speaker: Ben Goldacre
speaker_bio: Ben Goldacre unpicks dodgy scientific claims made by scaremongering journalists, dubious government reports, pharmaceutical corporations, PR companies and quacks.

talk: Filming democracy in Ghana
speaker: Jarreth Merz
speaker_bio: Jarreth Merz' new film, "An African Election," follows the 2008 presidential elections in Ghana from start to finish.

talk: A short intro to the Studio School
speaker: Geoff Mulgan
speaker_bio: Geoff Mulgan is director of the Young Foundation, a center for social innovation, social enterprise and public policy that pioneers ideas in fields such as aging, education and poverty reduction. He’s the founder of the think-tank Demos, and the author of "The Art of Public Strategy."

talk: A doctor's touch
speaker: Abraham Verghese
speaker_bio: In our era of the patient-as-data-point, Abraham Verghese believes in the old-fashioned physical exam, the bedside chat, the power of informed observation.

talk: Doodlers, unite!
speaker: Sunni Brown
speaker_bio: In her book "Gamestorming," Sunni Brown shows how using art and games can empower serious problem-solving.

talk: Fighting a contagious cancer
speaker: Elizabeth Murchison
speaker_bio: Elizabeth Murchison studies a mysterious (and contagious) cancer that threatens to wipe out Tasmanian devils.

talk: Selling condoms in the Congo
speaker: Amy Lockwood
speaker_bio: Amy Lockwood is the deputy director of Stanford's Center for Innovation in Global Health, where she looks at new solutions to big problems.

talk: What we learned from 5 million books
speaker: Jean-Baptiste Michel
speaker_bio: Jean-Baptiste Michel looks at how we can use large volumes of data to better understand our world.

talk: The 6 killer apps of prosperity
speaker: Niall Ferguson
speaker_bio: History is a curious thing, and Niall Ferguson investigates not only what happened but why. (Hint: Politics and money explain a lot.)

talk: The conscience of television
speaker: Lauren Zalaznick
speaker_bio: After wholly revamping the Bravo Network, media trendsetter Lauren Zalaznick is inventing fresh ways for NBC Universal to reach coveted new audiences across multiple media.

talk: Welcome to the genomic revolution
speaker: Richard Resnick
speaker_bio: Richard Resnick is on the front lines of the business of genomes, as CEO of GenomeQuest, a maker of genomic software.

talk: The art of wearable communication
speaker: Kate Hartman
speaker_bio: Kate Hartman creates devices and interfaces for humans, houseplants, and glaciers. Her work playfully questions the ways in which we relate and communicate.

talk: Hire the hackers!
speaker: Misha Glenny
speaker_bio: Journalist Misha Glenny leaves no stone unturned (and no failed state unexamined) in his excavation of criminal globalization.

talk: Does democracy stifle economic growth?
speaker: Yasheng Huang
speaker_bio: Yasheng Huang asks us to rethink our ideas about China and other large emerging economies. Lately he’s been asking, Does democracy hinder or promote economic growth?

talk: Shake up your story
speaker: Raghava KK
speaker_bio: Raghava KK's paintings and drawings use cartoonish shapes and colors to examine the body, society, our world.

talk: Making matter come alive
speaker: Lee Cronin
speaker_bio: A professor of chemistry, nanoscience and chemical complexity, Lee Cronin and his research group investigate how chemistry can revolutionize modern technology and even create life.

talk: My father the forger
speaker: Sarah Kaminsky
speaker_bio: Sarah Kaminsky writes about her father, Adolfo Kaminsky, a forger with a mission.

talk: Unintended consequences
speaker: Edward Tenner
speaker_bio: Edward Tenner is an independent writer, speaker and editor who analyzes the cultural aspects of technological change.

talk: Compassion and the true meaning of empathy
speaker: Joan Halifax
speaker_bio: Known for her compassionate work with the terminally ill, Joan Halifax is a driving force of socially engaged Buddhism.

talk: Can we make things that make themselves?
speaker: Skylar Tibbits
speaker_bio: Skylar Tibbits is the founder and codirector of the Self-Assembly Lab at MIT and assistant professor of design research in the department of architecture.

talk: Pay attention to nonviolence
speaker: Julia Bacha
speaker_bio: Julia Bacha is the creative director at Just Vision, an organization that uses film and multimedia storytelling to foster constructive conversations on some of the most divisive issues of our times.

talk: DNA clues to our inner neanderthal
speaker: Svante Pääbo
speaker_bio: Svante Pääbo explores human genetic evolution by analyzing DNA extracted from ancient sources, including mummies, an Ice Age hunter and the bone fragments of Neanderthals.

talk: Beware conflicts of interest
speaker: Dan Ariely
speaker_bio: The dismal science of economics is not as firmly grounded in actual behavior as was once supposed. In "Predictably Irrational," Dan Ariely told us why.

talk: The magic of truth and lies (and iPods)
speaker: Marco Tempest
speaker_bio: Using technology and an array of special effects, Marco Tempest develops immersive environments that allow viewers to viscerally experience the magic of technology.

talk: Finding planets around other stars
speaker: Lucianne Walkowicz
speaker_bio: Lucianne Walkowicz works on NASA's Kepler mission, studying starspots and "the tempestuous tantrums of stellar flares."

talk: One day of peace
speaker: Jeremy Gilley
speaker_bio: Filmmaker Jeremy Gilley founded Peace One Day to create an annual day without conflict. And ... it's happening. What will you do to make peace on September 21?

talk: The great penguin rescue
speaker: Dyan deNapoli
speaker_bio: Call her "the Penguin Lady." Dyan deNapoli educates the world about these fascinating birds.

talk: The shareable future of cities
speaker: Alex Steffen
speaker_bio: Alex Steffen explores our planet's future, telling powerful, inspiring stories about the hard choices facing humanity ... and our opportunity to create a much better tomorrow.

talk: Suddenly, my body
speaker: Eve Ensler
speaker_bio: Eve Ensler created the groundbreaking "Vagina Monologues," whose success propelled her to found V-Day -- a movement to end violence against women and girls everywhere.

talk: The demise of guys?
speaker: Philip Zimbardo
speaker_bio: Philip Zimbardo was the leader of the notorious 1971 Stanford Prison Experiment -- and an expert witness at Abu Ghraib. His book The Lucifer Effect explores the nature of evil; now, in his new work, he studies the nature of heroism.

talk: Are we filtering the wrong microbes?
speaker: Jessica Green
speaker_bio: Jessica Green wants people to understand the important role microbes play in every facet of our lives: climate change, building ecosystems, human health, even roller derby -- using nontraditional tools like art, animation and film to help people visualize the invisible world.

talk: How language transformed humanity
speaker: Mark Pagel
speaker_bio: Using biological evolution as a template, Mark Pagel wonders how languages evolve.

talk: Wireless data from every light bulb
speaker: Harald Haas
speaker_bio: Harald Haas is the pioneer behind a new technology that can communicate as well as illuminate.

talk: After your final status update
speaker: Adam Ostrow
speaker_bio: As editor in chief at Mashable, Adam Ostrow covers the tech, trends and people driving the evolution of the Web.

talk: 5 ways to listen better
speaker: Julian Treasure
speaker_bio: Julian Treasure studies sound and advises businesses on how best to use it.

talk: Ending hunger now
speaker: Josette Sheeran
speaker_bio: Our generation is the first in history with enough resources to eradicate hunger worldwide. Josette Sheeran, the former head of the UN World Food Programme, shares a plan.

talk: The origins of pleasure
speaker: Paul Bloom
speaker_bio: Paul Bloom explores some of the most puzzling aspects of human nature, including pleasure, religion, and morality.

talk: The surprising math of cities and corporations
speaker: Geoffrey West
speaker_bio: Physicist Geoffrey West believes that complex systems from organisms to cities are in many ways governed by simple laws -- laws that can be discovered and analyzed.

talk: Time to end the war in Afghanistan
speaker: Rory Stewart
speaker_bio: Rory Stewart -- a perpetual pedestrian, a diplomat, an adventurer and an author -- is the member of British Parliament for Penrith and the Border.

talk: How algorithms shape our world
speaker: Kevin Slavin
speaker_bio: Kevin Slavin navigates in the algoworld, the expanding space in our lives that’s determined and run by algorithms.

talk: Embracing otherness, embracing myself
speaker: Thandiwe Newton
speaker_bio: Swinging from Hollywood blockbusters to sensitive indie films, Thandiwe Newton brings thoughtfulness and delicate beauty to her work.

talk: Fighting viruses, defending the net
speaker: Mikko Hypponen
speaker_bio: As computer access expands, Mikko Hypponen asks: What's the next killer virus, and will the world be able to cope with it? And also: How can we protect digital privacy in the age of government surveillance?

talk: See Yemen through my eyes
speaker: Nadia Al-Sakkaf
speaker_bio: Nadia Al-Sakkaf is the editor-in-chief of the Yemen Times, the most widely read English-language newspaper in Yemen.

talk: Trial, error and the God complex
speaker: Tim Harford
speaker_bio: Tim Harford's writings reveal the economic ideas behind everyday experiences.

talk: A global culture to fight extremism
speaker: Maajid Nawaz
speaker_bio: Maajid Nawaz works to promote conversation, tolerance and democracy in Muslim and non-Muslim communities.

talk: Let's take back the Internet!
speaker: Rebecca MacKinnon
speaker_bio: Rebecca MacKinnon looks at issues of free expression, governance and democracy (or lack of) in the digital networks, platforms and services on which we are all more and more dependent.

talk: Caring for engineered tissue
speaker: Nina Tandon
speaker_bio: Nina Tandon studies ways to use electrical signals to grow artificial tissues for transplants and other therapies.

talk: Don't take consciousness for granted
speaker: Simon Lewis
speaker_bio: Simon Lewis is the author of "Rise and Shine," a memoir about his remarkable recovery from a car accident and coma, and his new approach to our own consciousness.

talk: The beautiful tricks of flowers
speaker: Jonathan Drori
speaker_bio: Jonathan Drori commissioned the BBC's very first websites, one highlight in a long career devoted to online culture and educational media -- and understanding how we learn.

talk: Cooking as never seen before
speaker: Nathan Myhrvold
speaker_bio: Nathan Myhrvold is a professional jack-of-all-trades. After leaving Microsoft in 1999, he's been a world barbecue champion, a wildlife photographer, a chef, a contributor to SETI, and a volcano explorer.

talk: Try something new for 30 days
speaker: Matt Cutts
speaker_bio: An early employee at Google, Matt Cutts works to modernize the US government as an administrator at U.S. Digital Service (USDS).

talk: Building a park in the sky
speaker: Robert Hammond
speaker_bio: The co-founder of Friends of the High Line, Robert Hammond helped lead the effort to build an elevated park on an abandoned railway line in Manhattan.

talk: Meet e-Patient Dave
speaker: Dave deBronkart
speaker_bio: Dave deBronkart wants to help patients help themselves -- by owning their medical data, connecting to fellow patients and making medical care better.

talk: A Rosetta Stone for a lost language
speaker: Rajesh Rao
speaker_bio: Rajesh Rao seeks to understand the human brain through computational modeling, on two fronts: developing computer models of our minds, and using tech to decipher the 4,000-year-old lost script of the Indus Valley civilization.

talk: On being just crazy enough
speaker: Joshua Walters
speaker_bio: Joshua Walters is a bipolar comedian whose work explores language, creativity, beatboxing and madness ...

talk: A history of the universe in sound
speaker: Honor Harger
speaker_bio: Honor Harger explores the cultural impact of scientific ideas and how technology shapes society.

talk: A circle of caring
speaker: Jok Church
speaker_bio: Jok Church created the science-education comic strip "You Can with Beakman and Jax" and the zany TV series "Beakman's World."

talk: Different ways of knowing
speaker: Daniel Tammet
speaker_bio: Daniel Tammet is the author of "Born on a Blue Day," about his life with high-functioning autistic savant syndrome. He runs the language-learning site Optimnem, and his new book is "Embracing the Wide Sky: A Tour Across the Horizons of the Mind."

talk: A future beyond traffic gridlock
speaker: Bill Ford
speaker_bio: As executive chair of the Ford Motor Company, Bill Ford leads the company that put the world on wheels.

talk: A cello with many voices
speaker: Maya Beiser
speaker_bio: Maya Beiser commissions and performs radical new work for the cello.

talk: This is beatjazz
speaker: Onyx Ashanti
speaker_bio: Onyx Ashanti is the inventor of "beatjazz" -- a new way to make music.

talk: Haunting photos of polar ice
speaker: Camille Seaman
speaker_bio: TED Senior Fellow Camille Seaman photographs big ice and big clouds.

talk: A manifesto for play, for Bulgaria and beyond
speaker: Steve Keil
speaker_bio: Based in Bulgaria, Steve Keil creates companies around big social and environmental goals.

talk: How I became 100 artists
speaker: Shea Hembrey
speaker_bio: Shea Hembrey explores patterns from nature and myth. A childhood love of nature, and especially birdlife, informs his vision.

talk: Medicine's future? There's an app for that
speaker: Daniel Kraft
speaker_bio: Daniel Kraft explores the impact and potential of rapidly developing technologies as applied to health and medicine.

talk: Break the silence for suicide attempt survivors
speaker: JD Schramm
speaker_bio: JD Schramm teaches future business leaders both the theoretical and practical aspects of communication.

talk: Is anatomy destiny?
speaker: Alice Dreger
speaker_bio: Alice Dreger studies history and anatomy, and acts as a patient advocate.

talk: The world's first charter city?
speaker: Paul Romer
speaker_occ: Chief Economist and Senior Vice President, World Bank
speaker_bio: Paul Romer's research on catch-up growth in low- and middle-income countries has emphasized the importance of government policies that encourage orderly urban expansion.

talk: Taking imagination seriously
speaker: Janet Echelman
speaker_bio: American artist Janet Echelman reshapes urban airspace with monumental, fluidly moving sculpture that responds to environmental forces including wind, water, and sunlight.

talk: We need a "moral operating system"
speaker: Damon Horowitz
speaker_bio: Damon Horowitz explores what is possible at the boundaries of technology and the humanities.

talk: Wearing nothing new
speaker: Jessi Arrington
speaker_bio: Jessi Arrington is a color-loving designer based in Brooklyn.

talk: 7 rules for making more happiness
speaker: Stefan Sagmeister
speaker_bio: Renowned for album covers, posters and his recent book of life lessons, designer Stefan Sagmeister invariably has a slightly different way of looking at things.

talk: Making a car for blind drivers
speaker: Dennis Hong
speaker_bio: Dennis Hong is the founder and director of RoMeLa -- a Virginia Tech robotics lab that has pioneered several breakthroughs in robot design and engineering.

talk: On violin and cello, "Passacaglia"
speaker: Robert Gupta
speaker_bio: Violinist Robert Gupta joined the LA Philharmonic at the age of 19 -- and maintains a passionate parallel interest in neurobiology and mental health issues. He's a TED Senior Fellow.

talk: Faith versus tradition in Islam
speaker: Mustafa Akyol
speaker_bio: Mustafa Akyol is a columnist for Turkey's oldest English-language daily, Hurriyet Daily News.

talk: Art in exile
speaker: Shirin Neshat
speaker_bio: Shirin Neshat has lived much of her life outside her native Iran. Her photographs and films offer a glimpse of the cultural, religious and political realities that shape the identities of Muslim women worldwide.

talk: How we'll stop polio for good
speaker: Bruce Aylward
speaker_bio: As the Assistant Director-General of the World Health Organization’s Polio and Emergencies Cluster, Bruce Aylward works to ensure that polio stays under control and that the world is prepared to respond to health crises.

talk: Visualizing ourselves ... with crowd-sourced data
speaker: Aaron Koblin
speaker_bio: Aaron Koblin is an artist specializing in data and digital technologies. His work takes real world and community-generated data and uses it to reflect on cultural trends and the changing relationship between humans and technology.

talk: How to tie your shoes
speaker: Terry Moore
speaker_bio: Terry Moore is the director of the Radius Foundation, a forum for exploring and gaining insight from different worldviews.

talk: The weird, wonderful world of bioluminescence
speaker: Edith Widder
speaker_bio: Edith Widder combines her expertise in research and technological innovation with a commitment to stopping and reversing the degradation of our marine environment.

talk: The mystery of chronic pain
speaker: Elliot Krane
speaker_bio: At the Lucile Packard Children's Hospital at Stanford, Elliot Krane works on the problem of treating pain in children.

talk: Building the Seed Cathedral
speaker: Thomas Heatherwick
speaker_bio: Thomas Heatherwick is the founder of Heatherwick Studio, an architecture and design firm that, among other projects, designed the astonishing "Seed Cathedral" for the UK Pavilion at Shanghai Expo 2010.

talk: A light switch for neurons
speaker: Ed Boyden
speaker_bio: Ed Boyden is a professor of biological engineering and brain and cognitive sciences at the MIT Media Lab and the MIT McGovern Institute.

talk: My friend Richard Feynman
speaker: Leonard Susskind
speaker_bio: Leonard Susskind works on string theory, quantum field theory, quantum statistical mechanics and quantum cosmology at Stanford.

talk: Building a museum of museums on the web
speaker: Amit Sood
speaker_bio: As the director of Google's Cultural Institute and Art Project, Amit Sood leads the effort to bring cultural artifacts from museums, archives and foundations onto the web in extraordinary detail.

talk: The hidden power of smiling
speaker: Ron Gutman
speaker_bio: Ron Gutman is the founder and former CEO of HealthTap, free mobile and online apps for health info. He's also the organizer of TEDxSiliconValley.

talk: Silk, the ancient material of the future
speaker: Fiorenzo Omenetto
speaker_bio: Fiorenzo G. Omenetto's research spans nonlinear optics, nanostructured materials (such as photonic crystals and photonic crystal fibers), biomaterials and biopolymer-based photonics. Most recently, he's working on high-tech applications for silk.

talk: Animal tales from icy wonderlands
speaker: Paul Nicklen
speaker_bio: Paul Nicklen photographs the creatures of the Arctic and Antarctic, generating global awareness about wildlife in these isolated and endangered environments.

talk: The hidden beauty of pollination
speaker: Louie Schwartzberg
speaker_bio: Louie Schwartzberg is a cinematographer, director and producer who captures breathtaking images that celebrate life -- revealing connections, universal rhythms, patterns and beauty.

talk: Distant time and the hint of a multiverse
speaker: Sean Carroll
speaker_bio: A physicist, cosmologist and gifted science communicator, Sean Carroll is asking himself -- and asking us to consider -- questions that get at the fundamental nature of the universe.

talk: Grow your own clothes
speaker: Suzanne Lee
speaker_bio: TED Fellow Suzanne Lee is a fashion designer turned biofabrication pioneer who is nurturing a global community of innovators growing materials.

talk: The mothers who found forgiveness, friendship
speaker: Aicha el-Wafi + Phyllis Rodriguez
speaker_bio: Aicha el-Wafi and Phyllis Rodriguez met around a shared tragedy -- and their friendship has become a powerful symbol for forgiveness and dialogue.

talk: Beware online "filter bubbles"
speaker: Eli Pariser
speaker_bio: As a cofounder of Upworthy, and the author of "The Filter Bubble," Eli Pariser leverages technology to help build better and more democratic societies.

talk: Turning trash into toys for learning
speaker: Arvind Gupta
speaker_bio: Science educator Arvind Gupta uses simple toys to teach.

talk: A next-generation digital book
speaker: Mike Matas
speaker_bio: While at Apple, Mike Matas helped write the user interface for the iPhone and iPad. Now with Push Pop Press, he's helping to rewrite the electronic book.

talk: Using nature to grow batteries
speaker: Angela Belcher
speaker_bio: Angela Belcher looks to nature for inspiration on how to engineer viruses to create extraordinary new materials.

talk: The security mirage
speaker: Bruce Schneier
speaker_bio: Bruce Schneier thinks hard about security -- as a computer security guru, and as a philosopher of the larger notion of making a safer world.

talk: Are we ready for neo-evolution?
speaker: Harvey Fineberg
speaker_bio: Harvey Fineberg studies medical decisionmaking -- from how we roll out new medical technology, to how we cope with new illnesses and threatened epidemics.

talk: 3 things I learned while my plane crashed
speaker: Ric Elias
speaker_bio: Ric Elias is the CEO and cofounder of Red Ventures, a portfolio of fast-growing digital businesses.

talk: What it takes to do extreme astrophysics
speaker: Anil Ananthaswamy
speaker_bio: Anil Ananthaswamy specializes in writing about neuroscience and physics. He is the author of "The Man Who Wasn’t There," "The Edge of Physics" and the forthcoming "Through Two Doors at Once."

talk: On being wrong
speaker: Kathryn Schulz
speaker_bio: Kathryn Schulz is a staff writer for the New Yorker and is the author of "Being Wrong: Adventures in the Margin of Error."

talk: A radical experiment in empathy
speaker: Sam Richards
speaker_bio: Sam Richards is a sociologist and teacher of the largest race relations course in the US. He argues that empathy is the core of sociology.

talk: Transplant cells, not organs
speaker: Susan Lim
speaker_bio: A surgical pioneer in Singapore, Susan Lim is a researcher and entrepreneur.

talk: Open-sourced blueprints for civilization
speaker: Marcin Jakubowski
speaker_bio: Marcin Jakubowski is open-sourcing a set of blueprints for 50 farming tools that can be built cheaply from scratch. Call it a "civilization starter kit."

talk: Remaking my voice
speaker: Roger Ebert
speaker_bio: After losing the power to speak, legendary film critic Roger Ebert went on to write about creativity, race, politics and culture -- and film, just as brilliantly as ever.

talk: The antidote to apathy
speaker: Dave Meslin
speaker_bio: Dave Meslin is a "professional rabble-rouser." Based in Toronto, he works to make local issues engaging and even fun to get involved in.

talk: The history of our world in 18 minutes
speaker: David Christian
speaker_bio: David Christian teaches an ambitious world history course that tells the tale of the entire universe -- from the Big Bang 13 billion years ago to present day.

talk: A song inspired by the ocean
speaker: Jackson Browne
speaker_bio: Jackson Browne has written and performed some of the most literate and moving songs in popular music -- and has defined a genre of songwriting charged with honesty, emotion and personal politics.

talk: Looking past limits
speaker: Caroline Casey
speaker_bio: Caroline Casey works relentlessly to bring out a global shift in business inclusion, and ensure that everyone can live their life without limit or labels.

talk: The invention that unlocked a locked-in artist
speaker: Mick Ebeling
speaker_bio: Mick Ebeling founded the Not Impossible Foundation, a nonprofit that develops creative solutions to real-world problems.

talk: The greatest TED Talk ever sold
speaker: Morgan Spurlock
speaker_bio: Morgan Spurlock makes documentary film and TV that is personal, political -- and, above all, deeply empathetic.

talk: Everyday compassion at Google
speaker: Chade-Meng Tan
speaker_bio: One of Google's earliest engineers, Chade-Meng Tan is now Google's Jolly Good Fellow -- the head of personal growth at the groundbreaking search company.

talk: Listen, learn ... then lead
speaker: Stanley McChrystal
speaker_bio: General Stanley McChrystal is the former commander of U.S. and International forces in Afghanistan. A four-star general, he is credited for creating a revolution in warfare that fuses intelligence and operations.

talk: Hands-on science with squishy circuits
speaker: AnnMarie Thomas
speaker_bio: AnnMarie Thomas works on the playful side of engineering -- using cool tools to teach and help others.

talk: A virtual choir 2,000 voices strong
speaker: Eric Whitacre
speaker_bio: After creating and conducting a worldwide virtual choir on YouTube, Eric Whitacre is now touring with an astonishing live choir.

talk: Google's driverless car
speaker: Sebastian Thrun
speaker_bio: Sebastian Thrun is a passionate technologist who is constantly looking for new opportunities to make the world better for all of us.

talk: The genius puppetry behind War Horse
speaker: Handspring Puppet Company
speaker_bio: Basil Jones and Adrian Kohler, of Handspring Puppet Company, bring the emotional complexity of animals to the stage with their life-size puppets. Their latest triumph: "War Horse."

talk: Cracking Stuxnet, a 21st-century cyber weapon
speaker: Ralph Langner
speaker_bio: Ralph Langner is a German control system security consultant. He has received worldwide recognition for his analysis of the Stuxnet malware.

talk: Don't insist on English!
speaker: Patricia Ryan
speaker_bio: Patricia Ryan has spent the past three-plus decades teaching English in Arabic countries -- where she has seen vast cultural (and linguistic) change.

talk: Human exoskeletons -- for war and healing
speaker: Eythor Bender
speaker_bio: Eythor Bender is the CEO of Berkeley Bionics, which augments humans with wearable, powered and artificially intelligent devices called exoskeletons or "wearable robots."

talk: It's time to question bio-engineering
speaker: Paul Root Wolpe
speaker_bio: Paul Root Wolpe examines the ethical implications of new science -- genetic modification, neuroscience and other breakthroughs that stretch our current philosophy to the breaking point. He's the chief bioethicist at NASA, among other appointments.

talk: Evolution's gift of play, from bonobo apes to humans
speaker: Isabel Behncke
speaker_bio: Isabel Behncke applies an evolutionary lens to human questions like: Why do we play?

talk: The magic washing machine
speaker: Hans Rosling
speaker_bio: In Hans Rosling’s hands, data sings. Global trends in health and economics come to vivid life. And the big picture of global development -- with some surprisingly good news -- snaps into sharp focus.

talk: If I should have a daughter ...
speaker: Sarah Kay
speaker_bio: Sarah Kay is a poet, performer, educator and the founder of Project VOICE, an organization that uses spoken word poetry to entertain, educate and empower students and teachers worldwide.

talk: Why light needs darkness
speaker: Rogier van der Heide
speaker_bio: Rogier van der Heide creates architectural spaces with light.

talk: A life lesson from a volunteer firefighter
speaker: Mark Bezos
speaker_bio: Mark Bezos works at Robin Hood, a poverty-fighting charity in New York City, and the assistant captain of a volunteer fire company in suburban New York.

talk: The sound the universe makes
speaker: Janna Levin
speaker_bio: Janna Levin is a professor of physics and astronomy at Barnard, where she studies the early universe, chaos, and black holes. She's the author of  “How the Universe Got Its Spots" and the novel “A Madman Dreams of Turing Machines.”

talk: The social animal
speaker: David Brooks
speaker_bio: Writer and thinker David Brooks has covered business, crime and politics over a long career in journalism.

talk: How to keep rivers and streams flowing
speaker: Rob Harmon
speaker_bio: Rob Harmon is an expert on energy and natural resources policy -- looking at smart ways to manage carbon, water and the energy we use every day.

talk: The birth of a word
speaker: Deb Roy
speaker_bio: Deb Roy studies how children learn language, and designs machines that learn to communicate in human-like ways. On sabbatical from MIT Media Lab, he's working with the AI company Bluefin Labs.

talk: Let's use video to reinvent education
speaker: Sal Khan
speaker_bio: In 2004, Sal Khan, a hedge fund analyst, began making math tutorials for his cousins. Twelve years later, Khan Academy has more than 42 million registered users from 190 countries, with tutorials on subjects from basic math through economics, art history, computer science, health, medicine and more.

talk: This isn't her mother's feminism
speaker: Courtney E. Martin
speaker_bio: Courtney E. Martin’s work has two obsessions at its core: storytelling and solutions.

talk: Printing a human kidney
speaker: Anthony Atala
speaker_bio: Anthony Atala asks, "Can we grow organs instead of transplanting them?" His lab at the Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine is doing just that -- engineering over 30 tissues and whole organs.

talk: How state budgets are breaking US schools
speaker: Bill Gates
speaker_bio: A passionate tech visionary, Bill Gates changed the world while leading Microsoft to dizzying success. Now he's doing it again through his global philanthropic work that strives to reduce inequity everywhere.

talk: Inside the Egyptian revolution
speaker: Wael Ghonim
speaker_bio: Wael Ghonim believes that the Internet can be the most powerful platform for connecting humanity, if we can bring civility and thoughtful conversations back to it.

talk: My wish
speaker: JR
speaker_bio: With a camera, a dedicated wheatpasting crew and the help of whole villages and favelas, 2011 TED Prize winner JR shows the world its true face.

talk: A historic moment in the Arab world
speaker: Wadah Khanfar
speaker_bio: As the Director General of Al Jazeera from 2003-2011, Wadah Khanfar worked to bring rare liberties like information, transparency and dissenting voices to repressive states and political hot zones.

talk: A modern take on piano, violin, cello
speaker: Ahn Trio
speaker_bio: With cello, piano and violin, sisters Maria, Lucia and Angella Ahn are constantly redefining the art and architecture of chamber music.

talk: Understanding cancer through proteomics
speaker: Danny Hillis
speaker_bio: Inventor, scientist, author, engineer -- over his broad career, Danny Hillis has turned his ever-searching brain on an array of subjects, with surprising results.

talk: Curating humanity's heritage
speaker: Elizabeth Lindsey
speaker_bio: Elizabeth Lindsey is a fellow of the National Geographic Society. Her mission: to keep ancestral voices alive by recording indigenous wisdom and traditions.

talk: Saving faces
speaker: Iain Hutchison
speaker_bio: Iain Hutchison is a pioneering oral and facial surgeon; his foundation, Saving Faces, explores the nature of our expressions.

talk: How to use experts -- and when not to
speaker: Noreena Hertz
speaker_bio: Noreena Hertz looks at global culture -- financial and otherwise -- using an approach that combines traditional economic analysis with foreign policy trends, psychology, behavioural economics, anthropology, history and sociology.

talk: On being a woman and a diplomat
speaker: Madeleine Albright
speaker_bio: Since leaving office as US Secretary of State in 2001, Madeleine Albright has continued her distinguished career in foreign affairs as a businesswoman, political adviser and professor.

talk: The future of business is the "mesh"
speaker: Lisa Gansky
speaker_bio: Lisa Gansky is the author of "The Mesh: Why the Future of Business Is Sharing," and the instigator behind the Mesh Directory (www.meshing.it).

talk: Inspiring a life of immersion
speaker: Jacqueline Novogratz
speaker_bio: Jacqueline Novogratz works to enable human flourishing. Her organization, Acumen, invests in people, companies and ideas that see capital and networks as means, not ends, to solving the toughest issues of poverty.

talk: The linguistic genius of babies
speaker: Patricia Kuhl
speaker_bio: Patricia Kuhl studies how we learn language as babies, looking at the ways our brains form around language acquisition.

talk: A whistleblower you haven't heard
speaker: Geert Chatrou
speaker_bio: It all started as a practical joke: Geert Chatrou's sister-in-law entered him in the International Whistler's Convention in Louisburg, NC. To save face, he went … and won!

talk: Using nature's genius in architecture
speaker: Michael Pawlyn
speaker_bio: Michael Pawlyn takes cues from nature to make new, sustainable architectural environments.

talk: Mother and daughter doctor-heroes
speaker: Dr. Hawa Abdi + Dr. Deqo Mohamed
speaker_occ: Somali doctors who treat women refugees
speaker_bio: Dr. Hawa Abdi and her daughters, Dr. Deqo Mohamed and Dr. Amina Mohamed, treat Somali refugee women and children, often for free.

talk: The rise of personal robots
speaker: Cynthia Breazeal
speaker_bio: At MIT, Cynthia Breazeal and her team are building robots with social intelligence that communicate and learn the same way people do.

talk: How to make work-life balance work
speaker: Nigel Marsh
speaker_bio: Nigel Marsh presents and writes on business and personal life -- and how the two interact. He is the author of "Fat, Forty and Fired."

talk: Poems of war, peace, women, power
speaker: Suheir Hammad
speaker_bio: In her poems and plays, Suheir Hammad blends the stories and sounds of her Palestinian-American heritage with the vibrant language of Brooklyn to create a passionately modern voice.

talk: Are we born to run?
speaker: Christopher McDougall
speaker_bio: Christopher McDougall is the author of "Born to Run: A Hidden Tribe, Super Athletes, and the Greatest Race the World Has Never Seen."

talk: Social media and the end of gender
speaker: Johanna Blakley
speaker_bio: Johanna Blakley studies the impact of mass media and entertainment on our world.

talk: We are makers
speaker: Dale Dougherty
speaker_bio: A technology and publishing enthusiast, Dale Dougherty founded MAKE magazine and created the world's largest DIY festival, Maker Faire.

talk: Reviving New York's rivers -- with oysters!
speaker: Kate Orff
speaker_bio: Kate Orff asks us to rethink “landscape”—to use urban greenspaces and blue spaces in fresh ways to mediate between humankind and nature.

talk: Know thyself, with a brain scanner
speaker: Ariel Garten
speaker_bio: As CEO of InteraXon, Ariel Garten works to close the gap between science, art, business and technology.

talk: Drawing on humor for change
speaker: Liza Donnelly
speaker_bio: New Yorker cartoonist Liza Donnelly tackles global issues with humor, intelligence and sarcasm. Her latest project supports the United Nations initiative Cartooning For Peace.

talk: It's time to redesign medical data
speaker: Thomas Goetz
speaker_bio: Thomas Goetz is the co-founder of Iodine and author of "The Decision Tree: Taking Control of Your Health in the New Era of Personalized Medicine.”

talk: Understanding the rise of China
speaker: Martin Jacques
speaker_bio: Martin Jacques is the author of "When China Rules the World," and a columnist for the Guardian and New Statesman. He was a co-founder of the think tank Demos.

talk: Silicon-based comedy
speaker: Heather Knight
speaker_bio: Heather Knight runs Marilyn Monrobot, which creates socially intelligent robot performances and sensor-based electronic art. (and she helped build the amazing Rube Goldberg machine for OK Go’s “This Too Shall Pass.")

talk: Visualizing the medical data explosion
speaker: Anders Ynnerman
speaker_bio: Anders Ynnerman studies the fundamental aspects of computer graphics and visualization, in particular large scale and complex data sets with a focus on volume rendering and multi-modal interaction.

talk: The economic injustice of plastic
speaker: Van Jones
speaker_bio: Van Jones is the CEO of REFORM Alliance and a CNN political commentator.

talk: Singing after a double lung transplant
speaker: Charity Tillemann-Dick
speaker_bio: Charity Tillemann-Dick was a soprano who appeared on opera and concert stages around the world. Her roles included Titania in "A Midsummer's Night Dream," Gilda in "Rigoletto" and Violetta in "La Traviata."

talk: Addicted to risk
speaker: Naomi Klein
speaker_bio: Naomi Klein is a public intellectual, journalist and activist.

talk: Gaming to re-engage boys in learning
speaker: Ali Carr-Chellman
speaker_bio: Ali Carr-Chellman is an instructional designer and author who studies the most effective ways to teach kids and to make changes at school.

talk: Take "the Other" to lunch
speaker: Elizabeth Lesser
speaker_bio: Elizabeth Lesser helps her readers and students transform their lives after brushes with pain, adversity and life's myriad problems.

talk: How I built a toaster -- from scratch
speaker: Thomas Thwaites
speaker_bio: Thomas Thwaites is a designer "of a more speculative sort," he says.

talk: We are all cyborgs now
speaker: Amber Case
speaker_bio: Amber Case studies the symbiotic interactions between humans and machines -- and considers how our values and culture are being shaped by living lives increasingly mediated by high technology.

talk: A realistic vision for world peace
speaker: Jody Williams
speaker_bio: Jody Williams won a Nobel Peace Prize for her efforts to eradicate landmines. Now she’s teaming up with five other female peace laureates to empower women to fight violence, injustice and inequality.

talk: The 3 A's of awesome
speaker: Neil Pasricha
speaker_bio: Neil Pasricha is one of the world's leading authorities on intentional living.

talk: A test that finds 3x more breast tumors, and why it's not available to you
speaker: Deborah Rhodes
speaker_bio: Deborah Rhodes is an expert at managing breast-cancer risk. The director of the Mayo Clinic’s Executive Health Program is now testing a gamma camera that can see tumors that get missed by mammography.

talk: Your brain on improv
speaker: Charles Limb
speaker_bio: Charles Limb is a doctor and a musician who researches the way musical creativity works in the brain.

talk: On reading the Koran
speaker: Lesley Hazleton
speaker_bio: Writer, psychologist and former Middle East reporter Lesley Hazleton explores the vast and often terrifying arena in which politics and religion intersect.

talk: How to succeed? Get more sleep
speaker: Arianna Huffington
speaker_bio: Arianna Huffington is the co-founder and former editor-in-chief of The Huffington Post, a nationally syndicated columnist, and author of thirteen books. She is the co-host of “Left, Right & Center,” a political roundtable radio program.

talk: Using our practical wisdom
speaker: Barry Schwartz
speaker_bio: Barry Schwartz studies the link between economics and psychology, offering startling insights into modern life.

talk: The power of vulnerability
speaker: Brené Brown
speaker_bio: Dr. Brené Brown studies courage, vulnerability, shame and empathy.

talk: 3 stories of local eco-entrepreneurship
speaker: Majora Carter
speaker_bio: Majora Carter redefined the field of environmental equality, starting in the South Bronx at the turn of the century.  Now she is leading the local economic development movement across the USA.

talk: Why we have too few women leaders
speaker: Sheryl Sandberg
speaker_bio: As the COO at the helm of Facebook, Sheryl Sandberg juggles the tasks of monetizing the world’s largest social networking site while keeping its users happy and engaged.

talk: Life lessons from big cats
speaker: Beverly + Dereck Joubert
speaker_bio: Documentary filmmakers Beverly and Dereck Joubert have worked to conserve wildlife for more than 25 years. As National Geographic Explorers in Residence, the couple influences public policy and perceptions.

talk: The case for collaborative consumption
speaker: Rachel Botsman
speaker_bio: Rachel Botsman is a recognized expert on how collaboration and trust enabled by digital technologies will change the way we live, work, bank and consume.

talk: Let's talk parenting taboos
speaker: Rufus Griscom + Alisa Volkman
speaker_bio: Rufus Griscom and Alisa Volkman co-founded Babble, a website for parents. They have three sons.

talk: How to learn? From mistakes
speaker: Diana Laufenberg
speaker_bio: For over 15 years Diana has been a secondary social studies teacher in Wisconsin, Kansas, Arizona and Pennsylvania.

talk: New data on the rise of women
speaker: Hanna Rosin
speaker_bio: Hanna Rosin isn’t afraid to shine a skeptical spotlight on people’s cherished ideals, whether it’s politically correct dogma or the conservative Christian agenda.

talk: A police chief with a difference
speaker: Kiran Bedi
speaker_bio: Kiran Bedi was one of India's top cops -- tough, innovative and committed to social change. Now retired from the national police force, Bedi runs two NGOs that benefit rural and urban poor.

talk: A call to men
speaker: Tony Porter
speaker_bio: Tony Porter is an educator and activist who is internationally recognized for his effort to end violence against women.

talk: A feminine response to Iceland's financial crash
speaker: Halla Tómasdóttir
speaker_bio: Halla Tómasdóttir is the CEO of The B Team, a group of global leaders working together to transform business for a better world.

talk: A vision for sustainable restaurants
speaker: Arthur Potts Dawson
speaker_bio: Arthur Potts Dawson wants us to take responsibility not just for the food we eat, but how we shop for and even dispose of it. And he's showing the way -- with impeccable taste.

talk: How I taught rats to sniff out land mines
speaker: Bart Weetjens
speaker_bio: The founder of Apopo, Bart Weet­jens, is train­ing rats to detect landmine explosives in minute amounts.

talk: Why not eat insects?
speaker: Marcel Dicke
speaker_bio: Marcel Dicke wants us to reconsider our relationship with insects, promoting bugs as a tasty -- and ecologically sound -- alternative to meat in an increasingly hungry world.

talk: The walk from "no" to "yes"
speaker: William Ury
speaker_bio: William Ury is a mediator, writer and speaker, working with conflicts ranging from family feuds to boardroom battles to ethnic wars. He's the author of "Getting to Yes."

talk: What's wrong with our food system
speaker: Birke Baehr
speaker_bio: Birke Baehr wants us to know how our food is made, where it comes from, and what's in it. At age 11, he's planning a career as an organic farmer.

talk: Creative houses from reclaimed stuff
speaker: Dan Phillips
speaker_bio: Dan Phillips builds homes out of recycled and reclaimed materials in Huntsville, Texas.

talk: Why work doesn't happen at work
speaker: Jason Fried
speaker_bio: Jason Fried thinks deeply about collaboration, productivity and the nature of work. He's the co-founder of 37signals, makers of Basecamp and other web-based collaboration tools, and co-author of "Rework."

talk: Women, wartime and the dream of peace
speaker: Zainab Salbi
speaker_bio: Iraqi-born Zainab Salbi founded and runs Women for Women International, and has dedicated her life to helping women in war-torn regions rebuild their lives and communities.

talk: Protecting the brain against concussion
speaker: Kim Gorgens
speaker_bio: Kim Gorgens studies the brain's response to injury -- and advocates that we mind our (gray) matter.

talk: Making law on the high seas
speaker: Kristina Gjerde
speaker_bio: Kristina Gjerde is an expert on the law of the high seas -- the vast areas of the sea and seabed that exist beyond any national jurisdiction. These places belong to the world; Gjerde's work helps the world work together to protect them.

talk: My green school dream
speaker: John Hardy
speaker_bio: Jewelry designer John Hardy co-founded the extraordinary Green School in Bali, where kids get a holistic and green education.

talk: What a bike ride can teach you
speaker: Shimon Schocken
speaker_bio: Shimon Schocken is a computer science professor and dedicated educator.

talk: A Darwinian theory of beauty
speaker: Denis Dutton
speaker_bio: Denis Dutton was a philosophy professor and the editor of Arts & Letters Daily. In his book The Art Instinct, he suggested that humans are hard-wired to seek beauty.

talk: Teaching kids real math with computers
speaker: Conrad Wolfram
speaker_bio: Conrad Wolfram runs the worldwide arm of Wolfram Research, the mathematical lab behind the cutting-edge knowledge engine Wolfram Alpha.

talk: Simplifying complexity
speaker: Eric Berlow
speaker_bio: TED Senior Fellow Eric Berlow studies ecology and networks, exposing the interconnectedness of our ecosystems with climate change, government, corporations and more.

talk: Making global labor fair
speaker: Auret van Heerden
speaker_bio: At the head of the Fair Labor Association (FLA), Auret van Heerden takes a practical approach to workers' rights, persuading corporations and NGOs to protect labor in global supply chains.

talk: America's native prisoners of war
speaker: Aaron Huey
speaker_bio: Photographer, adventurer and storyteller Aaron Huey captures all of his subjects -- from war victims to rock climbers to Sufi dervishes -- with elegance and fearless sensitivity.

talk: The path to ending ethnic conflicts
speaker: Stefan Wolff
speaker_bio: Stefan Wolff studies contemporary conflicts, focusing on the prevention and settlement of ethnic conflicts and in postconflict reconstruction in deeply divided and war-torn societies.

talk: Teaching design for change
speaker: Emily Pilloton
speaker_bio: Emily Pilloton wants to give young people the tools to build the world they want to see.

talk: A one-man orchestra of the imagination
speaker: Andrew Bird
speaker_bio: Andrew Bird is a virtual one-man band -- he’s a singer and songwriter and plays the violin, guitar, glockenspiel.

talk: Re-engineering the brain
speaker: Gero Miesenboeck
speaker_bio: Using light and a little genetic engineering -- optogenetics -- Gero Miesenboeck has developed a way to control how living nerve cells work, and advanced understanding of how the brain controls behavior.

talk: Saving the ocean one island at a time
speaker: Greg Stone
speaker_bio: Greg Stone was a key driver in the establishment of the Phoenix Island Protected Area in the island nation of Kiribati. The second-largest marine protected area in the world -- and one of the most pristine -- PIPA is a laboratory for exploring and monitoring the recovery of coral reefs from bleaching events.

talk: E-voting without fraud
speaker: David Bismark
speaker_bio: David Bismark has co-developed an electronic voting system that contains a simple and reliable method of verification.

talk: 7 ways games reward the brain
speaker: Tom Chatfield
speaker_bio: Tom Chatfield thinks about games -- what we want from them, what we get from them, and how we might use our hard-wired desire for a gamer's reward to change the way we learn.

talk: Glorious visions in animation and performance
speaker: Miwa Matreyek
speaker_bio: Miwa Matreyek creates performances where real shapes and virtual images trade places, amid layers of animation, video and live bodies.

talk: Natural pest control ... using bugs!
speaker: Shimon Steinberg
speaker_bio: Shimon Steinberg's biotech lab researches ways to harness the natural benefits of insects on a massive scale.

talk: Sustainable seafood? Let's get smart
speaker: Barton Seaver
speaker_bio: Barton Seaver is an advocate of sustainable seafood and a chef in Washington DC. His work tells the story of our common resources through the communion we all share – dinner.

talk: Global power shifts
speaker: Joseph Nye
speaker_bio: The former assistant secretary of defense and former dean of Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, Joseph Nye offers sharp insights into the way nations take and cede power.

talk: Breakthrough designs for ultra-low-cost products
speaker: R.A. Mashelkar
speaker_bio: Using a principle he calls “convex lens leadership,” R.A. Mashelkar’s vision has catapulted india’s talent for science and innovation onto the international stage.

talk: "(Nothing But) Flowers" with string quartet
speaker: Thomas Dolby
speaker_bio: Thomas Dolby has spent his career at the intersection of music and technology. He was an early star on MTV, then moved to Silicon Valley, then went back on the road with his album, "A Map of the Floating City."

talk: The power of cartoons
speaker: Patrick Chappatte
speaker_bio: With simple lines and pointed jokes that skewer injustice, Patrick Chappatte's editorial cartoons view the tragic, the farcical and the absurd through a lens of unfettered humor.

talk: Tough truths about plastic pollution
speaker: Dianna Cohen
speaker_bio: Dianna Cohen co-founded the Plastic Pollution Coalition, which is working to help end our cycle of plastics use.

talk: The brain in your gut
speaker: Heribert Watzke
speaker_bio: Heribert Watzke studies the brain in our gut -- and works to develop new kinds of food that will satisfy our bodies and minds.

talk: Poverty, money -- and love
speaker: Jessica Jackley
speaker_bio: Jessica Jackley is the co-founder of Kiva.org, an online community that helps individuals loan small amounts of money, called microloans, to entrepreneurs throughout the world.

talk: My web playroom
speaker: Ze Frank
speaker_bio: Ze Frank has been involved in online comedy, web toys and virtually shared experiences for the past 20 years as an influencer, performer, executive and mischief maker.

talk: The art of the eco-mindshift
speaker: Natalie Jeremijenko
speaker_bio: Natalie Jeremijenko blends art, engineering, environmentalism, biochemistry and more to create real-life experiments that enable social change.

talk: When bad engineering makes a natural disaster even worse
speaker: Peter Haas
speaker_bio: Inveterate tinkerer Peter Haas is the co-founder of AIDG, the Appropriate Infrastructure Development Group, which connect people to electricity, sanitation and clean water through a combination of business incubation, education, and outreach.

talk: What nonprofits can learn from Coca-Cola
speaker: Melinda Gates
speaker_bio: Melinda French Gates is cochair of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, where she puts into practice the idea that every life has equal value.

talk: The roots of plant intelligence
speaker: Stefano Mancuso
speaker_bio: Stefano Mancuso is a founder of the study of plant neurobiology, which explores signaling and communication at all levels of biological organization, from genetics to molecules, cells and ecological communities.

talk: The best gift I ever survived
speaker: Stacey Kramer
speaker_bio: Stacey Kramer has traveled the United States and the world helping to create names and brands for growing companies.

talk: Tagging tuna in the deep ocean
speaker: Barbara Block
speaker_bio: Barbara Block studies how tuna, billfish and sharks move around (and stay warm) in the open ocean. Knowing how these large predators travel through pelagic waters will help us understand their role in the wider ocean ecosystem.

talk: An economic reality check
speaker: Tim Jackson
speaker_bio: Tim Jackson is a British ecological economist and professor for sustainable development at the University of Surrey. He is the author of "Prosperity without Growth" and director of the Centre for the Understanding of Sustainable Prosperity.

talk: Are mushrooms the new plastic?
speaker: Eben Bayer
speaker_bio: Eben Bayer is co-inventor of MycoBond, an organic (really -- it's based on mycelium, a living, growing organism) adhesive that turns agriwaste into a foam-like material for packaging and insulation.

talk: How Mr. Condom made Thailand a better place for life and love
speaker: Mechai Viravaidya
speaker_bio: Since 1974, Mechai Viravaidya has been creating and running innovative family planning and poverty reduction programs throughout Southeast Asia.

talk: Bringing peace to the minds of Afghanistan
speaker: Inge Missmahl
speaker_bio: By building psychosocial care into the primary health care system in Afghanistan, Inge Missmahl offers hope to a society traumatized by decades of conflict and insecurity.

talk: I am my connectome
speaker: Sebastian Seung
speaker_bio: Sebastian Seung is a leader in the new field of connectomics, currently the hottest space in neuroscience, which studies, in once-impossible detail, the wiring of the brain.

talk: The quantified self
speaker: Gary Wolf
speaker_bio: Journalist Gary Wolf spends his days in pursuit of the most fascinating things. As a contributing editor at Wired, he's written about technology, mushroom hunters, venture capitalists ...

talk: Shh! Sound health in 8 steps
speaker: Julian Treasure
speaker_bio: Julian Treasure studies sound and advises businesses on how best to use it.

talk: The shape-shifting future of the mobile phone
speaker: Fabian Hemmert
speaker_bio: Fabian Hemmert is a design professor, driven by the belief that we shouldn't sacrifice our humanness for the sake of technology.

talk: Why I am an HIV/AIDS activist
speaker: Annie Lennox
speaker_bio: The most successful female British pop musician in history, Annie Lennox has now committed herself to raising awareness of, and supporting actions against, the HIV/AIDS crisis in Africa.

talk: Mothers helping mothers fight HIV
speaker: Mitchell Besser
speaker_bio: How can mothers with HIV avoid passing it to their kids? In South Africa, Mitchell Besser tapped a new resource for healthcare: moms themselves. The program he started, mothers2mothers, trains new mothers to educate and support other moms.

talk: Where good ideas come from
speaker: Steven Johnson
speaker_bio: Steven Berlin Johnson examines the intersection of science, technology and personal experience.

talk: How pig parts make the world turn
speaker: Christien Meindertsma
speaker_bio: Christien Meindertsma uses art (and craft) to expose the hidden processes and connections of our modern life.

talk: Hurdy-gurdy for beginners
speaker: Caroline Phillips
speaker_bio: Caroline Phillips' rich, soprano voice conjures up the far-and-wide cultures of the world, especially the sound and language of the Basque Country.

talk: How social networks predict epidemics
speaker: Nicholas Christakis
speaker_bio: Nicholas Christakis explores how the large-scale, face-to-face social networks in which we are embedded affect our lives, and what we can do to take advantage of this fact.

talk: Our natural sleep cycle is nothing like what we do now
speaker: Jessa Gamble
speaker_bio: Jessa Gamble writes about sleep and time, showing how our internal body clock struggles against our always-on global culture.

talk: How web video powers global innovation
speaker: Chris Anderson
speaker_bio: After a long career in journalism and publishing, Chris Anderson became the curator of the TED Conference in 2002 and has developed it as a platform for identifying and disseminating ideas worth spreading.

talk: Discovering ancient climates in oceans and ice
speaker: Rob Dunbar
speaker_bio: Rob Dunbar looks deeply at ancient corals and sediments to study how the climate and the oceans have shifted over the past 50 to 12,000 years -- and how the Antarctic ecosystem is changing right now.

talk: Why the live arts matter
speaker: Ben Cameron
speaker_bio: Ben Cameron runs the arts granting program at the Doris Duke Foundation, focusing on live theater, dance and jazz.

talk: An independent diplomat
speaker: Carne Ross
speaker_bio: Carne Ross is the founder of Independent Diplomat, a nonprofit that offers freelance diplomatic representation to small, developing and yet-unrecognized nations in the complex world of international negotiations.

talk: Art of substance and absence
speaker: Alwar Balasubramaniam
speaker_bio: Sculptor, painter and printmaker Alwar Balasubramaniam makes work that crosses the boundary between art, perception and life.

talk: The child-driven education
speaker: Sugata Mitra
speaker_bio: Educational researcher Sugata Mitra is the winner of the 2013 TED Prize. His wish: Build a School in the Cloud, where children can explore and learn from one another.

talk: The world's oldest living things
speaker: Rachel Sussman
speaker_bio: Rachel Sussman is on a quest to celebrate the resilience of life by identifying and photographing continuous-living organisms that are 2,000 years or older, all around the world.

talk: The technology of the heart
speaker: His Holiness the Karmapa
speaker_bio: Ogyen Trinley Dorje is the 17th Gyalwang Karmapa, a revered figure in Tibetan Buddhism devoted to preserving and propagating Buddhist teachings.

talk: Let the environment guide our development
speaker: Johan Rockström
speaker_bio: Johan Rockström works to understand Earth resilience.

talk: The Happy Planet Index
speaker: Nic Marks
speaker_bio: Nic Marks gathers evidence about what makes us happy, and uses it to promote policy that puts the well-being of people and the planet first. He's the founder of the Centre for Well-Being at the UK think tank New Economics Foundation (NEF).

talk: What physics taught me about marketing
speaker: Dan Cobley
speaker_bio: Dan Cobley is a marketing director at Google, where he connects customers and businesses, helping both navigate digital space to find what they need.

talk: The political chemistry of oil
speaker: Lisa Margonelli
speaker_bio: Director of the New America Foundation Energy Policy Initiative, Lisa Margonelli writes about the global culture and economy of energy.

talk: Learning from Sherman the shark
speaker: Jim Toomey
speaker_bio: For the past 13 years, Jim Toomey has been writing and drawing the daily comic strip Sherman’s Lagoon, about a daffy family of ocean dwellers.

talk: Inside an Antarctic time machine
speaker: Robert Lee Hotz
speaker_bio: Robert Lee Hotz is the science columnist for the Wall Street Journal, where he writes about cutting-edge research on climate change, cosmology, molecular medicine, the human brain and much more ... He has traveled three times to the South Pole.

talk: The beauty of data visualization
speaker: David McCandless
speaker_bio: David McCandless draws beautiful conclusions from complex datasets -- thus revealing unexpected insights into our world.

talk: The game layer on top of the world
speaker: Seth Priebatsch
speaker_bio: "Proud Princeton dropout" Seth Priebatsch runs SCVNGR, a mobile start-up trying to build the game layer on top of the world.

talk: Did you hear the one about the Iranian-American?
speaker: Maz Jobrani
speaker_bio: A founding member of the Axis of Evil Comedy Tour, Iranian-American comedian Maz Jobrani is now touring with his second solo comedy show, Browner and Friendlier.

talk: The Axis of Evil Middle East Comedy Tour
speaker: Jamil Abu-Wardeh
speaker_bio: Jamil Abu-Wardeh believes in the community-building power of a shared laugh -- especially in Arabic. He jumpstarted the Dubai standup comedy scene and produced the Axis of Evil Middle East Comedy Tour.

talk: Meet Milo, the virtual boy
speaker: Peter Molyneux
speaker_bio: The head of Microsoft's European games division, Peter Molyneux is building an astonishing new "virtual friend" who interacts with you.

talk: Our century's greatest injustice
speaker: Sheryl WuDunn
speaker_bio: As a journalist reporting on China, Sheryl WuDunn saw the everyday oppression of women around the world. She and Nick Kristof wrote "Half the Sky," chronicling women's stories of horror and, especially, hope.

talk: How big brands can help save biodiversity
speaker: Jason Clay
speaker_bio: Jason Clay’s ideas are changing the way governments, foundations, researchers and NGOs identify and address risks and opportunities for their work.

talk: My mind-shifting Everest swim
speaker: Lewis Pugh
speaker_bio: Pushing his body through epic cold-water swims, Lewis Gordon Pugh wants to draw attention to our global climate. He's just back from swimming in a meltwater lake on the slopes of Mount Everest.

talk: A monkey economy as irrational as ours
speaker: Laurie Santos
speaker_bio: Laurie Santos studies primate psychology and monkeynomics -- testing problems in human psychology on primates, who (not so surprisingly) have many of the same predictable irrationalities we do.

talk: Wiring an interactive ocean
speaker: John Delaney
speaker_bio: John Delaney leads the team that is building a cabled network of deep-ocean sensors that will study, over time and space, the way the ocean's complex processes interact. By networking the ocean to gather data, he's helping to revolutionize ocean science.

talk: The oil spill's toxic trade-off
speaker: Susan Shaw
speaker_bio: Susan Shaw is an internationally recognized marine toxicologist, author and explorer.

talk: The art of choosing
speaker: Sheena Iyengar
speaker_bio: Sheena Iyengar studies how people choose (and what makes us think we're good at it).

talk: The bio-future of joint replacement
speaker: Kevin Stone
speaker_bio: Kevin Stone's clinic treats joint injury using the latest in bio-medicine: reconstructing damaged tissue, even replacing whole joint parts, with lab-grown cartilage and ligament.

talk: A headset that reads your brainwaves
speaker: Tan Le
speaker_bio: Tan Le is the founder & CEO of Emotiv, a bioinformatics company that's working on identifying biomarkers for mental and other neurological conditions using electroencephalography (EEG).

talk: Superheroes inspired by Islam
speaker: Naif Al-Mutawa
speaker_bio: Naif Al-Mutawa has created a group of comic superheroes based on Islamic culture and religion. They derive their superpowers from the 99 attributes of Allah.

talk: Why the world needs WikiLeaks
speaker: Julian Assange
speaker_bio: Julian Assange serves as spokesperson for WikiLeaks.

talk: The politics of fiction
speaker: Elif Shafak
speaker_bio: One of the most unique novelists in today's world literature, Elif Shafak's writing blends East and West, feminism and memory, the local and the global, bringing the periphery to the centre, giving voice to the voiceless and the disempowered.

talk: Listening to global voices
speaker: Ethan Zuckerman
speaker_bio: Ethan Zuckerman studies how the world -- the whole world -- uses new media to share information and moods across cultures, languages and platforms.

talk: The oil spill's unseen villains -- and victims
speaker: Carl Safina
speaker_bio: Carl Safina's writing explores the scientific, moral and social dimensions of our relationship with nature.

talk: Global population growth, box by box
speaker: Hans Rosling
speaker_bio: In Hans Rosling’s hands, data sings. Global trends in health and economics come to vivid life. And the big picture of global development -- with some surprisingly good news -- snaps into sharp focus.

talk: Life science in prison
speaker: Nalini Nadkarni
speaker_bio: Called "the queen of canopy research," Nalini Nadkarni explores the rich, vital world found in the tops of trees. She communicates what she finds to non-scientists -- with the help of poets, preachers and prisoners.

talk: Fractals and the art of roughness
speaker: Benoit Mandelbrot
speaker_bio: Benoit Mandelbrot's work led the world to a deeper understanding of fractals, a broad and powerful tool in the study of roughness, both in nature and in humanity's works.

talk: A 3D atlas of the universe
speaker: Carter Emmart
speaker_bio: Carter Emmart uses astronomy and computational modeling to create scientifically accurate, three-dimensional tours of our universe.

talk: Hidden toxins in the fish we eat
speaker: Stephen Palumbi
speaker_bio: Stephen Palumbi studies the way humanity and ocean life interact and intertwine. His insights into our codependence offer ideas for protecting both the ocean and ourselves.

talk: How cognitive surplus will change the world
speaker: Clay Shirky
speaker_bio: Clay Shirky argues that the history of the modern world could be rendered as the history of ways of arguing, where changes in media change what sort of arguments are possible -- with deep social and political implications.

talk: LEGO for grownups
speaker: Hillel Cooperman
speaker_bio: When Hillel Cooperman isn't running his startup or seeking out the world's best food, he's investigating the secret underground world of Lego toys.

talk: A second opinion on developmental disorders
speaker: Aditi Shankardass
speaker_bio: Aditi Shankardass is pioneering the use of EEG technology to give children with developmental disorders their most accurate diagnosis.

talk: Education innovation in the slums
speaker: Charles Leadbeater
speaker_bio: A researcher at the London think tank Demos, Charles Leadbeater was early to notice the rise of "amateur innovation" -- great ideas from outside the traditional walls, from people who suddenly have the tools to collaborate, innovate and make their expertise known.

talk: Intricate beauty by design
speaker: Marian Bantjes
speaker_bio: At the intersection of word and form, Marian Bantjes makes her art.

talk: Measuring what makes life worthwhile
speaker: Chip Conley
speaker_bio: Chip Conley disrupted the hospitality industry -- twice.

talk: Fighting cancer with dance
speaker: Ananda Shankar Jayant
speaker_bio: With precision and sparkling grace, Ananda Shankar Jayant performs and teaches the classical dance styles of Bharatanatyam and Kuchipudi.

talk: Let's raise kids to be entrepreneurs
speaker: Cameron Herold
speaker_bio: An entrepreneur since childhood, Cameron Herold wants parents and teachers to recognize -- and foster -- entrepreneurial talent in kids.

talk: The intriguing sound of marine mammals
speaker: Peter Tyack
speaker_bio: Peter Tyack studies the social behavior and acoustic communication in whales and dolphins, learning how these animals use sound to perform critical activities, such as mating and locating food.

talk: How YouTube thinks about copyright
speaker: Margaret Gould Stewart
speaker_bio: At Facebook (and previously at YouTube), Margaret Gould Stewart designs experiences that touch the lives of a large percentage of the world's population.

talk: The pattern behind self-deception
speaker: Michael Shermer
speaker_bio: Michael Shermer debunks myths, superstitions and urban legends -- and explains why we believe them. Along with publishing Skeptic Magazine, he's author of Why People Believe Weird Things and The Mind of the Market.

talk: How architecture helped music evolve
speaker: David Byrne
speaker_bio: David Byrne builds an idiosyncratic world of music, art, writing and film.

talk: Debate
speaker: Stewart Brand
speaker_bio: Since the counterculture '60s, Stewart Brand has been creating our internet-worked world. Now, with biotech accelerating four times faster than digital technology, Stewart Brand has a bold new plan ...

talk: Sweat the small stuff
speaker: Rory Sutherland
speaker_bio: Rory Sutherland stands at the center of an advertising revolution in brand identities, designing cutting-edge, interactive campaigns that blur the line between ad and entertainment.

talk: How poachers became caretakers
speaker: John Kasaona
speaker_bio: John Kasaona is a pioneer of community-based conservation -- working with the people who use and live on fragile land to enlist them in protecting it.

talk: The lost art of democratic debate
speaker: Michael Sandel
speaker_bio: Michael Sandel teaches political philosophy at Harvard, exploring the most hotly contested moral and political issues of our time.

talk: How to engineer a viral music video
speaker: Adam Sadowsky
speaker_bio: As the president of Syyn Labs, Adam Sadowsky merges art and technology to create interactive projects big and small.

talk: Why we need the explorers
speaker: Brian Cox
speaker_bio: Physicist Brian Cox has two jobs: working with the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, and explaining big science to the general public. He's a professor at the University of Manchester.

talk: The case for anonymity online
speaker: Christopher "moot" Poole
speaker_bio: Christopher "moot" Poole is founder of 4chan, an online imageboard whose anonymous denizens have spawned the web's most bewildering -- and influential -- subculture.

talk: The ocean's glory -- and horror
speaker: Brian Skerry
speaker_bio: Brian Skerry is a photojournalist who captures images that not only celebrate the mystery and beauty of the sea but also bring attention to the pressing issue which endanger our oceans.

talk: Pointing to the future of UI
speaker: John Underkoffler
speaker_bio: Remember the data interface from Minority Report? Well, it's real, John Underkoffler invented it -- as a point-and-touch interface called g-speak -- and it's about to change the way we interact with data.

talk: Re-examining the remix
speaker: Lawrence Lessig
speaker_bio: Lawrence Lessig has already transformed intellectual-property law with his Creative Commons innovation. Now he's focused on an even bigger problem: The US' broken political system.

talk: HIV and flu -- the vaccine strategy
speaker: Seth Berkley
speaker_bio: Epidemiologist Seth Berkley is leading the charge to make sure vaccines are available to everyone, including those living in the developing world.

talk: Inside a school for suicide bombers
speaker: Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy
speaker_bio: TED Fellow Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy seeks to push people to have difficult conversations about inequality and injustice.

talk: Lessons from fashion's free culture
speaker: Johanna Blakley
speaker_bio: Johanna Blakley studies the impact of mass media and entertainment on our world.

talk: Bring on the learning revolution!
speaker: Sir Ken Robinson
speaker_bio: Creativity expert Sir Ken Robinson challenged the way we educate our children, championing a radical rethink of how our school systems cultivate creativity and acknowledge multiple types of intelligence.

talk: Watch me unveil "synthetic life"
speaker: Craig Venter
speaker_bio: In 2001, Craig Venter made headlines for sequencing the human genome. In 2003, he started mapping the ocean's biodiversity. And now he's created the first synthetic lifeforms -- microorganisms that can produce alternative fuels.

talk: Planning for the end of oil
speaker: Richard Sears
speaker_bio: Richard Sears thinks hard about the post-oil world. He's a visiting scientist at MIT, after a long career as a VP at Shell.

talk: Pay attention to penguins
speaker: Dee Boersma
speaker_bio: Dee Boersma considers penguins ocean sentinels, helping us understand the effects of pollution, overfishing and climate change on the marine environment.

talk: Why I'm a weekday vegetarian
speaker: Graham Hill
speaker_bio: Graham Hill is the founder of TreeHugger.com and LifeEdited; he travels the world to tell stories of sustainability and minimalism. He tweets at @GHill.

talk: Can we eat to starve cancer?
speaker: William Li
speaker_bio: William Li heads the Angiogenesis Foundation, a nonprofit that is re-conceptualizing global disease fighting.

talk: It's time for "The Talk"
speaker: Julia Sweeney
speaker_bio: Julia Sweeney creates comedic works that tackle deep issues like cancer, family and faith.

talk: Math class needs a makeover
speaker: Dan Meyer
speaker_bio: Dan Meyer is exploring the way we teach teachers to teach kids.

talk: Glimpses of a pristine ocean
speaker: Enric Sala
speaker_bio: Dr. Enric Sala is a former university professor who saw himself writing the obituary of ocean life and quit academia to become a full-time conservationist as a National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence.

talk: Could this laser zap malaria?
speaker: Nathan Myhrvold
speaker_bio: Nathan Myhrvold is a professional jack-of-all-trades. After leaving Microsoft in 1999, he's been a world barbecue champion, a wildlife photographer, a chef, a contributor to SETI, and a volcano explorer.

talk: The hidden influence of social networks
speaker: Nicholas Christakis
speaker_bio: Nicholas Christakis explores how the large-scale, face-to-face social networks in which we are embedded affect our lives, and what we can do to take advantage of this fact.

talk: "Love Is a Loaded Pistol"
speaker: Thomas Dolby
speaker_bio: Thomas Dolby has spent his career at the intersection of music and technology. He was an early star on MTV, then moved to Silicon Valley, then went back on the road with his album, "A Map of the Floating City."

talk: India's hidden hotbeds of invention
speaker: Anil Gupta
speaker_bio: Anil Gupta created the Honey Bee Network to support grassroots innovators who are rich in knowledge, but not in resources.

talk: How we wrecked the ocean
speaker: Jeremy Jackson
speaker_bio: A leader in the study of the ecology and evolution of marine organisms, Jeremy Jackson  is known for his deep understanding of geological time.

talk: How great leaders inspire action
speaker: Simon Sinek
speaker_bio: Simon Sinek explores how leaders can inspire cooperation, trust and change. He's the author of the classic "Start With Why"; his latest book is "Leaders Eat Last."

talk: Social experiments to fight poverty
speaker: Esther Duflo
speaker_bio: Esther Duflo takes economics out of the lab and into the field to discover the causes of poverty and means to eradicate it.

talk: Lies, damned lies and statistics (about TEDTalks)
speaker: Sebastian Wernicke
speaker_bio: After making a splash in the field of bioinformatics, Sebastian Wernicke moved on to the corporate sphere, where he motivates and manages multidimensional projects.

talk: Toward a science of simplicity
speaker: George Whitesides
speaker_bio: In his legendary career in chemistry, George Whitesides has been a pioneer in microfabrication and nanoscale self-assembly. Now, he's fabbing a diagnostic lab on a chip.

talk: Why I'm rowing across the Pacific
speaker: Roz Savage
speaker_bio: Roz Savage gave up her life as a management consultant to row across the Atlantic in 2005. Her mission now is to row across the Pacific, from the West Coast to Australia, raising awareness along the way of plastic pollution, climate change and eco-heroism.

talk: Computing a theory of all knowledge
speaker: Stephen Wolfram
speaker_bio: Stephen Wolfram is the creator of Mathematica and Wolfram|Alpha, the author of A New Kind of Science, and the founder and CEO of Wolfram Research.

talk: Radical women, embracing tradition
speaker: Kavita Ramdas
speaker_bio: Kavita Ramdas directs the Global Fund for Women, the largest foundation in the world supporting women's human rights across all borders.

talk: Political change with pen and paper
speaker: Omar Ahmad
speaker_bio: An internet infrastructure maven and activist, Omar Ahmad was the mayor of San Carlos, California.

talk: Build a tower, build a team
speaker: Tom Wujec
speaker_bio: Tom Wujec studies how we share and absorb information. He's an innovative practitioner of business visualization -- using design and technology to help groups solve problems and understand ideas. He is a Fellow at Autodesk.

talk: Bio-lab on a microchip
speaker: Frederick Balagadde
speaker_bio: TED Senior Fellow Frederick Balagadde invented the micro-chemostat, a first-of-its-kind, dime-sized piece of transparent plastic that can orchestrate the behavior of living cells.

talk: Homeopathy, quackery and fraud
speaker: James Randi
speaker_bio: Legendary skeptic James Randi devoted his life to debunking frauds and investigating paranormal and pseudoscientific claims.

talk: Glowing life in an underwater world
speaker: Edith Widder
speaker_bio: Edith Widder combines her expertise in research and technological innovation with a commitment to stopping and reversing the degradation of our marine environment.

talk: How art gives shape to cultural change
speaker: Thelma Golden
speaker_bio: Opening minds and showcasing new voices -- it's all part of the job description for Studio Museum in Harlem director and chief curator Thelma Golden.

talk: The tradeoffs of building green
speaker: Catherine Mohr
speaker_bio: Catherine Mohr loves what she does -- she's just not ever sure what it will be next.

talk: Photos that changed the world
speaker: Jonathan Klein
speaker_bio: Jonathan Klein runs Getty Images, a stock photo agency whose vast archive of still photography and illustrations is a mainstay of the creative class.

talk: The danger of science denial
speaker: Michael Specter
speaker_bio: Michael Specter is a staff writer for the New Yorker. His new book, Denialism, asks why we have increasingly begun to fear scientific advances instead of embracing them.

talk: Singing old poems to life
speaker: Natalie Merchant
speaker_bio: Natalie Merchant's career spans three decades -- as the leader of 10,000 Maniacs and in her own solo work -- of making warmly personal music.

talk: Every pollen grain has a story
speaker: Jonathan Drori
speaker_bio: Jonathan Drori commissioned the BBC's very first websites, one highlight in a long career devoted to online culture and educational media -- and understanding how we learn.

talk: My seven species of robot -- and how we created them
speaker: Dennis Hong
speaker_bio: Dennis Hong is the founder and director of RoMeLa -- a Virginia Tech robotics lab that has pioneered several breakthroughs in robot design and engineering.

talk: The emotion behind invention
speaker: Dean Kamen
speaker_bio: Dean Kamen landed in the limelight with the Segway, but he has been innovating since high school, with more than 150 patents under his belt. Recent projects include portable energy and water purification for the developing world, and a prosthetic arm for maimed soldiers.

talk: Sex, drugs and HIV -- let's get rational
speaker: Elizabeth Pisani
speaker_bio: In Elizabeth Pisani's latest book, she explores the "improbable nation" of Indonesia.

talk: What adults can learn from kids
speaker: Adora Svitak
speaker_bio: A prolific short story writer and blogger since age seven, Adora Svitak (now 12) speaks around the United States to adults and children as an advocate for literacy.

talk: How to start a movement
speaker: Derek Sivers
speaker_bio: Through his new project, MuckWork, Derek Sivers wants to lessen the burdens (and boredom) of creative people.

talk: And now, the real news
speaker: Kirk Citron
speaker_bio: Kirk Citron began his career as a fast-rising advertising executive, but now writes and provides media consultation for select non-profits.

talk: Teaching one child at a time
speaker: Shukla Bose
speaker_bio: Shukla Bose is the founder and head of the Parikrma Humanity Foundation, a nonprofit that runs four extraordinary schools for poor children.

talk: How to combat modern slavery
speaker: Kevin Bales
speaker_bio: Kevin Bales is the co-founder of Free the Slaves, whose mission is to end all forms of human slavery within the next 25 years. He's the author of "Ending Slavery: How We Free Today's Slaves."

talk: Music is medicine, music is sanity
speaker: Robert Gupta
speaker_bio: Violinist Robert Gupta joined the LA Philharmonic at the age of 19 -- and maintains a passionate parallel interest in neurobiology and mental health issues. He's a TED Senior Fellow.

talk: Why we need to go back to Mars
speaker: Joel Levine
speaker_bio: Joel Levine studies the atmospheres of Earth and Mars, looking at their origin, evolution, structure and chemistry and climate change. He's the principal investigator of the proposed ARES Mars Airplane Mission.

talk: Let's simplify legal jargon!
speaker: Alan Siegel
