speaker_bio: A branding expert and one of the leading authorities on business communication, Alan Siegel wants to put plain English into legal documents for government and business.

talk: The fight to end rare-animal trafficking in Brazil
speaker: Juliana Machado Ferreira
speaker_bio: Brazilian-born biologist Juliana Machado Ferreira wants, simply, to save the world one bird at a time. She is a TED Senior Fellow.

talk: We are the stories we tell ourselves
speaker: Shekhar Kapur
speaker_bio: Shekhar Kapur is a visionary filmmaker and storyteller who works at the intersection of art, myth and activism.

talk: Medical miracle on Everest
speaker: Ken Kamler
speaker_bio: Ken Kamler has served as doctor on some of the world’s most daring expeditions, but also performs delicate microsurgery when at home in New York.

talk: Gaming can make a better world
speaker: Jane McGonigal
speaker_bio: Reality is broken, says Jane McGonigal, and we need to make it work more like a game. Her work shows us how.

talk: Take health care off the mainframe
speaker: Eric Dishman
speaker_bio: Eric Dishman does health care research for Intel -- studying how new technology can solve big problems in the system for the sick, the aging and, well, all of us.

talk: Suspended animation is within our grasp
speaker: Mark Roth
speaker_bio: Mark Roth's research has reawakened an unusual notion from the annals of science: reversible metabolic hibernation. Yes, putting living organisms into suspended animation -- and bringing them back safely.

talk: The magic of the placebo
speaker: Eric Mead
speaker_bio: Eric Mead is a prolific magician, mentalist and comedian who worked his way up from doing magic on the street to appearing at exclusive events around the world.

talk: How I fell in love with a fish
speaker: Dan Barber
speaker_bio: Dan Barber is a chef and a scholar -- relentlessly pursuing the stories and reasons behind the foods we grow and eat.

talk: Take Turns
speaker: Gary Lauder
speaker_bio: Gary Lauder is the managing partner of Lauder Partners, a VC firm, and the co-creator of the Socrates Society at the Aspen Institute.

talk: The year open data went worldwide
speaker: Tim Berners-Lee
speaker_bio: Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web. He leads the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), overseeing the Web's standards and development.

talk: Plug into your hard-wired happiness
speaker: Srikumar Rao
speaker_bio: Executive, educator, writer and life coach Srikumar S. Rao asks, "Are you ready to succeed?" -- and in his famous course "Creativity and Personal Mastery," he teaches his students how to do so.

talk: In the Internet age, dance evolves ...
speaker: The LXD
speaker_bio: The LXD (the Legion of Extraordinary Dancers) are building an interactive web series that represents the next evolution of dance.

talk: Before Avatar ... a curious boy
speaker: James Cameron
speaker_bio: James Cameron is the director of Avatar, Titanic, Terminator, The Abyss and many other blockbusters. While his outsize films push the bounds of technology, they're always anchored in human stories with heart and soul.

talk: Is Pivot a turning point for web exploration?
speaker: Gary Flake
speaker_bio: Gary Flake is a Technical Fellow at Microsoft, and the founder and director of Live Labs.

talk: The rise of cricket, the rise of India
speaker: Harsha Bhogle
speaker_bio: Harsha Bhogle can talk about the business side of cricket, the technicalities of play and the psychology of the players with equal authority.

talk: The riddle of experience vs. memory
speaker: Daniel Kahneman
speaker_bio: Widely regarded as the world's most influential living psychologist, Daniel Kahneman won the Nobel in Economics for his pioneering work in behavioral economics -- exploring the irrational ways we make decisions about risk.

talk: My 5 lives as an artist
speaker: Raghava KK
speaker_bio: Raghava KK's paintings and drawings use cartoonish shapes and colors to examine the body, society, our world.

talk: How brains learn to see
speaker: Pawan Sinha
speaker_bio: Pawan Sinha researches how our brains interpret what our eyes see -- and uses that research to give blind children the gift of sight.

talk: The world needs all kinds of minds
speaker: Temple Grandin
speaker_bio: Through groundbreaking research and the lens of her own autism, Temple Grandin brings startling insight into two worlds.

talk: The wireless future of medicine
speaker: Eric Topol
speaker_bio: Eric Topol is a leading cardiologist who has embraced the study of genomics and the latest advances in technology to treat chronic disease.

talk: Four ways to fix a broken legal system
speaker: Philip K. Howard
speaker_bio: Philip K. Howard is the founder of Common Good, a drive to overhaul the US legal system. His new book is "Try Common Sense."

talk: Technology's epic story
speaker: Kevin Kelly
speaker_bio: There may be no one better to contemplate the meaning of cultural change than Kevin Kelly, whose life story reads like a treatise on the value and impacts of technology.

talk: Innovating to zero!
speaker: Bill Gates
speaker_bio: A passionate tech visionary, Bill Gates changed the world while leading Microsoft to dizzying success. Now he's doing it again through his global philanthropic work that strives to reduce inequity everywhere.

talk: The opportunity of adversity
speaker: Aimee Mullins
speaker_bio: A record-breaker at the Paralympic Games in 1996, Aimee Mullins has built a career as a model, actor and advocate for women, sports and the next generation of prosthetics.

talk: The next age of government
speaker: David Cameron
speaker_bio: David Cameron is the prime minister of the UK and the leader of the UK's Conservative Party.

talk: Augmented-reality maps
speaker: Blaise Agüera y Arcas
speaker_bio: Blaise Agüera y Arcas works on machine learning at Google. Previously a Distinguished Engineer at Microsoft, he has worked on augmented reality, mapping, wearable computing and natural user interfaces.

talk: Teach every child about food
speaker: Jamie Oliver
speaker_bio: Jamie Oliver is transforming the way we feed ourselves, and our children. The winner of the 2010 TED Prize, he's on a mission to teach every family about eating better and living healthier lives.

talk: How to expose the corrupt
speaker: Peter Eigen
speaker_bio: As a director of the World Bank in Nairobi, Peter Eigen saw firsthand how devastating corruption can be. He's founder of Transparency International, an NGO that works to persuade international companies not to bribe.

talk: The painter and the pendulum
speaker: Tom Shannon
speaker_bio: Tom Shannon's mixed-material sculpture seems to levitate -- often it actually does -- thanks to powerful magnets and clever arrangements of suspension wire. He designed the TED Prize trophy.

talk: A new strategy in the war on cancer
speaker: David Agus
speaker_bio: Although a highly-accomplished conventional doctor, David Agus has embraced the future of medicine and is constantly exploring ways that new technologies can help in the fight against cancer.

talk: A lab the size of a postage stamp
speaker: George Whitesides
speaker_bio: In his legendary career in chemistry, George Whitesides has been a pioneer in microfabrication and nanoscale self-assembly. Now, he's fabbing a diagnostic lab on a chip.

talk: The big idea my brother inspired
speaker: Jamie Heywood
speaker_bio: When MIT-trained mechanical engineer Jamie Heywood discovered that his younger brother was diagnosed with the terminal illness ALS, he focused all his energy on founding revolutionary healthcare initiatives to help his brother and others like him.

talk: Solving social problems with a nudge
speaker: Sendhil Mullainathan
speaker_bio: Sendhil Mullainathan asks a compelling question: what are the irrational choices we make that perpetuate poverty, corruption, discrimination?

talk: Weird, or just different?
speaker: Derek Sivers
speaker_bio: Through his new project, MuckWork, Derek Sivers wants to lessen the burdens (and boredom) of creative people.

talk: A warm embrace that saves lives
speaker: Jane Chen
speaker_bio: TED Fellow Jane Chen has spent years working on health issues in the developing world.

talk: Embrace your inner girl
speaker: Eve Ensler
speaker_bio: Eve Ensler created the groundbreaking "Vagina Monologues," whose success propelled her to found V-Day -- a movement to end violence against women and girls everywhere.

talk: Building a theater that remakes itself
speaker: Joshua Prince-Ramus
speaker_bio: Joshua Prince-Ramus is best known as architect of the Seattle Central Library, already being hailed as a masterpiece of contemporary culture. Prince-Ramus was the founding partner of OMA New York—the American affiliate of the Office for Metropolitan Architecture (OMA) in the Netherlands—and served as its Principal until he renamed the firm REX in 2006.

talk: Your health depends on where you live
speaker: Bill Davenhall
speaker_bio: Bill Davenhall wants to improve physicians' diagnostic techniques by collecting each patient's geographic and environmental data, and merging it with their medical records.

talk: Growing new organs
speaker: Anthony Atala
speaker_bio: Anthony Atala asks, "Can we grow organs instead of transplanting them?" His lab at the Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine is doing just that -- engineering over 30 tissues and whole organs.

talk: 10 young Indian artists to watch
speaker: Ravin Agrawal
speaker_bio: As an emerging markets investor, Ravin Agrawal tries to predict the future, balancing economic, political and technological factors.

talk: How I held my breath for 17 minutes
speaker: David Blaine
speaker_bio: With a deck of cards and authoritative cool, David Blaine brings the wonderment of magic off the stage and onto the sidewalk.

talk: All things are Moleeds
speaker: Charles Fleischer
speaker_bio: Best known as the voice of Roger Rabbit, Charles Fleischer's multi-decade career includes work on stage and on screen, and an online emporium of unusual observations called MonkeyDog.

talk: Making maps to fight disaster, build economies
speaker: Lalitesh Katragadda
speaker_bio: Lalitesh Katragadda builds tools that help groups of people compile information to build something greater than the sum of its parts. His latest fascination: collaborative maps.

talk: Kids, take charge
speaker: Kiran Sethi
speaker_bio: The founder of the Riverside School in Ahmedabad, Kiran Sethi has launched an initiative to make our cities more child-friendly.

talk: How we rescued the "dancing bears"
speaker: Kartick Satyanarayan
speaker_bio: Kartick Satyanarayan works tirelessly to save India’s wild animals from illegal captivity and poaching -- most notably rescuing hundreds of “dancing” bears.

talk: An all-star set
speaker: Herbie Hancock
speaker_bio: Herbie Hancock is an iconic jazz musician, known as much for his mastery of the traditional as he is for entirely changing the game.

talk: The real danger lurking in the water
speaker: Romulus Whitaker
speaker_bio: Romulus Whitaker is a scientist and conservationist who slings around the globe to study and protect reptiles.

talk: How to live to be 100+
speaker: Dan Buettner
speaker_bio: National Geographic writer and explorer Dan Buettner studies the world's longest-lived peoples, distilling their secrets into a single plan for health and long life.

talk: Exposing the invisible
speaker: Nick Veasey
speaker_bio: Logging countless hours behind an X-ray machine, Nick Veasey illuminates the labyrinthine secrets hidden beneath the exteriors of everyday objects.

talk: The neurons that shaped civilization
speaker: Vilayanur Ramachandran
speaker_bio: Neurologist V.S. Ramachandran looks deep into the brain’s most basic mechanisms. By working with those who have very specific mental disabilities caused by brain injury or stroke, he can map functions of the mind to physical structures of the brain.

talk: My solar-powered adventure
speaker: Bertrand Piccard
speaker_bio: Bertrand Piccard circumnavigated the Earth in a hot-air balloon. Now he wants to circle it in an airplane powered only by solar energy.

talk: My message of peace from Pakistan
speaker: Asher Hasan
speaker_bio: Asher Hasan's social enterprise Naya Jeevan (the name means "new life" in Urdu and Hindi) is the emerging world's first HMO for the urban, working poor.

talk: Fusion is energy's future
speaker: Steven Cowley
speaker_bio: Steven Cowley directs the UK's leading fusion research center. Soon he'll helm new experiments that may make cheap fusion energy real on a commercial scale.

talk: A new way to fight corruption
speaker: Shaffi Mather
speaker_bio: Shaffi Mather is the founder of 1298 for Ambulance, Education Access for All, and co-promoter of Moksha-Yug Access.

talk: Metaphorically speaking
speaker: James Geary
speaker_bio: Lost jobs, wayward lovers, wars and famine -- come to think of it, just about any of life's curveballs -- there's an aphorism for it, and James Geary's got it.

talk: Dragonflies that fly across oceans
speaker: Charles Anderson
speaker_bio: Charles Anderson studies marine life in the Maldives, a nation of coral atolls in the Indian ocean.

talk: How to make a splash in social media
speaker: Alexis Ohanian
speaker_bio: Alexis Ohanian is the co-founder an executive chairman of Reddit, a social-voting news website with geek allegiances, a small-town feel and a penchant for lighting up the memes your friends IM you about next week.

talk: Photographing the hidden story
speaker: Ryan Lobo
speaker_bio: As a photographer and filmmaker, Ryan Lobo uses his exquisite lens to capture humanity and nature at their most open and vulnerable moments.

talk: The intricate economics of terrorism
speaker: Loretta Napoleoni
speaker_bio: She made her name following the dollars in terrorist networks, but now Loretta Napoleoni is on the trail of something far more sinister -- the gray zone where crime and unregulated credit meet.

talk: Pop culture in the Arab world
speaker: Shereen El Feki
speaker_bio: Shereen El Feki works and writes on sexuality and social change in the Arab world.

talk: How low-cost eye care can be world-class
speaker: Thulasiraj Ravilla
speaker_bio: Thulasiraj Ravilla is the executive director of the Lions Aravind Institute of Community Ophthalmology, helping eye-care hospitals around the world build capacity to prevent blindness.

talk: The art of the interview
speaker: Marc Pachter
speaker_bio: Marc Pachter has spent his career curating and creating intimate portraits of the lives of others.

talk: A one-man world summit
speaker: Rory Bremner
speaker_bio: One of the UK's sharpest funny men, Rory Bremner exposes the lunacies of modern politics with devilishly clever political satire and spot-on impressions of leaders from around the world.

talk: The fight against sex slavery
speaker: Sunitha Krishnan
speaker_bio: Sunitha Krishnan is galvanizing India’s battle against sexual slavery by uniting government, corporations and NGOs to end human trafficking.

talk: The art of puzzles
speaker: Scott Kim
speaker_bio: Scott Kim designs puzzles in the spirit of MC Escher's art and Tetris -- visually stimulating, thought provoking and suffused with broad appeal.

talk: The ancient ingenuity of water harvesting
speaker: Anupam Mishra
speaker_bio: To promote smart water management, Anupam Mishra works to preserve rural India’s traditional rainwater harvesting techniques.

talk: The hunt for a supermassive black hole
speaker: Andrea Ghez
speaker_bio: Andrea Ghez is a stargazing detective, tracking the visible and invisible forces lurking in the vastness of interstellar space.

talk: Global ethic vs. national interest
speaker: Gordon Brown
speaker_bio: Britain's former prime minister Gordon Brown played a key role in shaping the G20 nations' response to the world's financial crisis, and was a powerful advocate for a coordinated global response to problems such as climate change, poverty and social justice.

talk: Why nations should pursue soft power
speaker: Shashi Tharoor
speaker_bio: After a long career at the UN, and a parallel life as a novelist, Shashi Tharoor became a member of India's Parliament. He spent 10 months as India's Minister for External Affairs, building connections between India and the world.

talk: Dance to change the world
speaker: Mallika Sarabhai
speaker_bio: As the leader of Darpana, Mallika Sarabhai is a pioneer in using dance and the arts for social change.

talk: Turning dunes into architecture
speaker: Magnus Larsson
speaker_bio: Magnus Larsson hopes to build new structures in the desert --  by using bacteria to turn shifting sand into a solid mass.

talk: Transition to a world without oil
speaker: Rob Hopkins
speaker_bio: Rob Hopkins is the founder of the Transition movement, a radically hopeful and community-driven approach to creating societies independent of fossil fuel.

talk: Asia's rise -- how and when
speaker: Hans Rosling
speaker_bio: In Hans Rosling’s hands, data sings. Global trends in health and economics come to vivid life. And the big picture of global development -- with some surprisingly good news -- snaps into sharp focus.

talk: Learn to use the 13th-century astrolabe
speaker: Tom Wujec
speaker_bio: Tom Wujec studies how we share and absorb information. He's an innovative practitioner of business visualization -- using design and technology to help groups solve problems and understand ideas. He is a Fellow at Autodesk.

talk: East vs. West -- the myths that mystify
speaker: Devdutt Pattanaik
speaker_bio: Devdutt Pattanaik looks at business and modern life through the lens of mythology.

talk: Learning from leadership's missing manual
speaker: Fields Wicker-Miurin
speaker_bio: Fields Wicker-Miurin wants to improve the quality and impact of leadership worldwide by discovering leaders in unique, local settings and connecting them with one another.

talk: Science-inspired design
speaker: Mathieu Lehanneur
speaker_bio: Kitchen-sized fish farms, living air purifiers and devices that turn old water bottles into martini shakers all spring from the form-and-function-fusing mind of designer Mathieu Lehanneur.

talk: The thrilling potential of SixthSense technology
speaker: Pranav Mistry
speaker_occ: Director of research, Samsung Research America
speaker_bio: As an MIT grad student, Pranav Mistry invented SixthSense, a wearable device that enables new interactions between the real world and the world of data.

talk: The surprising spread of Idol TV
speaker: Cynthia Schneider
speaker_bio: Cynthia Schneider studies culture and politics -- watching how novels, TV shows and cultural engagement around the globe (and especially within the Muslim world) might lead to political change. She was the US ambassador to the Netherlands from 1998 to 2001.

talk: Photographing the landscape of oil
speaker: Edward Burtynsky
speaker_bio: 2005 TED Prize winner Edward Burtynsky has made it his life's work to document humanity's impact on the planet. His riveting photographs, as beautiful as they are horrifying, capture views of the Earth altered by mankind.

talk: The science behind a climate headline
speaker: Rachel Pike
speaker_bio: Rachel Pike studies climate change at the molecular level -- tracking how emissions from biofuel crops react with the air to shape weather trends globally.

talk: The refugees of boom-and-bust
speaker: Cameron Sinclair
speaker_bio: 2006 TED Prize winner Cameron Sinclair is co-founder of Architecture for Humanity, a nonprofit that seeks architecture solutions to global crises -- and acts as a conduit between the design community and the world's humanitarian needs.

talk: How the Internet enables intimacy
speaker: Stefana Broadbent
speaker_bio: Stefana Broadbent watches us while we communicate, work and go about our daily lives. She is one of a new class of ethnographers who study the way our social habits and relationships function and mutate in the digital age.

talk: Symmetry, reality's riddle
speaker: Marcus du Sautoy
speaker_bio: Oxford's newest science ambassador Marcus du Sautoy is also author of The Times' Sexy Maths column. He'll take you footballing with prime numbers, whopping symmetry groups, higher dimensions and other brow-furrowers.

talk: The year I was homeless
speaker: Becky Blanton
speaker_bio: Becky Blanton is a writer, photographer and former journalist who found herself homeless, but bounced back to tell her story and inspire others.

talk: Architecture that repairs itself?
speaker: Rachel Armstrong
speaker_bio: TED Fellow Rachel Armstrong is a sustainability innovator who creates new materials that possess some of the properties of living systems, and can be manipulated to "grow" architecture.

talk: A new way to explain explanation
speaker: David Deutsch
speaker_bio: A pioneer in quantum computation and quantum information theory, David Deutsch now seeks to define the boundaries between the possible and the impossible.

talk: Navigating our global future
speaker: Ian Goldin
speaker_bio: Ian Goldin brings fresh thinking to bear on the big, looming issues of the future.

talk: 1.3m reasons to re-invent the syringe
speaker: Marc Koska
speaker_bio: Marc Koska wants to improve health care in the developing world by re-designing dangerous medical tools -- and offering education to practitioners in under-funded clinics.

talk: Lead like the great conductors
speaker: Itay Talgam
speaker_bio: After a decade-long conducting career in his native Israel, Itay Talgam has reinvented himself as a "conductor of people" -- in government, academia, business and education. He is the author of The Ignorant Maestro.

talk: Animating a photo-real digital face
speaker: Paul Debevec
speaker_bio: Paul Debevec's digital inventions have powered the breathtaking visual effects in films like The Matrix, Superman Returns, King Kong and The Curious Case of Benjamin Button.

talk: The post-crisis consumer
speaker: John Gerzema
speaker_bio: John Gerzema uses data, analysis and decades of experience to identify trends and develop daring new approaches to advertising.

talk: The 4 ways sound affects us
speaker: Julian Treasure
speaker_bio: Julian Treasure studies sound and advises businesses on how best to use it.

talk: A brain in a supercomputer
speaker: Henry Markram
speaker_bio: Henry Markram is director of Blue Brain, a supercomputing project that can model components of the mammalian brain to precise cellular detail -- and simulate their activity in 3D. Soon he'll simulate a whole rat brain in real time.

talk: Life lessons from an ad man
speaker: Rory Sutherland
speaker_bio: Rory Sutherland stands at the center of an advertising revolution in brand identities, designing cutting-edge, interactive campaigns that blur the line between ad and entertainment.

talk: Robots that "show emotion"
speaker: David Hanson
speaker_bio: David Hanson merges robotics and art to design life-like, social robots that can mimic human expression and emotion.

talk: New York -- before the City
speaker: Eric Sanderson
speaker_bio: Armed with an 18th-century map, a GPS and reams of data, Eric Sanderson has re-plotted the Manhattan of 1609, just in time for New York's quadricentennial.

talk: Claim your "manspace"
speaker: Sam Martin
speaker_bio: Sam Martin is the director of digital strategy at Texas Monthly magazine, and the author of "Manspace: A Primal Guide to Marking Your Territory."

talk: Optical illusions show how we see
speaker: Beau Lotto
speaker_bio: Beau Lotto seeks to pull aside the curtain of why we see what we do in order to create the possibility and agency in deciding what to perceive next.

talk: The danger of a single story
speaker: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
speaker_bio: Inspired by Nigerian history and tragedies all but forgotten by recent generations of westerners, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie’s novels and stories are jewels in the crown of diasporan literature.

talk: Tribal leadership
speaker: David Logan
speaker_bio: David Logan is a USC faculty member, best-selling author, and management consultant.

talk: How food shapes our cities
speaker: Carolyn Steel
speaker_bio: Food is a shared necessity -- but also a shared way of thinking, argues Carolyn Steel. Looking at food networks offers an unusual and illuminating way to explore how cities evolved.

talk: The power of time off
speaker: Stefan Sagmeister
speaker_bio: Renowned for album covers, posters and his recent book of life lessons, designer Stefan Sagmeister invariably has a slightly different way of looking at things.

talk: How spectroscopy could reveal alien life
speaker: Garik Israelian
speaker_bio: Garik Israelian's stargazing on the Canary Islands has led to high-profile discoveries about space's big disasters -- including the first evidence that supernova explosions make black holes.

talk: Let's revive the Golden Rule
speaker: Karen Armstrong
speaker_bio: Karen Armstrong -- winner of the 2008 TED Prize -- is a provocative, original thinker on the role of religion in the modern world.

talk: Mapping the future of countries
speaker: Parag Khanna
speaker_bio: Geopolitical futurist Parag Khanna foresees a world in which megacities, supply chains and connective technologies redraw the map away from states and borders.

talk: A third way to think about aid
speaker: Jacqueline Novogratz
speaker_bio: Jacqueline Novogratz works to enable human flourishing. Her organization, Acumen, invests in people, companies and ideas that see capital and networks as means, not ends, to solving the toughest issues of poverty.

talk: Photographs of secret sites
speaker: Taryn Simon
speaker_bio: With a large-format camera and a knack for talking her way into forbidden zones, Taryn Simon photographs portions of the American infrastructure inaccessible to its inhabitants.

talk: How I harnessed the wind
speaker: William Kamkwamba
speaker_bio: To power his family's home, young William Kamkwamba built an electricity-producing windmill from spare parts and scrap -- starting him on a journey detailed in the book and film "The Boy Who Harnessed the Wind."

talk: How the Net aids dictatorships
speaker: Evgeny Morozov
speaker_bio: Evgeny Morozov wants to know how the Internet has changed the conduct of global affairs, because it certainly has ... but perhaps not in all the ways we think.

talk: The Web as random acts of kindness
speaker: Jonathan Zittrain
speaker_bio: Jonathan Zittrain wants to make sure the electronic frontier stays open -- and he's looking to the Internet's millions of users for its salvation.

talk: "Wait It Out"
speaker: Imogen Heap
speaker_bio: Imogen Heap's aching voice and surprising electronics infuse countless videos and iPods with bone-chilling atmospherics.

talk: An inventory of the invisible
speaker: John Lloyd
speaker_bio: John Lloyd helps make some of the cleverest television in the UK.

talk: 3 warp-speed architecture tales
speaker: Bjarke Ingels
speaker_bio: Bjarke Ingels believes that architecture is the art and science of making sure our cities and buildings fit with the way we want to live our lives.

talk: The real story of McMafia -- how global crime networks work
speaker: Misha Glenny
speaker_bio: Journalist Misha Glenny leaves no stone unturned (and no failed state unexamined) in his excavation of criminal globalization.

talk: How we read each other's minds
speaker: Rebecca Saxe
speaker_bio: Rebecca Saxe studies how we think about other people's thoughts. At the Saxelab at MIT, she uses fMRI to identify what happens in our brains when we consider the motives, passions and beliefs of others.

talk: How I swam the North Pole
speaker: Lewis Pugh
speaker_bio: Pushing his body through epic cold-water swims, Lewis Gordon Pugh wants to draw attention to our global climate. He's just back from swimming in a meltwater lake on the slopes of Mount Everest.

talk: Time-lapse proof of extreme ice loss
speaker: James Balog
speaker_bio: James Balog's latest work, the Extreme Ice Survey, captures the twisting, soaring forms of threatened wild ice.

talk: A leap from the edge of space
speaker: Steve Truglia
speaker_bio: Stuntman and record-setter Steve Truglia was a stunt coordinator, performer and action unit director in the UK.

talk: Making sound visible through cymatics
speaker: Evan Grant
speaker_bio: Evan Grant works with cymatics, the art of visualizing sound, and is the founder of the arts and technology collective seeper.

talk: Post-crash, investing in a better world
speaker: Geoff Mulgan
speaker_bio: Geoff Mulgan is director of the Young Foundation, a center for social innovation, social enterprise and public policy that pioneers ideas in fields such as aging, education and poverty reduction. He’s the founder of the think-tank Demos, and the author of "The Art of Public Strategy."

talk: Adjustable liquid-filled eyeglasses
speaker: Joshua Silver
speaker_bio: Atomic physicist Joshua Silver invented liquid-filled optical lenses to produce low-cost, adjustable glasses, giving sight to millions without access to an optometrist.

talk: One seed at a time, protecting the future of food
speaker: Cary Fowler
speaker_bio: Biodiversity warrior Cary Fowler wants to save the world from agricultural collapse, one seed at a time.

talk: A multimedia theatrical adventure
speaker: Natasha Tsakos
speaker_bio: The president and founder of NTiD inc., Natasha Tsakos brings a creative, innovative vision, and the art of orchestrating and synchronizing various disciplines, to the execution of high-leveled productions.

talk: Let my dataset change your mindset
speaker: Hans Rosling
speaker_bio: In Hans Rosling’s hands, data sings. Global trends in health and economics come to vivid life. And the big picture of global development -- with some surprisingly good news -- snaps into sharp focus.

talk: A demo of wireless electricity
speaker: Eric Giler
speaker_bio: As the CEO of MIT-inspired WiTricity, Eric Giler has a plan to beam electric power through the air to wirelessly power your laptop or recharge your car. You may never plug in again.

talk: The puzzle of motivation
speaker: Dan Pink
speaker_bio: Bidding adieu to his last "real job" as Al Gore's speechwriter, Dan Pink went freelance to spark a right-brain revolution in the career marketplace.

talk: The music of a war child
speaker: Emmanuel Jal
speaker_bio: Emmanuel Jal's hypnotic voice rises from hellish origins as a beacon of hope for those caught in seemingly endless cycles of war and despair.

talk: Biomimicry in action
speaker: Janine Benyus
speaker_bio: A self-proclaimed nature nerd, Janine Benyus' concept of biomimicry has galvanized scientists, architects, designers and engineers into exploring new ways in which nature's successes can inspire humanity.

talk: Why the world needs charter cities
speaker: Paul Romer
speaker_occ: Chief Economist and Senior Vice President, World Bank
speaker_bio: Paul Romer's research on catch-up growth in low- and middle-income countries has emphasized the importance of government policies that encourage orderly urban expansion.

talk: How to make filthy water drinkable
speaker: Michael Pritchard
speaker_bio: With cutting-edge nanotech, Michael Pritchard's Lifesaver water-purification bottle could revolutionize water-delivery systems in disaster-stricken areas around the globe.

talk: Hold your breath for micro-sculpture
speaker: Willard Wigan
speaker_bio: Willard Wigan sculpts figures small enough to fit on the head of a pin. To create these microscopic masterpieces, he works diligently through the stillest hours of the night, between his own heartbeats.

talk: I believe we evolved from aquatic apes
speaker: Elaine Morgan
speaker_bio: Elaine Morgan, armed with an arsenal of television writing credits and feminist credentials, spent her life on a mission to prove humans evolved in water.

talk: Art that looks back at you
speaker: Golan Levin
speaker_bio: Half performance artist, half software engineer, Golan Levin manipulates the computer to create improvised soundscapes with dazzling corresponding visuals. He is at the forefront of defining new parameters for art.

talk: A kinder, gentler philosophy of success
speaker: Alain de Botton
speaker_bio: Through his witty and literate books -- and his new School of Life  -- Alain de Botton helps others find fulfillment in the everyday.

talk: Wiring a web for global good
speaker: Gordon Brown
speaker_bio: Britain's former prime minister Gordon Brown played a key role in shaping the G20 nations' response to the world's financial crisis, and was a powerful advocate for a coordinated global response to problems such as climate change, poverty and social justice.

talk: Skin color is an illusion
speaker: Nina Jablonski
speaker_bio: Nina Jablonski is author of Skin: A Natural History, a close look at human skin’s many remarkable traits: its colors, its sweatiness, the fact that we decorate it.

talk: Exploring the mind of a killer
speaker: Jim Fallon
speaker_bio: Sloan Scholar, Fulbright Fellow, Professor Emeritus of Neuroscience, Jim Fallon looks at the way nature and nurture intermingle to wire up the human brain.

talk: A better way to harvest bone marrow
speaker: Daniel Kraft
speaker_bio: Daniel Kraft explores the impact and potential of rapidly developing technologies as applied to health and medicine.

talk: Playing with space and light
speaker: Olafur Eliasson
speaker_bio: The transparent simplicity and experiential nature of Olafur Eliasson's work has built his reputation as one of the world's most accessible creators of contemporary art.

talk: 4 environmental 'heresies'
speaker: Stewart Brand
speaker_bio: Since the counterculture '60s, Stewart Brand has been creating our internet-worked world. Now, with biotech accelerating four times faster than digital technology, Stewart Brand has a bold new plan ...

talk: A next-gen cure for killer infections
speaker: Kary Mullis
speaker_bio: Kary Mullis won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing a way to copy a strand of DNA. (His technique, called PCR, jump-started the 1990s' biorevolution.) He's known for his wide-ranging interests -- and strong opinions.

talk: Escaping the Khmer Rouge
speaker: Sophal Ear
speaker_bio: Sophal Ear leads research on post-conflict countries -- looking at the effectiveness of foreign aid and the challenge of development in places like his native land, Cambodia.

talk: 3 ways the brain creates meaning
speaker: Tom Wujec
speaker_bio: Tom Wujec studies how we share and absorb information. He's an innovative practitioner of business visualization -- using design and technology to help groups solve problems and understand ideas. He is a Fellow at Autodesk.

talk: The design genius of Charles + Ray Eames
speaker: Eames Demetrios
speaker_bio: Eames Demetrios is the creator of  Kcymaerxthaere, a parallel universe coexisting with our world. He is the grandson of the legendary husband-and-wife design team Charles and Ray Eames.

talk: 17 words of architectural inspiration
speaker: Daniel Libeskind
speaker_bio: Being a designer of breathtaking and sometimes confounding buildings seems almost a footnote to the amazing life of architect Daniel Libeskind.

talk: Life lessons through tinkering
speaker: Gever Tulley
speaker_bio: The founder of the Tinkering School, Gever Tulley likes to build things with kids.

talk: Teach statistics before calculus!
speaker: Arthur Benjamin
speaker_bio: Using daring displays of algorithmic trickery, lightning calculator and number wizard Arthur Benjamin mesmerizes audiences with mathematical mystery and beauty.

talk: My trek to the South Pole
speaker: Ray Zahab
speaker_bio: In January 2009, Ray Zahab broke the record for fastest unsupported trek across Antarctica, to raise awareness and money for kids' environmental education. In 2006, he ran across the Sahara to raise awareness of water shortages. (He started running 5 years ago.)

talk: You are the future of philanthropy
speaker: Katherine Fulton
speaker_bio: President of Monitor Institute, Katherine Fulton is also a strategist, author, teacher and speaker working for social change.

talk: New rules for rebuilding a broken nation
speaker: Paul Collier
speaker_bio: Paul Collier’s book The Bottom Billion shows what is happening to the poorest people in the world, and offers ideas for opening up opportunities to all.

talk: The psychology of time
speaker: Philip Zimbardo
speaker_bio: Philip Zimbardo was the leader of the notorious 1971 Stanford Prison Experiment -- and an expert witness at Abu Ghraib. His book The Lucifer Effect explores the nature of evil; now, in his new work, he studies the nature of heroism.

talk: Surgery's past, present and robotic future
speaker: Catherine Mohr
speaker_bio: Catherine Mohr loves what she does -- she's just not ever sure what it will be next.

talk: How cults rewire the brain
speaker: Diane Benscoter
speaker_bio: Diane Benscoter, an ex-Moonie, is now invested in finding ways to battle extremist mentalities and their potentially deadly consequences.

talk: How social media can make history
speaker: Clay Shirky
speaker_bio: Clay Shirky argues that the history of the modern world could be rendered as the history of ways of arguing, where changes in media change what sort of arguments are possible -- with deep social and political implications.

talk: Life in Biosphere 2
speaker: Jane Poynter
speaker_bio: After weathering two years in Biosphere 2, Jane Poynter is trying to create technologies that allow us to live in hostile environments -- like outer space.

talk: Success is a continuous journey
speaker: Richard St. John
speaker_bio: A self-described average guy who found success doing what he loved, Richard St. John spent more than a decade researching the lessons of success -- and distilling them into 8 words, 3 minutes and one successful book.

talk: Learning from the gecko's tail
speaker: Robert Full
speaker_bio: Robert Full studies cockroach legs and gecko feet. His research is helping build tomorrow's robots, based on evolution's ancient engineering.

talk: Happiness and its surprises
speaker: Nancy Etcoff
speaker_bio: Nancy Etcoff is part of a new vanguard of cognitive researchers asking: What makes us happy? Why do we like beautiful things? And how on earth did we evolve that way?

talk: A plug for smart power outlets
speaker: John La Grou
speaker_bio: John La Grou, a long-time electronics inventor, audio designer and entrepreneur, wants to save lives (and energy) with a new, smarter type of electrical outlet.

talk: Eco-friendly drywall
speaker: Kevin Surace
speaker_bio: Kevin Surace is looking at the climate crisis from an engineer's perspective -- and creating products that prove there's no piece of our daily lives we can't redesign to be cleaner and greener.

talk: The world in 2200
speaker: Pete Alcorn
speaker_bio: Pete Alcorn is the head of podcasting for Apple, and a veteran of the paper-publishing industry.

talk: Odes to vice and consequences
speaker: Felix Dennis
speaker_bio: Former hippie, former jailbird, former aficionado of crack cocaine, Felix Dennis built one of the most successful privately owned magazine empires in the world.

talk: A wide-angle view of fragile Earth
speaker: Yann Arthus-Bertrand
speaker_bio: With photography, Yann Arthus-Bertrand has captured the beauty of the Earth. Through video and film, his latest projects bind together ecology and humanism. For him, it's all about living together.

talk: A university for the coming singularity
speaker: Ray Kurzweil
speaker_bio: Ray Kurzweil is an engineer who has radically advanced the fields of speech, text and audio technology. He's revered for his dizzying -- yet convincing -- writing on the advance of technology, the limits of biology and the future of the human species.

talk: A call to reinvent liberal arts education
speaker: Liz Coleman
speaker_bio: Liz Coleman radically remade Bennington College in the mid-1990s, in pursuit of a new vision: higher education as a performing art.

talk: Playing "Pink Noise" on guitar
speaker: Kaki King
speaker_bio: Kaki King combines jaw-dropping guitar work with dreamy, searching songwriting.

talk: Why we're storing billions of seeds
speaker: Jonathan Drori
speaker_bio: Jonathan Drori commissioned the BBC's very first websites, one highlight in a long career devoted to online culture and educational media -- and understanding how we learn.

talk: The world's English mania
speaker: Jay Walker
speaker_bio: Jay Walker is fascinated by intellectual property in all its forms. His firm, Walker Digital, created Priceline and many other businesses that reframe old problems with new IT. In his private life, he's a bibliophile and collector on an epic scale.

talk: A passionate, personal case for education
speaker: Michelle Obama
speaker_occ: First Lady of the United States
speaker_bio: First Lady Michelle Obama, a lawyer and administrator, is an advocate for working parents and education for girls all around the world.

talk: Don't eat the marshmallow!
speaker: Joachim de Posada
speaker_bio: Joachim de Posada was a speaker and motivational coach. He was the author of "How to Survive Among the Piranhas" and "Don't Eat the Marshmallow ... Yet."

talk: A supercharged motorcycle design
speaker: Yves Béhar
speaker_bio: Yves Béhar is a designer, entrepreneur and avid surfer whose principles for good design have been deeply influential across the field.

talk: Could a Saturn moon harbor life?
speaker: Carolyn Porco
speaker_bio: As the leader of the Imaging Team on the Cassini mission to Saturn, Carolyn Porco interprets and shares the pictures coming back from this fascinating planet, its rings and its moons.

talk: 10 things you didn't know about orgasm
speaker: Mary Roach
speaker_bio: Death, the afterlife, and now sex -- Mary Roach tackles the most pondered and least understood conundrums that have baffled humans for centuries. (She's funny, too.)

talk: Are we in control of our own decisions?
speaker: Dan Ariely
speaker_bio: The dismal science of economics is not as firmly grounded in actual behavior as was once supposed. In "Predictably Irrational," Dan Ariely told us why.

talk: The business logic of sustainability
speaker: Ray Anderson
speaker_bio: Ray Anderson founded the company that makes covetable Flor carpeting. But behind the fresh design is a decades-deep commitment to sustainable ways of doing business -- culminating in the Mission Zero plan.

talk: A full-band beatbox
speaker: Naturally 7
speaker_bio: The group Naturally 7 practices vocal play -- the art of using the human voice to mimic instruments. It's as if a beatboxing troupe decided they could "-box" a whole orchestra: flute, horns, drums, guitar -- building a vocal wall of sound.

talk: Ideas for India's future
speaker: Nandan Nilekani
speaker_bio: Nandan Nilekani is the author of "Imagining India," a radical re-thinking of one of the world’s great economies. The co-founder of Infosys, he helped move India into the age of IT.

talk: Insights on HIV, in stunning data visuals
speaker: Hans Rosling
speaker_bio: In Hans Rosling’s hands, data sings. Global trends in health and economics come to vivid life. And the big picture of global development -- with some surprisingly good news -- snaps into sharp focus.

talk: The tribes we lead
speaker: Seth Godin
speaker_bio: Seth Godin is an entrepreneur and blogger who thinks about the marketing of ideas in the digital age. His newest interest: the tribes we lead.

talk: What comes after An Inconvenient Truth?
speaker: Al Gore
speaker_bio: Nobel Laureate Al Gore focused the world's attention on the global climate crisis.

talk: We need to feed the whole world
speaker: Louise Fresco
speaker_bio: A powerful thinker and globe-trotting advisor on sustainability, Louise Fresco says it's time to think of food as a topic of social and economic importance on par with oil -- that responsible agriculture and food consumption are crucial to world stability.

talk: Anti-gravity sculpture
speaker: Tom Shannon
speaker_bio: Tom Shannon's mixed-material sculpture seems to levitate -- often it actually does -- thanks to powerful magnets and clever arrangements of suspension wire. He designed the TED Prize trophy.

talk: Teach arts and sciences together
speaker: Mae Jemison
speaker_occ: Astronaut, engineer, entrepreneur, physician and educator
speaker_bio: Astronaut Dr. Mae Jemison‘s inclusive, audacious journey to improving life here on earth and beyond is paving the way for human interstellar travel.

talk: The mathematics of war
speaker: Sean Gourley
speaker_bio: Sean Gourley, trained as a physicist, has turned his scientific mind to analyzing data about a messier topic: modern war and conflict. He is a TED Fellow.

talk: What went wrong at the LHC
speaker: Brian Cox
speaker_bio: Physicist Brian Cox has two jobs: working with the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, and explaining big science to the general public. He's a professor at the University of Manchester.

talk: Lessons from the 1918 flu
speaker: Laurie Garrett
speaker_bio: Pulitzer winner Laurie Garrett studies global health and disease prevention. Her books include "The Coming Plague" and "Betrayal of Trust," about the crisis in global public health.

talk: A one-woman global village
speaker: Sarah Jones
speaker_bio: Tony Award-winning monologist, UNICEF ambassador, firebrand and FCC-fighting poet -- Sarah Jones assumes as many roles offstage as on.

talk: Growing evidence of brain plasticity
speaker: Michael Merzenich
speaker_bio: Michael Merzenich studies neuroplasticity -- the brain's powerful ability to change itself and adapt -- and ways we might make use of that plasticity to heal injured brains and enhance the skills in healthy ones.

talk: How ideas trump crises
speaker: Alex Tabarrok
speaker_bio: With the hit economic blog MarginalRevolution.com, co-author Alex Tabarrok generates more hits than a summer hailstorm, and sheds light into the darkest corners of the dismal science.

talk: Comics of bygone New York
speaker: Ben Katchor
speaker_bio: The first MacArthur-winning cartoonist, Ben Katchor has collected both cult and mainstream hat tips for his wry, poetic creations that find uncanny humor (and color) in the commonplace deeds of a bygone New York City.

talk: Does racism affect how you vote?
speaker: Nate Silver
speaker_bio: Math whiz and baseball fan Nate Silver was mainly known for predicting outcomes in fantasy ballgames -- until his technique hit a home run calling the outcome of the 2008 election primaries.

talk: Reporting crisis via texting
speaker: Erik Hersman
speaker_bio: Erik Hersman harnesses Africa’s boundless spirit of innovation by creating platforms to improve daily lives both inside and outside the continent.

talk: Rethinking the way we sit down
speaker: Niels Diffrient
speaker_bio: Design legend Niels Diffrient is the creator of the Freedom Chair, a radical rethink of the way we sit today. Throughout his career, he's been a pioneer of ergonomic design -- studying the human body (in all its shapes and sizes) and how to make it comfortable.

talk: The beautiful math of coral
speaker: Margaret Wertheim
speaker_bio: By masterminding a project to model a coral reef armed only with crochet hooks, Margaret Wertheim hopes to bring some of the most complicated mathematical models embodied in our universe into the minds (and hands) of the masses.

talk: 9 life lessons from rock climbing
speaker: Matthew Childs
speaker_bio: Matthew Childs is an advertising lead at Razorfish. He is a lifelong rock climber and climbing guide.

talk: Smash fear, learn anything
speaker: Tim Ferriss
speaker_bio: Tim Ferriss is an early-stage tech investor, best-selling author and podcaster.

talk: Stunning data visualization in the AlloSphere
speaker: JoAnn Kuchera-Morin
speaker_bio: Composer JoAnn Kuchera-Morin is the director of the Center for Research in Electronic Art Technology (CREATE) at UC Santa Barbara.

talk: To upgrade is human
speaker: Gregory Stock
speaker_bio: Dr. Gregory Stock's levelheaded look at the hotpoints where tech and ethics connect (or short circuit) have made him a popular guest on TV and radio. He directs the Program on Science, Technology, and Society at UCLA.

talk: A new ecosystem for electric cars
speaker: Shai Agassi
speaker_bio: Shai Agassi wants to put you behind the wheel of an electric car -- but he doesn't want you to sacrifice convenience (or cash) to do it.

talk: Our antisocial phone tricks
speaker: Renny Gleeson
speaker_bio: Renny Gleeson helps navigate brands through fresh concepts, such as viral marketing and social media, to find the pulse of the modern consumer.

talk: A theory of everything
speaker: Emily Levine
speaker_bio: Humorist, writer and trickster Emily Levine riffs on science and the human condition.

talk: How bacteria "talk"
speaker: Bonnie Bassler
speaker_bio: Bonnie Bassler studies how bacteria can communicate with one another, through chemical signals, to act as a unit. Her work could pave the way for new, more potent medicine.

talk: A prediction for the future of Iran
speaker: Bruce Bueno de Mesquita
speaker_bio: A consultant to the CIA and the Department of Defense, Bruce Bueno de Mesquita has built an intricate computer model that can predict the outcomes of international conflicts with bewildering accuracy.

talk: Scenes from "My Architect"
speaker: Nathaniel Kahn
speaker_bio: Nathaniel Kahn is an Oscar- and Emmy-nominated maker of documentary films. His journey to understand his distant father -- the legendary modern architect Louis Kahn -- became the film "My Architect."

talk: Military robots and the future of war
speaker: P.W. Singer
speaker_bio: In P.W. Singer's most recent book, "Wired for War," he studies robotic and drone warfighters -- and explores how these new war machines are changing the very nature of human conflict. He has also written on other facets of modern war, including private armies and child soldiers.

talk: The Airstream, restyled
speaker: Christopher C. Deam
speaker_bio: A fascination with clean lines, modern materials and tiny houses made Christopher C. Deam the perfect designer to rethink the Airstream trailer right down to its aluminum skin.

talk: Extreme wingsuit flying
speaker: Ueli Gegenschatz
speaker_bio: Ueli Gegenschatz took flight just about every way a human can: paragliding, skydiving, BASE jumping (from the Eiffel Tower), and most breathtakingly: by donning a wingsuit and soaring.

talk: Can design save newspapers?
speaker: Jacek Utko
speaker_bio: Could good design save the newspaper -- at least for now? Jacek Utko thinks so -- and his lively, engaging designs for European papers prove that it works.

talk: Poetry of youth and age
speaker: C.K. Williams
speaker_bio: Often called a social poet, C.K. Williams was fascinated by the characters of modern civilization and their interactions.

talk: The jungle search for viruses
speaker: Nathan Wolfe
speaker_bio: Armed with blood samples, high-tech tools and a small army of fieldworkers, Nathan Wolfe hopes to re-invent pandemic control -- and reveal hidden secrets of the planet's dominant lifeform: the virus.

talk: The difference between winning and succeeding
speaker: John Wooden
speaker_bio: John Wooden, affectionately known as Coach, led UCLA to record wins that are still unmatched in the world of basketball. Throughout his long life, he shared the values and life lessons he passed to his players, emphasizing success that’s about much more than winning.

talk: Cool tricks your phone can do
speaker: David Pogue
speaker_bio: David Pogue is the personal technology columnist for the New York Times and a tech correspondent for CBS News. He's also one of the world's bestselling how-to authors, with titles in the For Dummies series and his own line of "Missing Manual" books.

talk: An escape from poverty
speaker: Jacqueline Novogratz
speaker_bio: Jacqueline Novogratz works to enable human flourishing. Her organization, Acumen, invests in people, companies and ideas that see capital and networks as means, not ends, to solving the toughest issues of poverty.

talk: High-altitude wind energy from kites!
speaker: Saul Griffith
speaker_bio: Inventor Saul Griffith looks for elegant ways to make real things, from low-cost eyeglasses to a kite that tows boats. His latest projects include open-source inventions and elegant new ways to generate power.

talk: How to grow fresh air
speaker: Kamal Meattle
speaker_bio: With its air-filtering plants and sustainable architecture, Kamal Meattle's office park in New Delhi is a model of green business. Meattle himself is a longtime activist for cleaning up India's air.

talk: What is retro-futurism?
speaker: Bruce McCall
speaker_bio: Illustrator and humorist Bruce McCall paints our imagined future -- a supercharged, streamlined fantasyland that teeters on the edge of hysteria.

talk: My obsession with objects and the stories they tell
speaker: Adam Savage
speaker_bio: Adam Savage is an internationally renowned television producer, host and public speaker.

talk: Our buggy moral code
speaker: Dan Ariely
speaker_bio: The dismal science of economics is not as firmly grounded in actual behavior as was once supposed. In "Predictably Irrational," Dan Ariely told us why.

talk: Cute, sexy, sweet, funny
speaker: Dan Dennett
speaker_bio: Dan Dennett thinks that human consciousness and free will are the result of physical processes.

talk: The next web
speaker: Tim Berners-Lee
speaker_bio: Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web. He leads the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), overseeing the Web's standards and development.

talk: Play is more than just fun
speaker: Stuart Brown
speaker_bio: Stuart Brown's research shows play is not just joyful and energizing -- it's deeply involved with human development and intelligence. Through the National Institute for Play, he's working to better understand its significance.

talk: My 12 pairs of legs
speaker: Aimee Mullins
speaker_bio: A record-breaker at the Paralympic Games in 1996, Aimee Mullins has built a career as a model, actor and advocate for women, sports and the next generation of prosthetics.

talk: Meet the SixthSense interaction
speaker: Pattie Maes
speaker_bio: As head of the MIT Media Lab's Fluid Interfaces Group, Pattie Maes researches the tools we use to work with information and connect with one another.

talk: 3 ways good design makes you happy
speaker: Don Norman
speaker_bio: Don Norman studies how real people interact with design, exploring the gulf between what a designer intends and what a regular person actually wants. His work has resulted in some classic books, including "The Design of Everyday Things."

talk: Learning from dirty jobs
speaker: Mike Rowe
speaker_bio: Mike Rowe is the host of "Dirty Jobs" -- an incredibly entertaining and heartfelt tribute to hard labor.

talk: Conserving the canopy
speaker: Nalini Nadkarni
speaker_bio: Called "the queen of canopy research," Nalini Nadkarni explores the rich, vital world found in the tops of trees. She communicates what she finds to non-scientists -- with the help of poets, preachers and prisoners.

talk: How to restore a rainforest
speaker: Willie Smits
speaker_bio: Willie Smits has devoted his life to saving the forest habitat of orangutans, the "thinkers of the jungle." As towns, farms and wars encroach on native forests, Smits works to save what is left.

talk: Why not make video games for girls?
speaker: Brenda Laurel
speaker_bio: Brenda Laurel has been part of several major revolutions in the way humans use computers: virtual reality, interactive narratives and some fresh approaches to gaming.

talk: The voices of Twitter users
speaker: Evan Williams
speaker_bio: Evan Williams is the co-founder of Twitter, the addictive messaging service that connects the world 140 characters at a time.

talk: My underground art explorations
speaker: Miru Kim
speaker_bio: Miru Kim is a fearless explorer of abandoned and underground places. Her photography underscores the vulnerable nature of the human explorer in these no-woman's-lands.

talk: Seas of plastic
speaker: Charles Moore
speaker_bio: Charles Moore is founder of the Algalita Marine Research Foundation. He captains the foundation's research vessel, the Alguita, documenting the great expanses of plastic waste that now litter our oceans.

talk: How Benjamin Button got his face
speaker: Ed Ulbrich
speaker_bio: Ed Ulbrich works at the leading edge of computer-generated visuals. On a recent project, filmmakers, artists, and technologists have been working at a breakthrough point where reality and digitally created worlds collide.

talk: Join the SETI search
speaker: Jill Tarter
speaker_bio: SETI's Jill Tarter has devoted her career to hunting for signs of sentient beings elsewhere. Winner of the 2009 TED Prize, almost all aspects of her field have been affected by her work.

talk: My wish
speaker: Sylvia Earle
speaker_bio: Sylvia Earle has been at the forefront of ocean exploration for more than four decades. The winner of the 2009 TED Prize, she's a tireless advocate for our oceans.

talk: El Sistema's top youth orchestra
speaker: Gustavo Dudamel and the Teresa Carreño Youth Orchestra
speaker_bio: The Teresa Carreño Youth Orchestra is the national high-school-age youth orchestra of El Sistema, made up of the best young musicians from throughout Venezuela. Gustavo Dudamel, himself a product of El Sistema, is the new musical director of the LA Philharmonic.

talk: The El Sistema music revolution
speaker: José Antonio Abreu
speaker_bio: José Antonio Abreu founded El Sistema in 1975 to help Venezuelan kids learn to play musical instruments and be part of an orchestra. The TED Prize winner's bold idea has seeded hundreds of youth orchestras -- and many happy lives.

talk: The next species of human
speaker: Juan Enriquez
speaker_bio: Juan Enriquez thinks and writes about the profound changes that genomics and brain research will bring about in business, technology, politics and society.

talk: Our loss of wisdom
speaker: Barry Schwartz
speaker_bio: Barry Schwartz studies the link between economics and psychology, offering startling insights into modern life.

talk: Toy tiles that talk to each other
speaker: David Merrill
speaker_bio: David Merrill works on Siftables, tiny computer blocks that interact with each other to make networks (and music).

talk: Using design to make ideas new
speaker: Milton Glaser
speaker_bio: If his career began and ended with "I [heart] N Y," Milton Glaser would still be a legend. But over his multi-decade career, his body of work is sprinkled with similarly iconic images and logos.

talk: Your elusive creative genius
speaker: Elizabeth Gilbert
speaker_bio: The author of "Eat, Pray, Love," Elizabeth Gilbert has thought long and hard about some big topics. Her fascinations: genius, creativity and how we get in our own way when it comes to both.

talk: Mosquitos, malaria and education
speaker: Bill Gates
speaker_bio: A passionate tech visionary, Bill Gates changed the world while leading Microsoft to dizzying success. Now he's doing it again through his global philanthropic work that strives to reduce inequity everywhere.

talk: A solar energy system that tracks the sun
speaker: Bill Gross
speaker_bio: Bill Gross founded Idealab, an incubator of new inventions, ideas and businesses.

talk: Fiddling in reel time
speaker: Natalie MacMaster
speaker_bio: Natalie MacMaster is a star of Cape Breton fiddling, a Canadian tradition with Scottish roots. Her energetic style and virtuoso talent has brought her star billing on the international folk circuit.

talk: Solving medical mysteries
speaker: Joe DeRisi
speaker_bio: Joe DeRisi hunts for the genes that make us sick. At his lab, he works to understand the genome of Plasmodium falciparum, the deadliest form of malaria.

talk: Changing my legs - and my mindset
speaker: Aimee Mullins
speaker_bio: A record-breaker at the Paralympic Games in 1996, Aimee Mullins has built a career as a model, actor and advocate for women, sports and the next generation of prosthetics.

talk: A theory of Earth's mass extinctions
speaker: Peter Ward
speaker_bio: Peter D. Ward studies life on Earth -- where it came from, how it might end, and how utterly rare it might be.

talk: Hypersonic sound and other inventions
speaker: Woody Norris
speaker_bio: Woody Norris is a serial inventor of electronics, tools and cutting-edge sonic equipment -- such as the LRAD acoustic cannon.

talk: The extraordinary power of ordinary people
speaker: Sherwin Nuland
speaker_bio: A practicing surgeon for three decades, Sherwin Nuland witnessed life and death in every variety. Then he turned to writing, exploring what there is to people beyond just anatomy.

talk: Genomics 101
speaker: Barry Schuler
speaker_bio: Barry Schuler's multimedia firm Medior built key interactive technologies for AOL, helping millions connect to the Internet through a simple, accessible interface. Now, through venture capital (and wine appreciation), he wants to do the same for genomics.

talk: Design and discovery
speaker: David Carson
speaker_bio: David Carson is the "grunge typographer" whose magazine Ray Gun helped explode the possibilities of text on a page.

talk: What consumers want
speaker: Joseph Pine
speaker_bio: A writer and veteran consultant to entrepreneurs and executives alike, Joseph Pine's books and workshops help businesses create what modern consumers really want: authentic experiences.

talk: The art and craft of bread
speaker: Peter Reinhart
speaker_bio: Master breadmaker Peter Reinhart is also a teacher, author and theologian. Through his lectures and numerous cookbooks, he channels the science of baking into deep, spiritual lessons -- and dispels stale myths about the nature (and flavor) of good, wholesome bread.

talk: The visual magic of comics
speaker: Scott McCloud
speaker_bio: Scott McCloud is author of Understanding Comics, a comic book about comics. He's an evangelist for comics as a valid literary form (as more than pulp and kids' stuff) and his admiring fans include a laundry list of superstar cartoonists.

talk: Ways of seeing
speaker: Rob Forbes
speaker_bio: Rob Forbes founded Design Within Reach, the furniture company that brought high design to the general public.

talk: Organic algorithms in architecture
speaker: Greg Lynn
speaker_bio: Greg Lynn is the head of Greg Lynn FORM, an architecture firm known for its boundary-breaking, biomorphic shapes and its embrace of digital tools for design and fabrication.

talk: My dream of a flying car
speaker: Paul Moller
speaker_bio: With a team of engineers, Paul Moller works on the Skycar, a combination car and jet, as well as the M200, a saucer-shaped hovering car. He also develops next-generation engines to power these and other amazing vehicles.

talk: Digging up dinosaurs
speaker: Paul Sereno
speaker_bio: Surely not the only science career based on a museum tour epiphany, Paul Sereno's is almost certainly the most triumphant. He's dug up dinosaurs on five continents -- and discovered the world's largest crocodile, the (extinct) 40-foot Sarchosuchus.

talk: My journey in design
speaker: John Maeda
speaker_bio: John Maeda, the former president of the Rhode Island School of Design, is dedicated to linking design and technology. Through the software tools, web pages and books he creates, he spreads his philosophy of elegant simplicity.

talk: Play! Experiment! Discover!
speaker: Kary Mullis
speaker_bio: Kary Mullis won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing a way to copy a strand of DNA. (His technique, called PCR, jump-started the 1990s' biorevolution.) He's known for his wide-ranging interests -- and strong opinions.

talk: The hunt for General Tso
speaker: Jennifer 8. Lee
speaker_bio: Jennifer 8. Lee reports on culture and city life.

talk: Taking OLPC to Colombia
speaker: Nicholas Negroponte
speaker_bio: The founder of the MIT Media Lab, Nicholas Negroponte pushed the edge of the information revolution as an inventor, thinker and angel investor. He's the driving force behind One Laptop per Child, building computers for children in the developing world.

talk: The science of sync
speaker: Steven Strogatz
speaker_bio: In his work in applied mathematics, Steven Strogatz studies the way math and biology intersect.

talk: There might just be life on Mars
speaker: Penelope Boston
speaker_bio: Penelope Boston studies caves and karst formations, and the special biology that lives in them -- both here on Earth and possibly on other planets.

talk: The price of happiness
speaker: Benjamin Wallace
speaker_bio: Benjamin Wallace is a journalist and author of The Billionaire's Vinegar, the true story of the world's most expensive bottle of (possibly phony?) wine. He's been a contributor to GQ, Details, Salon and The Washington Post.

talk: Why we make bad decisions
speaker: Dan Gilbert
speaker_bio: Harvard psychologist Dan Gilbert says our beliefs about what will make us happy are often wrong -- a premise he supports with intriguing research, and explains in his accessible and unexpectedly funny book, Stumbling on Happiness.

talk: My library of human imagination
speaker: Jay Walker
speaker_bio: Jay Walker is fascinated by intellectual property in all its forms. His firm, Walker Digital, created Priceline and many other businesses that reframe old problems with new IT. In his private life, he's a bibliophile and collector on an epic scale.

talk: A plea for bees
speaker: Dennis vanEngelsdorp
speaker_bio: Dennis vanEngelsdorp is Acting State Apiarist for Pennsylvania's Department of Agriculture, studying colony collapse disorder -- the alarming, worldwide disappearance of worker bees and Western honey bees.

talk: The playful search for beauty
speaker: Eva Zeisel
speaker_bio: The legendary Eva Zeisel worked as a ceramics designer -- whose curvy, sensual pieces bring delight and elegance to tabletops around the world.

talk: The joyful tradition of mountain music
speaker: David Holt
speaker_bio: Four-time Grammy Award-winning folk musician David Holt is a born troubadour. Behind his energizing musicianship (often featuring unusual instruments like "the paper bag") is a deep love of hidden Appalachian wisdom and storytelling that shines on every stage he takes.

talk: Demo
speaker: Nick Sears
speaker_bio: Working with his father, Ron Sears, Nick Sears is designing and building the Orb, a rotating LED display that uses persistence of vision to produce moving images in 3D space.

talk: The future of cars
speaker: Larry Burns
speaker_bio: Larry Burns is the vice president of R&D for GM. His job? Find a new way to power cars.

talk: Life in Second Life
speaker: Philip Rosedale
speaker_bio: Philip Rosedale (avatar "Philip Linden") is founder of Second Life, an online 3D virtual world inhabited by millions. He's chair of Linden Labs, the company behind the digital society.

talk: The mysterious lives of giant trees
speaker: Richard Preston
speaker_bio: Richard Preston wrote The Hot Zone, a classic look at the Ebola virus and the scientists who fight it. His wide-ranging curiosity about science and people has led him to cover a dizzying list of topics, with a lapidary attention to detail and an ear for the human voice.

talk: The coming neurological epidemic
speaker: Gregory Petsko
speaker_bio: Gregory Petsko is a biochemist who studies the proteins of the body and their biochemical function. Working with Dagmar Ringe, he's doing pioneering work in the way we look at proteins and what they do.

talk: Do the green thing
speaker: Andy Hobsbawm
speaker_bio:
Andy Hobsbawm is the founder and CMO of Evrythng.com and the founder of
the website Do The Green Thing.

talk: A foie gras parable
speaker: Dan Barber
speaker_bio: Dan Barber is a chef and a scholar -- relentlessly pursuing the stories and reasons behind the foods we grow and eat.

talk: What I'm worried about, what I'm excited about
speaker: Bill Joy
speaker_bio: The co-founder of Sun Microsystems, Bill Joy has, in recent years, turned his attention to the biggest questions facing humanity: Where are we going? What could go wrong? What's the next great thing?

talk: The design of the universe
speaker: George Smoot
speaker_bio: Astrophysicist, cosmologist and Nobel Prize winner George Smoot studies the cosmic microwave background radiation -- the afterglow of the Big Bang. His pioneering research into deep space and time is uncovering the structure of the universe itself.

talk: A tour of Nollywood, Nigeria's booming film industry
speaker: Franco Sacchi
speaker_bio: Franco Sacchi is the director of This Is Nollywood, the story of Nigeria's massive homegrown film industry.

talk: Fashion and creativity
speaker: Isaac Mizrahi
speaker_bio: Fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi mixes high fashion and the mass market, with a line of haute couture and a line for Target. Plus a talk show, a cabaret act, a movie, a new book ...

talk: The Long Now
speaker: Stewart Brand
speaker_bio: Since the counterculture '60s, Stewart Brand has been creating our internet-worked world. Now, with biotech accelerating four times faster than digital technology, Stewart Brand has a bold new plan ...

talk: Tidying up art
speaker: Ursus Wehrli
speaker_bio: Comedian and cabaret artist Ursus Wehrli is on a crusade to tidy up art.

talk: The story behind the Mars Rovers
speaker: Charles Elachi
speaker_bio: Charles Elachi is the director of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, where he oversees space exploration programs such as the Mars Rovers.

talk: A complicated hero in the war on dictatorship
speaker: Samantha Power
speaker_bio: Samantha Power studies US foreign policy, especially as it relates to war and human rights. Her books take on the world's worst problems: genocide, civil war and brutal dictatorships.

talk: Science and democracy
speaker: Lee Smolin
speaker_bio: Lee Smolin is a theoretical physicist, working mainly in the field of quantum gravity. He's a founding member of the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics in Canada, and the author of The Trouble With Physics.

talk: The science of scent
speaker: Luca Turin
speaker_bio: Biophysicist Luca Turin studies the science of smell. He's the author of Perfumes: The Guide, and the subject of Chandler Burr's 2003 book The Emperor of Scent. His next project: developing an artificial nose.

talk: Tales of creativity and play
speaker: Tim Brown
speaker_bio: Tim Brown is the CEO of the "innovation and design" firm IDEO -- taking an approach to design that digs deeper than the surface.

talk: Walk the earth ... my 17-year vow of silence
speaker: John Francis
speaker_bio: John Francis walks the Earth, carrying a message of careful, truly sustainable development and respect for our planet.

talk: The power and the danger of online crowds
speaker: James Surowiecki
speaker_bio: James Surowiecki argues that people, when we act en masse, are smarter than we think. He's the author of The Wisdom of Crowds and writes about finance for the New Yorker.

talk: A flight through the ocean
speaker: Graham Hawkes
speaker_bio: A world-renowned engineer and inventor, Graham Hawkes wants to revolutionize the way we experience the oceans. He created the Deep Flight series of winged submersibles, which "fly" to the depths of the oceans with the power and elegance of an airplane.

talk: The evolution of compassion
speaker: Robert Wright
speaker_bio: The best-selling author of "Nonzero," "The Moral Animal" and "The Evolution of God," Robert Wright draws on his wide-ranging knowledge of science, religion, psychology, history and politics to figure out what makes humanity tick -- and what makes us moral.

talk: Expanding your circle of compassion
speaker: Robert Thurman
speaker_bio: The first American to be ordained a Tibetan Monk by the Dalai Lama, Robert A.F. Thurman is a scholar, author and tireless proponent of peace.

talk: Lose your ego, find your compassion
speaker: Feisal Abdul Rauf
speaker_bio: Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf has devoted himself to healing relations between Muslim-Americans and their neighbors, and bringing that message of peace to the wider Muslim world.

talk: Compassion at the dinner table
speaker: James Forbes
speaker_bio: Known as the preacher’s preacher, Rev. James Forbes is a spiritual leader with charismatic style and radically progressive opinions.

talk: The profound journey of compassion
speaker: Dayananda Saraswati
speaker_bio: Swami Dayananda Saraswati is an acclaimed spiritual teacher and the founder of AIM for Seva -- a charitable trust that works to relieve poverty across India.

talk: The balancing act of compassion
speaker: Jackie Tabick
speaker_bio: As the first woman in the UK to be ordained in the Jewish faith, Rabbi Jackie Tabick has forged a path of inclusiveness from her work’s beginning.

talk: The story of Ezra
speaker: Newton Aduaka
speaker_bio: Newton Aduaka's award-winning Ezra, told through the eyes of a young boy in Sierra Leone, illuminates one of the most harrowing consequences of war: the recruitment of child soldiers.

talk: A story of mixed emoticons
speaker: Rives
speaker_bio: Performance artist and storyteller Rives has been called "the first 2.0 poet," using images, video and technology to bring his words to life.

talk: Why do societies collapse?
speaker: Jared Diamond
speaker_bio: Jared Diamond investigates why cultures prosper or decline -- and what we can learn by taking a broad look across many kinds of societies.

talk: The face of AIDS in Africa
speaker: Kristen Ashburn
speaker_bio: Kristen Ashburn's photographs bring us face-to-face with real people in desperate circumstances. Taking us to the intimate spaces of her subjects -- the victims of war, disaster, epidemic -- she elicits the sublime sadness and resolve of human beings in suffering.

talk: Flow, the secret to happiness
speaker: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi
speaker_bio: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi has contributed pioneering work to our understanding of happiness, creativity, human fulfillment and the notion of "flow" -- a state of heightened focus and immersion in activities such as art, play and work.

talk: Nature vs. humans
speaker: Paul MacCready
speaker_bio: Paul MacCready, an aircraft designer and environmentalist, is a pioneer of human-powered flight, alternative energy for transportation, and environmentally responsible design.

talk: Aliens, love -- where are they?
speaker: John Hodgman
speaker_bio: John Hodgman is a writer, humorist, geek celebrity, former professional literary agent and expert on all world knowledge. He was the bumbling PC in Apple's long-running "I'm a Mac; I'm a PC" ad campaign.

talk: Healing through diet
speaker: Dean Ornish
speaker_bio: Dean Ornish is a clinical professor at UCSF and founder of the Preventive Medicine Research Institute. He's a leading expert on fighting illness -- particularly heart disease with dietary and lifestyle changes.

talk: On glamour
speaker: Virginia Postrel
speaker_bio: Virginia Postrel is a writer and cultural critic who examines the hidden economics of modern society, poking at the unexamined ideas behind the march of progress.

talk: Design and the Elastic Mind
speaker: Paola Antonelli
speaker_bio: Paola Antonelli is on a mission to introduce -- and explain -- design to the world. With her shows at New York's Museum of Modern Art, she celebrates design's presence in every part of life.

talk: Playing invisible turntables
speaker: James Burchfield
speaker_bio: James Burchfield is a human beatbox. Using only his mouth, tongue, throat and vocal cords, he performs heavy, layered, club-style jams that seem to come from real drum machines and lusciously scratched turntables.

talk: The Web as a city
speaker: Steven Johnson
speaker_bio: Steven Berlin Johnson examines the intersection of science, technology and personal experience.

talk: Lessons from past presidents
speaker: Doris Kearns Goodwin
speaker_bio: Doris Kearns Goodwin writes insightful books on the US Presidency (JFK, LBJ, FDR and Lincoln, so far), telling each president's personal story against the backdrop of history.

talk: Are games better than life?
speaker: David Perry
speaker_bio: Dave Perry is the visionary game designer behind some of the most beloved titles of the past two decades -- Earthworm Jim, MDK, Messiah, and game adaptations of films such as Terminator and The Matrix.

talk: Moving photos of extreme drug-resistant TB
speaker: James Nachtwey
speaker_bio: Photojournalist James Nachtwey is considered by many to be the greatest war photographer of recent decades. He has covered conflicts and major social issues in more than 30 countries.

talk: The Blur Building and other tech-empowered architecture
speaker: Elizabeth Diller
speaker_bio: Elizabeth Diller and her maverick firm DS+R bring a groundbreaking approach to projects in architecture, urban design and art by playing with new materials and tampering with space and spectacle in ways that make you look twice.

talk: Politics and religion are technologies
speaker: Noah Feldman
speaker_bio: Noah Feldman studies the intersection of religion, politics and law.

talk: Things I've learned in my life so far
speaker: Stefan Sagmeister
speaker_bio: Renowned for album covers, posters and his recent book of life lessons, designer Stefan Sagmeister invariably has a slightly different way of looking at things.

talk: Robots will invade our lives
speaker: Rodney Brooks
speaker_bio: Rodney Brooks builds robots based on biological principles of movement and reasoning. The goal: a robot who can figure things out.

talk: Human nature and the blank slate
speaker: Steven Pinker
speaker_bio: Steven Pinker is a professor of cognitive science (the study of the human mind) who writes about language, mind and human nature.

talk: Playtime with Pleo, your robotic dinosaur friend
speaker: Caleb Chung
speaker_bio: Caleb Chung dreams up toys that interact with children. He's the inventor of Furby, a talking (and listening) robotic furball that sold some 50 million units in the late '90s. His newest plaything: Pleo the adorable robot dinosaur.

talk: Remember to say thank you
speaker: Laura Trice
speaker_bio: Laura Trice is a counselor, life coach -- and purveyor of wholesome junk food.

talk: The psychology of evil
speaker: Philip Zimbardo
speaker_bio: Philip Zimbardo was the leader of the notorious 1971 Stanford Prison Experiment -- and an expert witness at Abu Ghraib. His book The Lucifer Effect explores the nature of evil; now, in his new work, he studies the nature of heroism.

talk: Health and the human mind
speaker: Marvin Minsky
speaker_bio: Marvin Minsky is one of the great pioneers of artificial intelligence -- and using computing metaphors to understand the human mind. His contributions to mathematics, robotics and computational linguistics are legendary and far-reaching.

talk: How to pitch to a VC
speaker: David S. Rose
speaker_bio: "The Pitch Coach" David S. Rose is an expert on the business pitch. As an entrepreneur, he has raised millions for his own companies. As an investor, he has funded millions more.

talk: What security means to me
speaker: Eve Ensler
speaker_bio: Eve Ensler created the groundbreaking "Vagina Monologues," whose success propelled her to found V-Day -- a movement to end violence against women and girls everywhere.

talk: The moral roots of liberals and conservatives
speaker: Jonathan Haidt
speaker_bio: Jonathan Haidt studies how -- and why -- we evolved to be moral and political creatures.

talk: What's wrong with school lunches
speaker: Ann Cooper
speaker_bio: Ann Cooper cares -- a lot -- what kids eat for lunch. As the head of nutrition for Berkeley, California, schools, she serves organic, regionally sourced and sustainable meals to lots of lucky children.

talk: The camel's hump
speaker: Keith Bellows
