speaker_bio: On the heels of a long and bruising camel ride, Keith Bellows became fascinated with the "SUV of the sand," and with the many thorny aspects of their personalities (and mating habits) most of us would rather not dwell upon.

talk: Life in the deep oceans
speaker: David Gallo
speaker_bio: A pioneer in ocean exploration, David Gallo is an enthusiastic ambassador between the sea and those of us on dry land.

talk: A free digital library
speaker: Brewster Kahle
speaker_bio: Brewster Kahle is an inventor, philanthropist and digital librarian. His Internet Archive offers 85 billion pieces of deep Web geology -- a fascinating look at the formation of the Internet over the years, and a challenge to those who would keep knowledge buried.

talk: How to survive a nuclear attack
speaker: Irwin Redlener
speaker_bio: Dr. Irwin Redlener spends his days imagining the worst: He studies how humanity might survive natural or human-made disasters of unthinkable severity. He's been an outspoken critic of half-formed government recovery plans (especially after Katrina).

talk: How humans and animals can live together
speaker: Jane Goodall
speaker_bio: Dubbed "the woman who redefined man" by her biographer, Jane Goodall has changed our perceptions of primates, people and the connection between the two.

talk: What we think we know
speaker: Jonathan Drori
speaker_bio: Jonathan Drori commissioned the BBC's very first websites, one highlight in a long career devoted to online culture and educational media -- and understanding how we learn.

talk: The web is more than "better TV"
speaker: Peter Hirshberg
speaker_bio: A Silicon Valley executive, entrepreneur and marketing specialist, Peter Hirshberg might just be the definitive voice on how new technology affects business and culture.

talk: Our next giant leap
speaker: Peter Diamandis
speaker_bio: Peter Diamandis runs the X Prize Foundation, which offers large cash incentive prizes to inventors who can solve grand challenges like space flight, low-cost mobile medical diagnostics and oil spill cleanup. He is the chair of Singularity University, which teaches executives and grad students about exponentially growing technologies.

talk: DNA folding, in detail
speaker: Paul Rothemund
speaker_bio: Paul Rothemund folds DNA into shapes and patterns. Which is a simple enough thing to say, but the process he has developed has vast implications for computing and manufacturing -- allowing us to create things we can now only dream of.

talk: A talking, squawking parrot
speaker: Einstein the Parrot
speaker_bio: Einstein, the African grey parrot, has a vocabulary of more than 200 words and sounds; she can perform nearly half on cue.

talk: How I became an activist
speaker: Ory Okolloh
speaker_bio: Ory Okolloh maintains the blog Mzalendo, providing an unprecedented look at the doings of Kenya's parliament -- information once unavailable to Kenyan citizens.

talk: Kids can teach themselves
speaker: Sugata Mitra
speaker_bio: Educational researcher Sugata Mitra is the winner of the 2013 TED Prize. His wish: Build a School in the Cloud, where children can explore and learn from one another.

talk: Great piano performances, recreated
speaker: John Q. Walker
speaker_bio: Software entrepreneur John Q. Walker uses computers to bring piano legends back to life -- digitally reconstructing their performances from audio tracks and playing them on real instruments, live.

talk: "The Dog Song"
speaker: Nellie McKay
speaker_bio: Nellie McKay sings, croons, raps, grooves and -- barks? -- to glowing critical acclaim.

talk: Dog-friendly dog training
speaker: Ian Dunbar
speaker_bio: Veterinarian, dog trainer and animal behaviorist Ian Dunbar understands our pets' point of view. By training dog owners in proper conduct (as much as he trains the dogs themselves), he hopes to encourage better relationships with dogs -- not to mention their friends and children, too.

talk: Close-up card magic with a twist
speaker: Lennart Green
speaker_bio: Cards that fly all over the table, spill onto the floor, and disappear beneath a laser beam. Welcome to the chaotic and flabbergasting magical world of Lennart Green, grand master of close-up card trickery.

talk: How photography connects us
speaker: David Griffin
speaker_bio: As director of photography for National Geographic, David Griffin works with some of the most powerful photographs the world has ever seen.

talk: A family tree for humanity
speaker: Spencer Wells
speaker_bio: Spencer Wells studies human diversity -- the process by which humanity, which springs from a single common source, has become so astonishingly diverse and widespread.

talk: Shedding light on dark matter
speaker: Patricia Burchat
speaker_bio: Patricia Burchat studies the structure and distribution of dark matter and dark energy. These mysterious ingredients can't be measured in conventional ways, yet form a quarter of the mass of our universe.

talk: Watch me fold origami (blindfolded)
speaker: Bruno Bowden
speaker_bio: An engineer with Google (he helped build Google Earth), Bruno Bowden is also an enthusiastic folder of paper.

talk: The math and magic of origami
speaker: Robert Lang
speaker_bio: Robert Lang merges mathematics with aesthetics to fold elegant modern origami. His scientific approach helps him make folds once thought impossible -- and has secured his place as one of the first great Western masters of the art.

talk: A computer that works like the brain
speaker: Kwabena Boahen
speaker_bio: Kwabena Boahen wants to understand how brains work -- and to build a computer that works like the brain by reverse-engineering the nervous system. His group at Stanford is developing Neurogrid, a hardware platform that will emulate the cortex’s inner workings.

talk: The next 5,000 days of the web
speaker: Kevin Kelly
speaker_bio: There may be no one better to contemplate the meaning of cultural change than Kevin Kelly, whose life story reads like a treatise on the value and impacts of technology.

talk: A tour of modern architecture
speaker: Reed Kroloff
speaker_bio: With an outspoken approach to the problems of rebuilding cites and a fearless eye for design, Reed Kroloff is helping to change the urban landscape of cities from New York to New Orleans.

talk: The web as art
speaker: Jonathan Harris
speaker_bio: Artist and computer scientist Jonathan Harris makes online art that captures the world's expression -- and gives us a glimpse of the soul of the Internet.

talk: A dig for humanity's origins
speaker: Louise Leakey
speaker_bio: Louise Leakey hunts for hominid fossils in East Africa, in the family tradition.

talk: On humanity
speaker: Chris Abani
speaker_bio: Imprisoned three times by the Nigerian government, Chris Abani turned his experience into poems that Harold Pinter called "the most naked, harrowing expression of prison life and political torture imaginable." His novels include GraceLand (2004) and The Virgin of Flames (2007).

talk: The wonder of Zulu wire art
speaker: Marisa Fick-Jordan
speaker_bio: South African product designer Marisa Fick-Jordan works with Zulu wire artists to develop a sustainable, worldwide market for their bold and shimmering work.

talk: The new era of positive psychology
speaker: Martin Seligman
speaker_bio: Martin Seligman is the founder of positive psychology, a field of study that examines healthy states, such as happiness, strength of character and optimism.

talk: My year of living biblically
speaker: A.J. Jacobs
speaker_bio: Immersing himself in alternate lifestyles and hilarious experiments (usually with himself as the guinea pig), writer A.J. Jacobs tests the limits of behavior, customs, culture -- and reports back on the wisdom and practical knowledge he's gained.

talk: On technology and faith
speaker: Billy Graham
speaker_bio: In his long career as a religious evangelist, the Rev. Billy Graham spoken to millions around the world and served as advisor to US presidents.

talk: The brain in love
speaker: Helen Fisher
speaker_bio: Anthropologist Helen Fisher studies gender differences and the evolution of human emotions. She’s best known as an expert on romantic love.

talk: Let's look for life in the outer solar system
speaker: Freeman Dyson
speaker_bio: With Freeman Dyson's astonishing forecasts for the future, it was hard to tell where science ended and science fiction began. But far from being a wild-eyed visionary, Dyson was a clear and sober thinker -- and one not afraid of controversy or heresy.

talk: "Mother of Pearl," "If I Had You"
speaker: Nellie McKay
speaker_bio: Nellie McKay sings, croons, raps, grooves and -- barks? -- to glowing critical acclaim.

talk: Institutions vs. collaboration
speaker: Clay Shirky
speaker_bio: Clay Shirky argues that the history of the modern world could be rendered as the history of ways of arguing, where changes in media change what sort of arguments are possible -- with deep social and political implications.

talk: What happens when you lose everything
speaker: David Hoffman
speaker_bio: In David Hoffman's long film career, he's made documentaries on everything from Amelia Earhardt to B.B. King, from double-dutch jump-roping to F-15 fighter pilots. Lately he's been fascinated with the early space program and our mania for all things Sputnik.

talk: Animate characters by evolving them
speaker: Torsten Reil
speaker_bio: By coding computer simulations with biologically modeled nervous systems, Torsten Reil and his company NaturalMotion breathe life into the animated characters inhabiting the most eye-poppingly realistic games and movies around.

talk: A hero of the Congo forest
speaker: Corneille Ewango
speaker_bio: As a botanist at the Okapi Wildlife Reserve in the Congo basin, Corneille Ewango has faced down poachers and soldiers who threaten this delicate and vital ecosystem.

talk: "Peace on Earth"
speaker: Raul Midon
speaker_bio: Guitarist and singer Raul Midon blends flamenco, jazz and R&B to create a category-defying sound. His life story is as inspiring as his musical vision.

talk: The story of a girl
speaker: Rick Smolan
speaker_bio: Rick Smolan is the co-founder of the America 24/7 and Day in the Life photography series -- and a natural storyteller in many media. His latest books are America at Home and Blue Planet Run.

talk: Stephen Hawking's zero g flight
speaker: Peter Diamandis
speaker_bio: Peter Diamandis runs the X Prize Foundation, which offers large cash incentive prizes to inventors who can solve grand challenges like space flight, low-cost mobile medical diagnostics and oil spill cleanup. He is the chair of Singularity University, which teaches executives and grad students about exponentially growing technologies.

talk: "Clonie"
speaker: Nellie McKay
speaker_bio: Nellie McKay sings, croons, raps, grooves and -- barks? -- to glowing critical acclaim.

talk: One Laptop per Child, two years on
speaker: Nicholas Negroponte
speaker_bio: The founder of the MIT Media Lab, Nicholas Negroponte pushed the edge of the information revolution as an inventor, thinker and angel investor. He's the driving force behind One Laptop per Child, building computers for children in the developing world.

talk: The transformative power of classical music
speaker: Benjamin Zander
speaker_bio: A leading interpreter of Mahler and Beethoven, Benjamin Zander is known for his charisma and unyielding energy -- and for his brilliant pre-concert talks.

talk: Surprising stats about child carseats
speaker: Steven Levitt
speaker_bio: Steven Levitt's eye-opening Freakonomics took economic theory into the real world of suburban parenting and urban drug gangs, turning conventional wisdom upside-down.

talk: A mobile fridge for vaccines
speaker: Adam Grosser
speaker_bio: Adam Grosser is a general partner at Foundation Capital -- and a refrigeration visionary.

talk: Robots inspired by cockroach ingenuity
speaker: Robert Full
speaker_bio: Robert Full studies cockroach legs and gecko feet. His research is helping build tomorrow's robots, based on evolution's ancient engineering.

talk: Turning powerful stats into art
speaker: Chris Jordan
speaker_bio: Chris Jordan runs the numbers on modern American life -- making large-format, long-zoom artwork from the most mindblowing data about our stuff.

talk: The birth of the computer
speaker: George Dyson
speaker_bio: In telling stories of technologies and the individuals who created them, George Dyson takes a clear-eyed view of our scientific past -- while illuminating what lies ahead.

talk: The ancestor of language
speaker: Murray Gell-Mann
speaker_bio: Murray Gell-Mann brings visibility to a crucial aspect of our existence that we can't actually see: elemental particles. He won the Nobel Prize in Physics for introducing quarks, one of two fundamental ingredients for all matter in the universe.

talk: The worldwide web of belief and ritual
speaker: Wade Davis
speaker_bio: A National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence, Wade Davis has been described as “a rare combination of scientist, scholar, poet and passionate defender of all of life’s diversity.”

talk: Archeology, animal photography, BBQ ...
speaker: Nathan Myhrvold
speaker_bio: Nathan Myhrvold is a professional jack-of-all-trades. After leaving Microsoft in 1999, he's been a world barbecue champion, a wildlife photographer, a chef, a contributor to SETI, and a volcano explorer.

talk: Memes and "temes"
speaker: Susan Blackmore
speaker_bio: Susan Blackmore studies memes -- those self-replicating "life forms" that spread themselves via human consciousness. We're now headed, she believes, toward a new form of meme, spread by the technology we've created.

talk: The "bottom billion"
speaker: Paul Collier
speaker_bio: Paul Collier’s book The Bottom Billion shows what is happening to the poorest people in the world, and offers ideas for opening up opportunities to all.

talk: A hospital tour in Nigeria
speaker: Seyi Oyesola
speaker_bio: Physician Seyi Oyesola co-developed the "Hospital in a Box" -- a pop-up, portable, solar-powered OR for off-grid medicine in Africa and elsewhere. But, he says, Africa needs more than new tools to heal itself.

talk: Moving sculpture
speaker: Arthur Ganson
speaker_bio: Arthur Ganson's kinetic metal sculptures mix high art with gearhead humor. He's also the inventor of the kids' construction toy Toobers & Zots.

talk: Designing objects that tell stories
speaker: Yves Béhar
speaker_bio: Yves Béhar is a designer, entrepreneur and avid surfer whose principles for good design have been deeply influential across the field.

talk: The astonishing hidden world of the deep ocean
speaker: Robert Ballard
speaker_bio: On more than 120 deep-sea expeditions, Robert Ballard has made many major natural discoveries, such as the deep-sea vents. Oh, and he found the Titanic.

talk: What's wrong with what we eat
speaker: Mark Bittman
speaker_bio: Mark Bittman is a bestselling cookbook author, journalist and television personality. His friendly, informal approach to home cooking has shown millions that fancy execution is no substitute for flavor and soul.

talk: How the news distorts our worldview
speaker: Alisa Miller
speaker_bio: As the CEO of Public Radio International, Alisa Miller works to bring the most significant news stories to millions  -- empowering Americans with the knowledge to make choices in an interconnected world.

talk: A thought experiment on the intelligence of crows
speaker: Joshua Klein
speaker_bio: Joshua Klein is a fervent hacker of all things, including wet, pulpy systems like animals and people and the way they behave.

talk: Juggling as art ... and science
speaker: Michael Moschen
speaker_bio: Quite simply, Michael Moschen has revolutionized juggling, refining it into an art and a bit of a science. With a few flying balls and well-chosen props he will completely re-wire your notions of the physically possible.

talk: Can we domesticate germs?
speaker: Paul Ewald
speaker_bio: After years of studying illness from the germs' point of view, microbiologist Paul Ewald believes that Big Pharma is wrong about some very big issues. What's right? The leader in evolutionary medicine posits radical new approaches.

talk: 6 ways mushrooms can save the world
speaker: Paul Stamets
speaker_bio: Paul Stamets believes that mushrooms can save our lives, restore our ecosystems and transform other worlds.

talk: The thinking behind 50x15
speaker: Hector Ruiz
speaker_bio: The executive chairman of AMD, Hector Ruiz is devoted to his company's 50x15 initiative, which seeks to give 50 percent of the world's population access to the internet by 2015.

talk: Wake up! It's They Might Be Giants!
speaker: They Might Be Giants
speaker_bio: John Linnell and John Flansburgh are They Might Be Giants: multi-instrumental, tech-savvy and implacably prolific, they are the musicians of choice of geeks, tinkerers and curious kids of all ages.

talk: CERN's supercollider
speaker: Brian Cox
speaker_bio: Physicist Brian Cox has two jobs: working with the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, and explaining big science to the general public. He's a professor at the University of Manchester.

talk: Making sense of string theory
speaker: Brian Greene
speaker_bio: Brian Greene is perhaps the best-known proponent of superstring theory, the idea that minuscule strands of energy vibrating in a higher dimensional space-time create every particle and force in the universe.

talk: Where does creativity hide?
speaker: Amy Tan
speaker_bio: Amy Tan is the author of such beloved books as The Joy Luck Club, The Kitchen God's Wife and The Hundred Secret Senses.

talk: World-class health care
speaker: Ernest Madu
speaker_bio: Ernest Madu founded the Heart Institute of the Caribbean, a revolutionary clinic for cardiovascular diseases in Kingston, Jamaica -- revolutionary for offering first-class health care in a developing nation. His next stop: Nigeria.

talk: The new open-source economics
speaker: Yochai Benkler
speaker_bio: Yochai Benkler has been called "the leading intellectual of the information age." He proposes that volunteer-based projects such as Wikipedia and Linux are the next stage of human organization and economic production.

talk: Inventing instruments that unlock new music
speaker: Tod Machover
speaker_bio: At MIT's Media Lab, Tod Machover creates boundary-breaking new music, often using new instruments and music technologies he has invented.

talk: Free or cheap Wii Remote hacks
speaker: Johnny Lee
speaker_bio: Researcher Johnny Lee became a YouTube star with his demo of Wii Remote hacks -- bending the low-cost game piece to power an interactive whiteboard, a multitouch surface, a head-mounted display ...

talk: New thinking on the climate crisis
speaker: Al Gore
speaker_bio: Nobel Laureate Al Gore focused the world's attention on the global climate crisis.

talk: Questioning the universe
speaker: Stephen Hawking
speaker_bio: Stephen Hawking's scientific investigations shed light on the origins of the cosmos, the nature of time and the ultimate fate of the universe. His bestselling books for a general audience have given an appreciation of physics to millions.

talk: A new kind of music video
speaker: Jakob Trollback
speaker_bio: Jakob Trollback is a pioneering designer, whose work in video and motion graphics has helped define the industry -- always pushing the edges of technology and entertainment through design.

talk: Sputnik mania
speaker: David Hoffman
speaker_bio: In David Hoffman's long film career, he's made documentaries on everything from Amelia Earhardt to B.B. King, from double-dutch jump-roping to F-15 fighter pilots. Lately he's been fascinated with the early space program and our mania for all things Sputnik.

talk: The search for the true face of Leonardo
speaker: Siegfried Woldhek
speaker_bio: Siegfried Woldhek knows faces -- he's drawn more than 1,100 of them. Using sophisticated image analysis and his own skills as an artist, he's come up with a fascinating discovery about Leonardo Da Vinci.

talk: The call to learn
speaker: Clifford Stoll
speaker_bio: Astronomer Clifford Stoll helped to capture a notorious KGB hacker back in the infancy of the Internet. His agile mind continues to lead him down new paths -- from education and techno-skepticism to the making of zero-volume bottles.

talk: A look inside the brain in real time
speaker: Christopher deCharms
speaker_bio: Christopher deCharms is working on a way to use fMRI scans to show brain activity -- in real time.

talk: My green agenda for architecture
speaker: Norman Foster
speaker_bio: Lord Norman Foster, winner of the 1999 Pritzker Prize, is perhaps the leading urban stylist of our age. His elegant, efficient buildings grace cities around the globe.

talk: My wish
speaker: Neil Turok
speaker_bio: Neil Turok is working on a model of the universe that explains the big bang -- while, closer to home, he's founded a network of math and science academies across Africa.

talk: My wish
speaker: Karen Armstrong
speaker_bio: Karen Armstrong -- winner of the 2008 TED Prize -- is a provocative, original thinker on the role of religion in the modern world.

talk: My wish
speaker: Dave Eggers
speaker_bio: Writing is only his day job: Dave Eggers moonlights as a publisher, philanthropist and advocate for students and teachers.

talk: My days as a young rebel
speaker: Frank Gehry
speaker_bio: A living legend, Frank Gehry has forged his own language of architecture, creating astonishing buildings all over the world, such as the Guggenheim in Bilbao, the Walt Disney Concert Hall in LA, and Manhattan's new IAC building.

talk: My stroke of insight
speaker: Jill Bolte Taylor
speaker_bio: Brain researcher Jill Bolte Taylor studied her own stroke as it happened -- and has become a powerful voice for brain recovery.

talk: 5 predictions, from 1984
speaker: Nicholas Negroponte
speaker_bio: The founder of the MIT Media Lab, Nicholas Negroponte pushed the edge of the information revolution as an inventor, thinker and angel investor. He's the driving force behind One Laptop per Child, building computers for children in the developing world.

talk: On the verge of creating synthetic life
speaker: Craig Venter
speaker_bio: In 2001, Craig Venter made headlines for sequencing the human genome. In 2003, he started mapping the ocean's biodiversity. And now he's created the first synthetic lifeforms -- microorganisms that can produce alternative fuels.

talk: A powerful idea about ideas
speaker: Alan Kay
speaker_bio: One of the true luminaries of personal computing, Alan Kay conceived of laptops and graphical interfaces years before they were realized. At XeroxPARC, Apple, HP and Disney, he has developed tools for improving the mind.

talk: A preview of the WorldWide Telescope
speaker: Curtis Wong
speaker_bio: Curtis Wong is manager of Next Media Research for Microsoft, whose focus "spans the linear and interactive media spectrum from television, broadband and gaming to emerging media forms." He's a leader on the WorldWide Telescope project.

talk: Model rocketry
speaker: Steve Jurvetson
speaker_bio: Venture capitalist Steve Jurvetson (he brought you Hotmail) is one of the most influential funders and thinkers in Silicon Valley. He's also an enthusiastic hobbyist, blogger and Flickr-er.

talk: A parable for Kenya
speaker: Joseph Lekuton
speaker_bio: A teacher, writer and member of the Kenyan parliament, Joseph Lekuton has an inspiring vision for Kenya.

talk: Juggle and jest
speaker: Raspyni Brothers
speaker_bio: Unapologetic vaudevillians Barry Friedman and Dan Holzman -- the Raspyni Brothers -- have been international juggling champions, Guinness record holders, recurring guests on "The Tonight Show" and, recently, preeminent entertainers on the corporate seminar circuit.

talk: The Jill and Julia Show
speaker: Jill Sobule
speaker_bio: Jill Sobule isn't just another singer-songwriter with catchy tunes and smart lyrics, she's one of the more insightful satirists of our age. Each of her fanciful songs captures an issue or irony, an emotion or epiphany that helps us understand what it's like to live now.

talk: Building uniqueness
speaker: Moshe Safdie
speaker_bio: Moshe Safdie's buildings -- from grand libraries to intimate apartment complexes -- explore the qualities of light and the nature of private and public space.

talk: The story of Project Orion
speaker: George Dyson
speaker_bio: In telling stories of technologies and the individuals who created them, George Dyson takes a clear-eyed view of our scientific past -- while illuminating what lies ahead.

talk: The untouchable music of the theremin
speaker: Pamelia Kurstin
speaker_bio: Pamelia Kurstin excavates a dusty artifact from the prehistoric strata of electronic music -- and demonstrates how to squeeze soul from an instrument you can't even touch.

talk: The new power of collaboration
speaker: Howard Rheingold
speaker_bio: Writer, artist and designer, theorist and community builder, Howard Rheingold is one of the driving minds behind our net-enabled, open, collaborative life.

talk: A plant's-eye view
speaker: Michael Pollan
speaker_bio: Michael Pollan is the author of "The Omnivore’s Dilemma", in which he explains how our food not only affects our health but has far-reaching political, economic and environmental implications.

talk: An illustrated journey through Rome
speaker: David Macaulay
speaker_bio: David Macaulay gets under the skins of skyscrapers, mosques, pyramids, subways, and a host of other ancient and modern marvels. His lavish and micro-detailed renderings expose the world's secret engineering to dazzled readers of all ages.

talk: A song of the city
speaker: Jaime Lerner
speaker_bio: From building opera houses with wire to mapping the connection between the automobile and your mother-in-law, Jaime Lerner delights in discovering eccentric solutions to vexing urban problems. In the process he has transformed the face of cities worldwide.

talk: The idea behind Zipcar (and what comes next)
speaker: Robin Chase
speaker_bio: With Zipcar, Robin Chase introduced car-crazy America to the concept of non-ownership. Now she's flipping that model with Buzzcar, which lets you rent your own auto to your neighbors.

talk: TED's nonprofit transition
speaker: Chris Anderson
speaker_bio: After a long career in journalism and publishing, Chris Anderson became the curator of the TED Conference in 2002 and has developed it as a platform for identifying and disseminating ideas worth spreading.

talk: An unusual glimpse at celebrity
speaker: Alison Jackson
speaker_bio: Why can't you make it through the checkout line without flipping through page after page of pregnant celebs in Us magazine? Alison Jackson knows why. And she photographs the people you think you recognize doing what you really want to see.

talk: The music wars
speaker: David Pogue
speaker_bio: David Pogue is the personal technology columnist for the New York Times and a tech correspondent for CBS News. He's also one of the world's bestselling how-to authors, with titles in the For Dummies series and his own line of "Missing Manual" books.

talk: The life-long learner
speaker: Bernie Dunlap
speaker_bio: Bernie Dunlap is a true polymath, whose talents span poetry, opera, ballet, literature and administration. He is the president of South Carolina’s Wofford College.

talk: Rebuilding a neighborhood with beauty, dignity, hope
speaker: Bill Strickland
speaker_bio: As a Pittsburgh youth besieged by racism in the crumbling remains of the steel economy, Bill Strickland should have been one of the Rust Belt's casualties. Instead, he discovered the potter's wheel, and the transforming power of fountains, irrepressible dreams, and the slide show.

talk: "Tembererana"
speaker: Raul Midon
speaker_bio: Guitarist and singer Raul Midon blends flamenco, jazz and R&B to create a category-defying sound. His life story is as inspiring as his musical vision.

talk: A master architect asks, Now what?
speaker: Frank Gehry
speaker_bio: A living legend, Frank Gehry has forged his own language of architecture, creating astonishing buildings all over the world, such as the Guggenheim in Bilbao, the Walt Disney Concert Hall in LA, and Manhattan's new IAC building.

talk: Treat design as art
speaker: Paola Antonelli
speaker_bio: Paola Antonelli is on a mission to introduce -- and explain -- design to the world. With her shows at New York's Museum of Modern Art, she celebrates design's presence in every part of life.

talk: Underwater astonishments
speaker: David Gallo
speaker_bio: A pioneer in ocean exploration, David Gallo is an enthusiastic ambassador between the sea and those of us on dry land.

talk: The mystery box
speaker: J.J. Abrams
speaker_bio: Writer, director and producer J.J. Abrams makes smart, addictive dramas like TV's Lost, and films like Cloverfield and the new Star Trek.

talk: The emergent genius of ant colonies
speaker: Deborah Gordon
speaker_bio: By studying how ant colonies work without any one leader, Deborah Gordon has identified striking similarities in how ant colonies, brains, cells and computer networks regulate themselves.

talk: We're worried about local warming ... in your lap
speaker: Yossi Vardi
speaker_bio: Investor Yossi Vardi is godfather to more than 40 startups, mostly in the jumping Israeli high-tech sector. He's a legendary community-builder, connector and prankster.

talk: Tales of passion
speaker: Isabel Allende
speaker_bio: Isabel Allende writes stories of passion. Her novels and memoirs, including The House of the Spirits and Eva Luna, tell the stories of women and men who live with passionate commitment -- to love, to their world, to an ideal.

talk: 5 dangerous things you should let your kids do
speaker: Gever Tulley
speaker_bio: The founder of the Tinkering School, Gever Tulley likes to build things with kids.

talk: The lost art of letter-writing
speaker: Lakshmi Pratury
speaker_bio: Lakshmi Pratury is the host of The INK Conference and was the co-host of TEDIndia 2009.

talk: Why aren't we more compassionate?
speaker: Daniel Goleman
speaker_bio: Daniel Goleman, psychologist and award-winning author of Emotional Intelligence and other books on EI, challenges traditional measures of intelligence as a predictor of life success.

talk: A performance of "Mathemagic"
speaker: Arthur Benjamin
speaker_bio: Using daring displays of algorithmic trickery, lightning calculator and number wizard Arthur Benjamin mesmerizes audiences with mathematical mystery and beauty.

talk: Winning the oil endgame
speaker: Amory Lovins
speaker_bio: In his new book, "Reinventing Fire," Amory Lovins shares ingenious ideas for the next era of energy.

talk: Beauty, truth and ... physics?
speaker: Murray Gell-Mann
speaker_bio: Murray Gell-Mann brings visibility to a crucial aspect of our existence that we can't actually see: elemental particles. He won the Nobel Prize in Physics for introducing quarks, one of two fundamental ingredients for all matter in the universe.

talk: Design and destiny
speaker: Philippe Starck
speaker_bio: Philippe Starck designs deluxe objects and posh condos and hotels around the world. Always witty and engaged, he takes special delight in rethinking everyday objects.

talk: The fractals at the heart of African designs
speaker: Ron Eglash
speaker_bio: Ron Eglash is an ethno-mathematician: he studies the way math and cultures intersect. He has shown that many aspects of African design -- in architecture, art, even hair braiding -- are based on perfect fractal patterns.

talk: The sticky wonder of gecko feet
speaker: Robert Full
speaker_bio: Robert Full studies cockroach legs and gecko feet. His research is helping build tomorrow's robots, based on evolution's ancient engineering.

talk: The case for optimism
speaker: Larry Brilliant
speaker_bio: TED Prize winner Larry Brilliant has spent his career solving the world's biggest problems, from overseeing the last smallpox cases to saving millions from blindness.

talk: Using biology to rethink the energy challenge
speaker: Juan Enriquez
speaker_bio: Juan Enriquez thinks and writes about the profound changes that genomics and brain research will bring about in business, technology, politics and society.

talk: A critical look at geoengineering against climate change
speaker: David Keith
speaker_bio: David Keith studies our climate, and the many ideas we've come up with to fix it. A wildly original thinker, he challenges us to look at climate solutions that may seem daring, sometimes even shocking.

talk: Playing with DNA that self-assembles
speaker: Paul Rothemund
speaker_bio: Paul Rothemund folds DNA into shapes and patterns. Which is a simple enough thing to say, but the process he has developed has vast implications for computing and manufacturing -- allowing us to create things we can now only dream of.

talk: Laws that choke creativity
speaker: Lawrence Lessig
speaker_bio: Lawrence Lessig has already transformed intellectual-property law with his Creative Commons innovation. Now he's focused on an even bigger problem: The US' broken political system.

talk: The habits of happiness
speaker: Matthieu Ricard
speaker_bio: Sometimes called the "happiest man in the world," Matthieu Ricard is a Buddhist monk, author and photographer.

talk: How electroshock therapy changed me
speaker: Sherwin Nuland
speaker_bio: A practicing surgeon for three decades, Sherwin Nuland witnessed life and death in every variety. Then he turned to writing, exploring what there is to people beyond just anatomy.

talk: A commodities exchange for Ethiopia
speaker: Eleni Gabre-Madhin
speaker_bio: Eleni Gabre-Madhin is working to build Ethiopia's first commodities market. Re-establishing the profit motive for farmers, she believes, could help turn the world's largest recipient of food aid into a regional food basket.

talk: 3 clues to understanding your brain
speaker: Vilayanur Ramachandran
speaker_bio: Neurologist V.S. Ramachandran looks deep into the brain’s most basic mechanisms. By working with those who have very specific mental disabilities caused by brain injury or stroke, he can map functions of the mind to physical structures of the brain.

talk: The anthropology of mobile phones
speaker: Jan Chipchase
speaker_bio: As Executive Creative Director of global insights for frog design, Jan Chipchase travels around the world and inside our pockets in search of behavioral patterns that will inform the design of products we don't even know we want. Yet.

talk: Building "self-aware" robots
speaker: Hod Lipson
speaker_bio: Hod Lipson works at the intersection of engineering and biology, studying robots and the way they "behave" and evolve. His work has exciting implications for design and manufacturing -- and serves as a window to understand our own behavior and evolution.

talk: Life at 30,000 feet
speaker: Richard Branson
speaker_bio: Richard Branson bootstrapped his way from record-shop owner to head of the Virgin empire. Now he's focusing his boundless energy on saving our environment.

talk: My magic moves
speaker: Kenichi Ebina
speaker_bio: 2013 "America's Got Talent" winner Kenichi Ebina blends hip-hop, martial arts, modern dance, magic and a blast of pop culture in his mesmerizing performances.

talk: This is Saturn
speaker: Carolyn Porco
speaker_bio: As the leader of the Imaging Team on the Cassini mission to Saturn, Carolyn Porco interprets and shares the pictures coming back from this fascinating planet, its rings and its moons.

talk: A flight on solar wings
speaker: Paul MacCready
speaker_bio: Paul MacCready, an aircraft designer and environmentalist, is a pioneer of human-powered flight, alternative energy for transportation, and environmentally responsible design.

talk: 10 ways the world could end
speaker: Stephen Petranek
speaker_bio: Stephen Petranek untangles emerging technologies to predict which will become fixtures of our future lives -- and which could potentially save them.

talk: Designing for simplicity
speaker: John Maeda
speaker_bio: John Maeda, the former president of the Rhode Island School of Design, is dedicated to linking design and technology. Through the software tools, web pages and books he creates, he spreads his philosophy of elegant simplicity.

talk: An Iraq war movie crowd-sourced from soldiers
speaker: Deborah Scranton
speaker_bio: The director of the award-winning documentary The War Tapes, Deborah Scranton is committed to using new technology to give people power to tell their own stories.

talk: The surprising decline in violence
speaker: Steven Pinker
speaker_bio: Steven Pinker is a professor of cognitive science (the study of the human mind) who writes about language, mind and human nature.

talk: What our language habits reveal
speaker: Steven Pinker
speaker_bio: Steven Pinker is a professor of cognitive science (the study of the human mind) who writes about language, mind and human nature.

talk: My creations, a new form of life
speaker: Theo Jansen
speaker_bio: Theo Jansen is a Dutch artist who builds walking kinetic sculptures that he calls a new form of life. His "Strandbeests" walk the coastline of Holland, feeding on wind and fleeing from water.

talk: Aid for Africa? No thanks.
speaker: Andrew Mwenda
speaker_bio: Journalist Andrew Mwenda has spent his career fighting for free speech and economic empowerment throughout Africa. He argues that aid makes objects of the poor -- they become passive recipients of charity rather than active participants in their own economic betterment.

talk: The joy of lexicography
speaker: Erin McKean
speaker_bio: As the co-founder of Reverb Technologies, the maker of the online dictionary Wordnik, Erin McKean is reshaping how we interact with language itself.

talk: Luke, a new prosthetic arm for soldiers
speaker: Dean Kamen
speaker_bio: Dean Kamen landed in the limelight with the Segway, but he has been innovating since high school, with more than 150 patents under his belt. Recent projects include portable energy and water purification for the developing world, and a prosthetic arm for maimed soldiers.

talk: My journey into movies that matter
speaker: Jeff Skoll
speaker_bio: Jeff Skoll was the first president of eBay; he used his dot-com fortune to found the film house Participant Productions, making movies to inspire social change, including Syriana; Good Night, and Good Luck; Murderball; An Inconvenient Truth ...

talk: "Thula Mama"
speaker: Vusi Mahlasela
speaker_bio: South African singer-songwriter Vusi Mahlasela was a crucial artistic voice during the fight against apartheid, and now in the new modern-day nation. Blending traditional African music with soul and blues, his music showcases powerful vocals and poetic lyrics.

talk: Patient capitalism
speaker: Jacqueline Novogratz
speaker_bio: Jacqueline Novogratz works to enable human flourishing. Her organization, Acumen, invests in people, companies and ideas that see capital and networks as means, not ends, to solving the toughest issues of poverty.

talk: Telling stories from Africa
speaker: Chris Abani
speaker_bio: Imprisoned three times by the Nigerian government, Chris Abani turned his experience into poems that Harold Pinter called "the most naked, harrowing expression of prison life and political torture imaginable." His novels include GraceLand (2004) and The Virgin of Flames (2007).

talk: Why invest in Africa
speaker: Euvin Naidoo
speaker_bio: As leading advocate for Western Investment into Africa, BCG's Euvin Naidoo works with leading corporations and governments to strengthen trans-Atlantic economic ties.

talk: How I built a windmill
speaker: William Kamkwamba
speaker_bio: To power his family's home, young William Kamkwamba built an electricity-producing windmill from spare parts and scrap -- starting him on a journey detailed in the book and film "The Boy Who Harnessed the Wind."

talk: Aid versus trade
speaker: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala
speaker_bio: A respected global economist, Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala's parents instilled in her the value of service to others.

talk: Africa's cheetahs versus hippos
speaker: George Ayittey
speaker_bio: Economist George Ayittey sees Africa's future as a fight between Hippos -- complacent, greedy bureaucrats wallowing in the muck -- and Cheetahs, the fast-moving, entrepreneurial leaders and citizens who will rebuild Africa.

talk: How to get (a new) hip
speaker: Allison Hunt
speaker_bio: Allison Hunt has worked in advertising and marketing for 20 years, developing human insight and persuasion into an art for her clients. Six years after getting an artificial hip, she decided to try something new.

talk: Visualizing the wonder of a living cell
speaker: David Bolinsky
speaker_bio: David Bolinsky and his team illustrate scientific and medical concepts with high-drama animation. You've never seen the life of a cell quite like this.

talk: The  4 a.m. mystery
speaker: Rives
speaker_bio: Performance artist and storyteller Rives has been called "the first 2.0 poet," using images, video and technology to bring his words to life.

talk: Spore, birth of a game
speaker: Will Wright
speaker_bio: Will Wright invented a genre of computer game that involves neither winning nor shooting, yet has generated colossal hits. Among them: SimCity (which earned its publisher $230 million), The Sims, and Spore.

talk: Flip your thinking on AIDS in Africa
speaker: Emily Oster
speaker_bio: Emily Oster has a history of rethinking conventional wisdom.

talk: The Web's secret stories
speaker: Jonathan Harris
speaker_bio: Artist and computer scientist Jonathan Harris makes online art that captures the world's expression -- and gives us a glimpse of the soul of the Internet.

talk: The potential of regenerative medicine
speaker: Alan Russell
speaker_bio: In the fight against disease, defect and injury, Alan Russell has a novel argument: Why not engineer new tissue and organs to replace sick ones?

talk: Dangerous memes
speaker: Dan Dennett
speaker_bio: Dan Dennett thinks that human consciousness and free will are the result of physical processes.

talk: Inside the world's deepest caves
speaker: Bill Stone
speaker_bio: Engineer and daredevil cave explorer Bill Stone is obsessed with discovery -- on Earth and beyond.

talk: New insights on poverty
speaker: Hans Rosling
speaker_bio: In Hans Rosling’s hands, data sings. Global trends in health and economics come to vivid life. And the big picture of global development -- with some surprisingly good news -- snaps into sharp focus.

talk: Tour Microsoft's Virtual Earth
speaker: Stephen Lawler
speaker_occ: General manager of Microsoft's Virtual Earth
speaker_bio: Stephen Lawler and the Virtual Earth team have created an addictively interactive 3D world that is poised to reinvent our view of advertising, gaming, weather/traffic reporting, instant messaging and more.

talk: Let's rethink America's military strategy
speaker: Thomas Barnett
speaker_bio: Strategic planner Thomas Barnett has advised US leaders on national security since the end of the Cold War. His bold ideas about the future of warfare and the military are spelled out in his best-selling book The Pentagon's New Map.

talk: A memorial at Ground Zero
speaker: David Rockwell
speaker_bio: Architect David Rockwell draws on his love of drama and spectacle to create fantastic, high-impact restaurants, cultural facilities, airline terminals, theater sets -- and playgrounds.

talk: We can be Buddhas
speaker: Robert Thurman
speaker_bio: The first American to be ordained a Tibetan Monk by the Dalai Lama, Robert A.F. Thurman is a scholar, author and tireless proponent of peace.

talk: Rethink the desktop with BumpTop
speaker: Anand Agarawala
speaker_bio: Anand Agarawala's job: to imagine and build the computers you'll use in 20 years.

talk: Want to help Africa? Do business here
speaker: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala
speaker_bio: A respected global economist, Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala's parents instilled in her the value of service to others.

talk: Salvation (and profit) in greentech
speaker: John Doerr
speaker_bio: John Doerr is an engineer, acclaimed venture capitalist and the chairman of Kleiner Perkins.

talk: How PhotoSynth can connect the world's images
speaker: Blaise Agüera y Arcas
speaker_bio: Blaise Agüera y Arcas works on machine learning at Google. Previously a Distinguished Engineer at Microsoft, he has worked on augmented reality, mapping, wearable computing and natural user interfaces.

talk: Swim with the giant sunfish
speaker: Tierney Thys
speaker_bio: Tierney Thys is a marine biologist and science educator. She studies the behavior of the Mola mola, or giant ocean sunfish -- and works with other scientists to make films that share the wonders they see.

talk: How brain science will change computing
speaker: Jeff Hawkins
speaker_bio: Jeff Hawkins pioneered the development of PDAs such as the Palm and Treo. Now he's trying to understand how the human brain really works, and adapt its method -- which he describes as a deep system for storing memory -- to create new kinds of computers and tools.

talk: What squatter cities can teach us
speaker: Stewart Brand
speaker_bio: Since the counterculture '60s, Stewart Brand has been creating our internet-worked world. Now, with biotech accelerating four times faster than digital technology, Stewart Brand has a bold new plan ...

talk: Human-centered design
speaker: David Kelley
speaker_bio: David Kelley’s company IDEO helped create many icons of the digital generation -- but what matters even more to him is unlocking the creative potential of people and organizations to innovate routinely.

talk: The ghastly tragedy of the suburbs
speaker: James Howard Kunstler
speaker_bio: James Howard Kunstler may be the world’s most outspoken critic of suburban sprawl. He believes the end of the fossil fuels era will soon force a return to smaller-scale, agrarian communities -- and an overhaul of the most destructive features of postwar society.

talk: "Black Men Ski"
speaker: Stew
speaker_bio: Singer-songwriter Stew spins improvisatory songs drawn from his seemingly endless stable of stories and ideas. His musical Passing Strange won a Tony for Best Book in 2008.

talk: The genesis of Google
speaker: Sergey Brin
speaker_bio: Sergey Brin is half of the team that founded Google.

talk: Cape Breton fiddling in reel time
speaker: Natalie MacMaster
speaker_bio: Natalie MacMaster is a star of Cape Breton fiddling, a Canadian tradition with Scottish roots. Her energetic style and virtuoso talent has brought her star billing on the international folk circuit.

talk: Technology's long tail
speaker: Chris Anderson
speaker_bio: Chris Anderson is an authority on emerging technologies and the cultures that surround them.

talk: "La Vie en Rose"
speaker: Rachelle Garniez
speaker_bio: Mischievous and deeply original, accordionist Rachelle Garniez plays her own witty songs and gives a beautiful swing to the classics.

talk: A comic sendup of TED2006
speaker: Tom Rielly
speaker_bio: Traditionally, Tom Rielly closes the TED Conference with a merciless 18-minute monologue, skewering all the speakers with his deadpan delivery, spot-on satire and boundary-less performance (complete with PowerPoint, pratfalls and partial nudity).

talk: Militant atheism
speaker: Richard Dawkins
speaker_bio: Oxford professor Richard Dawkins has helped steer evolutionary science into the 21st century, and his concept of the "meme" contextualized the spread of ideas in the information age. In recent years, his devastating critique of religion has made him a leading figure in the New Atheism.

talk: Why would God create a tsunami?
speaker: Tom Honey
speaker_bio: The Vicar of St David's Church, Exeter, in the UK, is unafraid to take on some of religion's tougher issues.

talk: "What You've Got"
speaker: Eddi Reader
speaker_bio: In her warm, glorious voice, Eddi Reader sings thoughtful songs about love, longing and introspection.

talk: "Kiteflyer's Hill"
speaker: Eddi Reader
speaker_bio: In her warm, glorious voice, Eddi Reader sings thoughtful songs about love, longing and introspection.

talk: A mockingbird remix of TED2006
speaker: Rives
speaker_bio: Performance artist and storyteller Rives has been called "the first 2.0 poet," using images, video and technology to bring his words to life.

talk: The electricity metaphor for the web's future
speaker: Jeff Bezos
speaker_bio: As founder and CEO of Amazon.com, Jeff Bezos defined online shopping and rewrote the rules of commerce, ushering in a new era in business. Time magazine named him Man of the Year in 1999.

talk: Cradle to cradle design
speaker: William McDonough
speaker_bio: Architect William McDonough believes green design can prevent environmental disaster and drive economic growth. He champions “cradle to cradle” design, which considers a product's full life cycle -- from creation with sustainable materials to a recycled afterlife.

talk: How to truly listen
speaker: Evelyn Glennie
speaker_bio: Percussionist and composer Dame Evelyn Glennie lost nearly all of her hearing by age 12. Rather than isolating her, it has given her a unique connection to her music.

talk: The illusion of consciousness
speaker: Dan Dennett
speaker_bio: Dan Dennett thinks that human consciousness and free will are the result of physical processes.

talk: Casting a spell on the cello
speaker: Caroline Lavelle
speaker_bio: Equally talented on cello and vocals, Caroline Lavelle has created a performance style all her own. Her expansive talents, channeling the best of both classical and contemporary influences, have earned her comparisons to both Kate Bush and Jacqueline du Pré.

talk: Global warming's theme song, "Manhattan in January"
speaker: Jill Sobule
speaker_bio: Jill Sobule isn't just another singer-songwriter with catchy tunes and smart lyrics, she's one of the more insightful satirists of our age. Each of her fanciful songs captures an issue or irony, an emotion or epiphany that helps us understand what it's like to live now.

talk: The route to a sustainable future
speaker: Alex Steffen
speaker_bio: Alex Steffen explores our planet's future, telling powerful, inspiring stories about the hard choices facing humanity ... and our opportunity to create a much better tomorrow.

talk: Sampling the ocean's DNA
speaker: Craig Venter
speaker_bio: In 2001, Craig Venter made headlines for sequencing the human genome. In 2003, he started mapping the ocean's biodiversity. And now he's created the first synthetic lifeforms -- microorganisms that can produce alternative fuels.

talk: How to get your ideas to spread
speaker: Seth Godin
speaker_bio: Seth Godin is an entrepreneur and blogger who thinks about the marketing of ideas in the digital age. His newest interest: the tribes we lead.

talk: What separates us from chimpanzees?
speaker: Jane Goodall
speaker_bio: Dubbed "the woman who redefined man" by her biographer, Jane Goodall has changed our perceptions of primates, people and the connection between the two.

talk: Art with wire, sugar, chocolate and string
speaker: Vik Muniz
speaker_bio: Vik Muniz delights in subverting a viewer's expectations. He uses unexpected materials to create portraits, landscapes and still lifes, which he then photographs.

talk: Happiness by design
speaker: Stefan Sagmeister
speaker_bio: Renowned for album covers, posters and his recent book of life lessons, designer Stefan Sagmeister invariably has a slightly different way of looking at things.

talk: The story of life in photographs
speaker: Frans Lanting
speaker_bio: Frans Lanting is one of the greatest nature photographers of our time. His work has been featured in National Geographic, Audubon andTime, as well as numerous award-winning books. Lanting's recent exhibition, The LIFE Project, offers a lyrical interpretation of the history of life on Earth.

talk: How architecture can connect us
speaker: Thom Mayne
speaker_bio: Founder of the influential studio Morphosis, and co-founder of the Southern California Institute of Architecture, Pritzker Prize-winning architect Thom Mayne marries conceptual ideas with form, challenging the way we perceive structure, building and the environment.

talk: The gentle genius of bonobos
speaker: Susan Savage-Rumbaugh
speaker_bio: Susan Savage-Rumbaugh has made startling breakthroughs in her lifelong work with chimpanzees and bonobos, showing the animals to be adept in picking up language and other "intelligent" behaviors.

talk: Software (as) art
speaker: Golan Levin
speaker_bio: Half performance artist, half software engineer, Golan Levin manipulates the computer to create improvised soundscapes with dazzling corresponding visuals. He is at the forefront of defining new parameters for art.

talk: Great cars are great art
speaker: Chris Bangle
speaker_bio: Car design is a ubiquitous but often overlooked art form. As chief of design for the BMW Group, Chris Bangle has overseen cars that have been seen the world over, including BMW 7 Series and the Z4 roadster.

talk: The life code that will reshape the future
speaker: Juan Enriquez
speaker_bio: Juan Enriquez thinks and writes about the profound changes that genomics and brain research will bring about in business, technology, politics and society.

talk: The shrimp with a kick!
speaker: Sheila Patek
speaker_bio: Biologist Sheila Patek is addicted to speed -- animal speed. She's measured the fastest animal movements in the world, made by snail-smashing mantis shrimp and the snapping mandibles of trap-jaw ants.

talk: How we discovered DNA
speaker: James Watson
speaker_bio: Nobel laureate James Watson took part in one of the most important scientific breakthroughs of the 20th century: the discovery of the structure of DNA. More than 50 years later, he continues to investigate biology's deepest secrets.

talk: A philosophical quest for our biggest problems
speaker: Nick Bostrom
speaker_bio: Nick Bostrom works on big questions: What should we do, as individuals and as a species, to optimize our long-term prospects?

talk: Design is in the details
speaker: Paul Bennett
speaker_bio: As a creative director at Ideo, Paul Bennett reminds us that design need not invoke grand gestures or sweeping statements to be successful, but instead can focus on the little things in life, the obvious, the overlooked.

talk: Biomimicry's surprising lessons from nature's engineers
speaker: Janine Benyus
speaker_bio: A self-proclaimed nature nerd, Janine Benyus' concept of biomimicry has galvanized scientists, architects, designers and engineers into exploring new ways in which nature's successes can inspire humanity.

talk: Visual illusions that show how we (mis)think
speaker: Al Seckel
speaker_bio: Al Seckel explored how eye tricks can reveal the way the brain processes visual information -- or fails to do so. Among his other accomplishments: He co-created the Darwin Fish.

talk: My wish
speaker: James Nachtwey
speaker_bio: Photojournalist James Nachtwey is considered by many to be the greatest war photographer of recent decades. He has covered conflicts and major social issues in more than 30 countries.

talk: My wish
speaker: Bill Clinton
speaker_bio: Through his William J. Clinton Foundation, former US President Bill Clinton has become a vital and innovative force for world change. He works in four critical areas: health, economic empowerment, citizen service, and reconciliation.

talk: My wish
speaker: E.O. Wilson
speaker_bio: Biologist E.O. Wilson explores the world of ants and other tiny creatures, and writes movingly about the way all creatures great and small are interdependent.

talk: In praise of slowness
speaker: Carl Honoré
speaker_bio: Carl Honoré loves words: the way they appear on the page, the music they make when spoken and their power to change the world.

talk: Everyday inventions
speaker: Saul Griffith
speaker_bio: Inventor Saul Griffith looks for elegant ways to make real things, from low-cost eyeglasses to a kite that tows boats. His latest projects include open-source inventions and elegant new ways to generate power.

talk: Four American characters
speaker: Anna Deavere Smith
speaker_bio: Anna Deavere Smith's ground-breaking solo shows blur the lines between theater and journalism, using text from real-life encounters to create gripping portraits.

talk: How the "ghost map" helped end a killer disease
speaker: Steven Johnson
speaker_bio: Steven Berlin Johnson examines the intersection of science, technology and personal experience.

talk: The era of open innovation
speaker: Charles Leadbeater
speaker_bio: A researcher at the London think tank Demos, Charles Leadbeater was early to notice the rise of "amateur innovation" -- great ideas from outside the traditional walls, from people who suddenly have the tools to collaborate, innovate and make their expertise known.

talk: Progress is not a zero-sum game
speaker: Robert Wright
speaker_bio: The best-selling author of "Nonzero," "The Moral Animal" and "The Evolution of God," Robert Wright draws on his wide-ranging knowledge of science, religion, psychology, history and politics to figure out what makes humanity tick -- and what makes us moral.

talk: Is this our final century?
speaker: Martin Rees
speaker_bio: Lord Martin Rees, one of the world's most eminent astronomers, is an emeritus professor of cosmology and astrophysics at the University of Cambridge and the UK's Astronomer Royal. He is one of our key thinkers on the future of humanity in the cosmos.

talk: Photos of endangered cultures
speaker: Phil Borges
speaker_bio: Dentist-turned-photographer Phil Borges documents the world's disappearing cultures, capturing portraits of exiled Tibetan monks and many of the world’s embattled tribal and indigenous cultures.

talk: Dreams from endangered cultures
speaker: Wade Davis
speaker_bio: A National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence, Wade Davis has been described as “a rare combination of scientist, scholar, poet and passionate defender of all of life’s diversity.”

talk: Global priorities bigger than climate change
speaker: Bjorn Lomborg
speaker_bio: Danish political scientist Bjorn Lomborg heads the Copenhagen Consensus, which has prioritized the world's greatest problems -- global warming, world poverty, disease -- based on how effective our solutions might be. It's a thought-provoking, even provocative list.

talk: The hidden world of shadow cities
speaker: Robert Neuwirth
speaker_bio: Robert Neuwirth’s writings on the street-level reality of the developing world have opened a new dialogue on development and economics.

talk: If I controlled the Internet
speaker: Rives
speaker_bio: Performance artist and storyteller Rives has been called "the first 2.0 poet," using images, video and technology to bring his words to life.

talk: 8 secrets of success
speaker: Richard St. John
speaker_bio: A self-described average guy who found success doing what he loved, Richard St. John spent more than a decade researching the lessons of success -- and distilling them into 8 words, 3 minutes and one successful book.

talk: The killer American diet that's sweeping the planet
speaker: Dean Ornish
speaker_bio: Dean Ornish is a clinical professor at UCSF and founder of the Preventive Medicine Research Institute. He's a leading expert on fighting illness -- particularly heart disease with dietary and lifestyle changes.

talk: Fight injustice with raw video
speaker: Peter Gabriel
speaker_bio: Peter Gabriel writes incredible songs but, as the co-founder of WITNESS and TheElders.org, is also a powerful human rights advocate.

talk: The accelerating power of technology
speaker: Ray Kurzweil
speaker_bio: Ray Kurzweil is an engineer who has radically advanced the fields of speech, text and audio technology. He's revered for his dizzying -- yet convincing -- writing on the advance of technology, the limits of biology and the future of the human species.

talk: How technology evolves
speaker: Kevin Kelly
speaker_bio: There may be no one better to contemplate the meaning of cultural change than Kevin Kelly, whose life story reads like a treatise on the value and impacts of technology.

talk: Why people believe weird things
speaker: Michael Shermer
speaker_bio: Michael Shermer debunks myths, superstitions and urban legends -- and explains why we believe them. Along with publishing Skeptic Magazine, he's author of Why People Believe Weird Things and The Mind of the Market.

talk: How juries are fooled by statistics
speaker: Peter Donnelly
speaker_bio: Peter Donnelly is an expert in probability theory who applies statistical methods to genetic data -- spurring advances in disease treatment and insight on our evolution. He's also an expert on DNA analysis, and an advocate for sensible statistical analysis in the courtroom.

talk: My wish
speaker: Bono
speaker_bio: Bono, the lead singer of U2, uses his celebrity to fight for social justice worldwide: to end hunger, poverty and disease, especially in Africa. His nonprofit ONE raises awareness via media, policy and calls to action.

talk: My wish
speaker: Robert Fischell
speaker_bio: Robert Fischell invented the rechargeable pacemaker, the implantable insulin pump, and devices that warn of epileptic seizures and heart attacks. Yet it's not just his inventive genius that makes him fascinating, but his determination to make the world a better place.

talk: My wish
speaker: Edward Burtynsky
speaker_bio: 2005 TED Prize winner Edward Burtynsky has made it his life's work to document humanity's impact on the planet. His riveting photographs, as beautiful as they are horrifying, capture views of the Earth altered by mankind.

talk: Why did I ski to the North Pole?
speaker: Ben Saunders
speaker_bio: In 2004, Ben Saunders became the youngest person ever to ski solo to the North Pole. In 2013, he set out on another record-breaking expedition, this time to retrace Captain Scott’s ill-fated journey to the South Pole on foot.

talk: The real future of space exploration
speaker: Burt Rutan
speaker_bio: In 2004, legendary spacecraft designer Burt Rutan won the $10M Ansari X-Prize for SpaceShipOne, the first privately funded craft to enter space twice in a two-week period. He's now collaborating with Virgin Galactic to build the first rocketship for space tourism.

talk: How to rebuild a broken state
speaker: Ashraf Ghani
speaker_bio: Afghanistan's president Ashraf Ghani has initiated sweeping economic, trade, social and peace reforms.

talk: Why we should invest in a free press
speaker: Sasa Vucinic
speaker_bio: Sasa Vucinic's Media Development Loan Fund applies venture-capital principles to create a sustainable free press in developing nations and countries emerging from repressive regimes.

talk: How mobile phones can fight poverty
speaker: Iqbal Quadir
speaker_bio: Iqbal Quadir is an advocate of business as a humanitarian tool. With GrameenPhone, he brought the first commercial telecom services to poor areas of Bangladesh. His latest project will help rural entrepreneurs build power plants.

talk: Invest in Africa's own solutions
speaker: Jacqueline Novogratz
speaker_bio: Jacqueline Novogratz works to enable human flourishing. Her organization, Acumen, invests in people, companies and ideas that see capital and networks as means, not ends, to solving the toughest issues of poverty.

talk: A roadmap to end aging
speaker: Aubrey de Grey
speaker_bio: Aubrey de Grey, British researcher on aging, claims he has drawn a roadmap to defeat biological aging. He provocatively proposes that the first human beings who will live to 1,000 years old have already been born.

talk: Meet the future of cancer research
speaker: Eva Vertes
speaker_bio: Eva Vertes is a microbiology prodigy. Her discovery, at age 17, of a compound that stops fruit-fly brain cells from dying was regarded as a step toward curing Alzheimer's. Now she aims to find better ways to treat -- and avoid -- cancer.

talk: The surprising science of happiness
speaker: Dan Gilbert
speaker_bio: Harvard psychologist Dan Gilbert says our beliefs about what will make us happy are often wrong -- a premise he supports with intriguing research, and explains in his accessible and unexpectedly funny book, Stumbling on Happiness.

talk: The paradox of choice
speaker: Barry Schwartz
speaker_bio: Barry Schwartz studies the link between economics and psychology, offering startling insights into modern life.

talk: Choice, happiness and spaghetti sauce
speaker: Malcolm Gladwell
speaker_bio: Detective of fads and emerging subcultures, chronicler of jobs-you-never-knew-existed, Malcolm Gladwell's work is toppling the popular understanding of bias, crime, food, marketing, race, consumers and intelligence.

talk: The freakonomics of crack dealing
speaker: Steven Levitt
speaker_bio: Steven Levitt's eye-opening Freakonomics took economic theory into the real world of suburban parenting and urban drug gangs, turning conventional wisdom upside-down.

talk: Chemical scum that dream of distant quasars
speaker: David Deutsch
speaker_bio: A pioneer in quantum computation and quantum information theory, David Deutsch now seeks to define the boundaries between the possible and the impossible.

talk: Why the universe seems so strange
speaker: Richard Dawkins
speaker_bio: Oxford professor Richard Dawkins has helped steer evolutionary science into the 21st century, and his concept of the "meme" contextualized the spread of ideas in the information age. In recent years, his devastating critique of religion has made him a leading figure in the New Atheism.

talk: Why we love, why we cheat
speaker: Helen Fisher
speaker_bio: Anthropologist Helen Fisher studies gender differences and the evolution of human emotions. She’s best known as an expert on romantic love.

talk: Happiness in body and soul
speaker: Eve Ensler
speaker_bio: Eve Ensler created the groundbreaking "Vagina Monologues," whose success propelled her to found V-Day -- a movement to end violence against women and girls everywhere.

talk: Meet the founder of the blog revolution
speaker: Mena Trott
speaker_bio: Mena Trott and her husband Ben founded Six Apart in a spare bedroom after the blogging software they developed grew beyond a hobby. With products Movable Type, TypePad, LiveJournal and Vox, the company has helped lead the "social media" revolution.

talk: Nerdcore comedy
speaker: Ze Frank
speaker_bio: Ze Frank has been involved in online comedy, web toys and virtually shared experiences for the past 20 years as an influencer, performer, executive and mischief maker.

talk: The birth of the open-source learning revolution
speaker: Richard Baraniuk
speaker_bio: Richard Baraniuk founded Connexions -- now called OpenStax -- a free, open-source, global clearinghouse of course materials. Students and educators tap into its vast store of texts on everything from engineering to ornithology to music, adapting the content as they see fit.

talk: The birth of Wikipedia
speaker: Jimmy Wales
speaker_bio: With a vision for a free online encyclopedia, Wales assembled legions of volunteer contributors, gave them tools for collaborating, and created the self-organizing, self-correcting, ever-expanding, multilingual encyclopedia of the future.

talk: Organic design, inspired by nature
speaker: Ross Lovegrove
speaker_bio: Known as "Captain Organic," Ross Lovegrove embraces nature as the inspiration for his "fat-free" design. Each object he creates -- be it bottle, chair, staircase or car -- is reduced to its essential elements. His pieces offer minimal forms of maximum beauty.

talk: Simple designs to save a life
speaker: Amy Smith
speaker_bio: Amy Smith designs cheap, practical fixes for tough problems in developing countries. Among her many accomplishments, the MIT engineer received a MacArthur "genius" grant in 2004 and was the first woman to win the Lemelson-MIT Prize for turning her ideas into inventions.

talk: Improvising on piano, aged 14
speaker: Jennifer Lin
speaker_bio: Concert pianist and composer Jennifer Lin was only 14 when she performed at TED, drawing tears with her extraordinary improvisation.

talk: An 11-year-old's magical violin
speaker: Sirena Huang
speaker_bio: Sirena Huang started taking violin lessons at age 4 and made her professional solo debut at 9 with the Taiwan Symphony Orchestra. She has won top prizes in numerous international competitions, delighting audiences worldwide with her virtuosity and charm.

talk: The radical promise of the multi-touch interface
speaker: Jeff Han
speaker_bio: After years of research on touch-driven computer displays, Jeff Han has created a simple, multi-touch, multi-user screen interface that just might herald the end of the point-and-click era.

talk: One Laptop per Child
speaker: Nicholas Negroponte
speaker_bio: The founder of the MIT Media Lab, Nicholas Negroponte pushed the edge of the information revolution as an inventor, thinker and angel investor. He's the driving force behind One Laptop per Child, building computers for children in the developing world.

talk: My wish
speaker: Cameron Sinclair
speaker_bio: 2006 TED Prize winner Cameron Sinclair is co-founder of Architecture for Humanity, a nonprofit that seeks architecture solutions to global crises -- and acts as a conduit between the design community and the world's humanitarian needs.

talk: My wish
speaker: Jehane Noujaim
speaker_bio: TED Prize winner Jehane Noujaim is a gutsy filmmaker whose astonishing documentaries reveal the triumphs and hardships of courageous individuals.

talk: My wish
speaker: Larry Brilliant
speaker_bio: TED Prize winner Larry Brilliant has spent his career solving the world's biggest problems, from overseeing the last smallpox cases to saving millions from blindness.

talk: Let's teach religion -- all religion -- in schools
speaker: Dan Dennett
speaker_bio: Dan Dennett thinks that human consciousness and free will are the result of physical processes.

talk: A life of purpose
speaker: Rick Warren
speaker_bio: Pastor Rick Warren is the author of The Purpose-Driven Life, which has sold more than 30 million copies worldwide. His has become an immensely influential voice seeking to apply the values of his faith to issues such as global poverty, HIV/AIDS and injustice.

talk: Behind the design of Seattle's library
speaker: Joshua Prince-Ramus
speaker_bio: Joshua Prince-Ramus is best known as architect of the Seattle Central Library, already being hailed as a masterpiece of contemporary culture. Prince-Ramus was the founding partner of OMA New York—the American affiliate of the Office for Metropolitan Architecture (OMA) in the Netherlands—and served as its Principal until he renamed the firm REX in 2006.

talk: Letting go of God
speaker: Julia Sweeney
speaker_bio: Julia Sweeney creates comedic works that tackle deep issues like cancer, family and faith.

talk: The best stats you've ever seen
speaker: Hans Rosling
speaker_bio: In Hans Rosling’s hands, data sings. Global trends in health and economics come to vivid life. And the big picture of global development -- with some surprisingly good news -- snaps into sharp focus.

talk: Do schools kill creativity?
speaker: Sir Ken Robinson
speaker_bio: Creativity expert Sir Ken Robinson challenged the way we educate our children, championing a radical rethink of how our school systems cultivate creativity and acknowledge multiple types of intelligence.

talk: Greening the ghetto
speaker: Majora Carter
speaker_bio: Majora Carter redefined the field of environmental equality, starting in the South Bronx at the turn of the century.  Now she is leading the local economic development movement across the USA.

talk: Simplicity sells
speaker: David Pogue
speaker_bio: David Pogue is the personal technology columnist for the New York Times and a tech correspondent for CBS News. He's also one of the world's bestselling how-to authors, with titles in the For Dummies series and his own line of "Missing Manual" books.

talk: Averting the climate crisis
speaker: Al Gore
speaker_bio: Nobel Laureate Al Gore focused the world's attention on the global climate crisis.
